PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
National Flag
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future.
That we are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression.
Nevertheless we recognise the right of all Australians to contribute to any future decisions on the design of the flag.

Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: Object strongly on our behalf to any change being made to the Australian flag without the consent of the entire community through a referendum.
And your petitioners as is duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the proposed Bill of Rights because it adversely affects areas of the liberty and freedom of Australians. It will operate against:
The States and our Federal system of Government
Criminal Justice
The Police
Education
Families
Employer/Employee relations

It will remove the power of the people through Parliament, by giving power to a new more powerful Human Rights Commission which is not elected, but can act as a Star Chamber. We do most earnestly wish to keep our system of Common Law.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights will do nothing to advance the rights of Australians, because it is dangerously ambiguous and will cause confusion within the legal system; it endangers our Federal system; and, it is to be administered in an authoritarian manner inconsistent with the present legal rights of all Australians.
Your Petitioners therefore pray: That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and all cognate Bills.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.

Our petitioners therefore humbly pray: That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Retailers

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, humbly pray that the parliament act to outlaw the practice of the large petrol companies also controlling petrol retail outlets in competition with independent petrol distributers and retailers who they supply, thus acting in a position of unfair competition, and leading to the large companies exerting unconscionable pressure on those independent distributors and retailers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oil Prices

That the Hawke Government should;
Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That certain Trade Unions are currently forcing employers and employees to join union controlled superannuation schemes through industrial blackmail, thereby extending the Unions' economic power and at the same time infringing individual rights. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
(i) Guarantee that Occupational Superannuation is a matter of individual choice;
(ii) Declare illegal industrial standover tactics which force people to join superannuation schemes controlled by, or sponsored by, trade unions;
(iii) Protect those companies and their employees who establish their own superannuation arrangements at the enterprise level;
(iv) Ensure that union or industry-based schemes are not disguised pay rises by providing that employees must also make contributions;
(v) Provide that control of the funds of such schemes is vested in the elected representative of the contributors to those schemes;
(vi) Oppose any backdoor attempts at achieving compulsory unionism.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Tax Fund
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully brings to your attention:
that there are individuals who have a conscientious objection to war because of their religious or general moral principles;
and that the Parliament of this country has already recognised the right of such individuals not to have to participate in military service in time of war;
and that all Australian taxpayers are required to contribute to military expenditure, regardless of their beliefs, through that part of their tax that is used for the Defence budget;

and that while we acknowledge the right of the Government to levy taxes and to decide on the expenditure of money so collected we cannot accept that those with a conscientious objection to war should be forced to contribute to military expenditure.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government will acknowledge the right of those who have a conscientious objection to war to withhold their taxes from military allocations and enable the military related proportion of their taxes to be used for peaceful purposes only and, as we note that taxes are collected or disbursed for specific purposes (such as for Medicare), that the Commissioner for Taxation be directed that the military-related proportion of taxes collected from conscientious objectors to war be set aside in a separate fund, the Peace Tax Fund, to be used only for peaceful purposes, such purposes to be determined by the Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Service Medal
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should seek for Australian merchant seamen's time served on ships of the United States of America to be added to time served on Australian ships during war time to qualify for the Australian Service Medal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: LAWNTON BAPTIST CHURCH
Dear Madam,
In the next session of Parliament the proposed Bill of Rights will come before the Senate to be debated.
We would like to voice our protest at the proposed Bill.
1. Because of the haste with which this legislation was passed through the House of Representatives in view of the fact that it affects adversely areas of immense importance to liberty and freedom.

2. Because it is based upon the United Nations International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights which has been rejected by the United States of America and Great Britain but was accepted the Warsaw Pact countries.

We therefore request that you vote to reject this proposed Bill of Rights.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call on Questions without Notice, I must say that for some time I have been concerned at the increase in the numbers of supplementary questions during Question Time and the types of some questions being submitted as supplementary. It might be recalled that, in 1973, during the presidency of Senator Sir Magnus Cormack, the practice developed of allowing a supplementary question to a questioner. The then President said that, within reasonable limits, he would allow supplementary questions to elucidate an answer already given.

INTERJECT.PARA: This has remained the practice. Since that time successive Presidents have consistently ruled that supplementary questions are appropriate only for the purposes of elucidating information arising from the original question and answer. They are not appropriate for the purpose of introducing additional or new material or proposing a new question, even though such a question might be related to the subject matter of the original question.

I am happy to continue the practice of allowing appropriate supplementary questions, but I remind the Senate of what I have said from time to time-the granting of the opportunity for supplementary questions diminishes the time available for first questions on behalf of other senators. This, of course, must be seen in the context of an increased number of senators in the chamber.

Without reflecting on any senator or senators, it is my impression that recently attempts have been made to extend the scope of supplementary questions by the use of what I would call double-barrelled questions; the second, the supplementary question, being held back for asking, virtually irrespective of the answer to the original. I do not believe that is a proper use of the supplementary question procedure which I remind senators is completely within the control of the Chair. Supplementary questions have a useful purpose, to seek a full response to the original question or elucidate information given, but must not extend the parameters of the original question. I do not propose in future to allow supplementary questions which, in the opinion of the Chair, go beyond that limited purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to his admission on Friday in relation to his position as a director of the Industrial Printing and Publicity Co. Ltd that he probably would have been aware that the company held shares in a wide number of industrial shares but that he could not say which companies. With that general knowledge when he became the Federal Minister responsible for industry, the member of Cabinet specifically charged with policy bearing on the future of Australian industry, how can he attempt to justify not having inquired as to the specific holdings of the company? Is this not a clear case of negligence on his part as a senior Minister of the Government?

—I said in answer to questions on Friday in this place what I construed as involving conflict of interest. As I said on Friday, conflict of interest involves a Minister being in a position where, as a result of knowledge and personal financial interest, he might exercise his judgment in one way or another. In that circumstance I said I had no personal financial interests in the affairs of the company and in that circumstance I do not believe I had any conflict of interest.

—I want to ask a supplementary question with very considerable care, Mr President, in light of your ruling. Indeed, the question is simply to ask the Minister, as I originally asked, how he justifies not having inquired into the specific holdings of the company, given his clear responsibilities for industry generally and the policies with respect to industry under this Government.

—Senator Chaney has been pursuing a series of questions, as I understand it, about ministerial conflict of interests, as he sees it. The point I was making on Friday and which I again repeat is that in the exercise of my duties as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce I was not open, at any stage, to my own personal financial welfare being advantaged or disadvantaged by my position--
—That is not the point.
—It may not be the honourable senator's point; it is mine-as a director of the Industrial Printing and Publicity Co. Ltd. That answer, as I said, was given on Friday. I give it again today.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to recent reports about the high prices country consumers, such as those on Eyre Peninsula in South Australia, are paying for petrol? What are the reasons for relatively high country petrol prices? Is it the case that the oil companies and petroleum distributors are seeking to maintain high retail prices in the country at the consumers' expense?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it has to be appreciated at the outset, as I have said previously on this subject, that the Commonwealth Government's legislative authority to control retail prices, including petrol prices, is to a very large degree constrained by constitutional limitations and that constitutional authority to control retail petroleum product prices does lie primarily with the States. We have, however, been able to maintain a wholesale price surveillance system through the Prices Surveillance Authority because of the essentially voluntary co-operation of the State and Territory governments and of the oil industry. But that does not mean that we have the power to enforce any PSA direction if the States or any part of the industry decide to ignore it. Therein, perhaps, lies part of the difficulty in this whole area of retail petroleum prices.

ANSWER.PARA: Retail prices of petrol are generally determined by the refining companies and their distributors and agents. There are familiar and extensive price differences between metropolitan and country areas, but they mainly reflect two factors: One is the higher cost of supply to consumers in country areas, the familiar transport imposts, plus the higher wholesaling and retailing costs which are associated with smaller sales volumes in country locations.

There is a third factor which often quite seriously compounds that basic difference, and that is the existence of discounting near sources of bulk supply, in particular in periods of excess supply or refinery underutilisation. That discounting, which has become almost a fact of life in its ups and downs in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide in particular, does not usually occur in the more remote areas. So country consumers never ever seem to get the benefit of those discount wars that are so much a familiar feature of the landscape from time to time in the major metropolitan areas.

The problem is that petrol prices reflect differences in both supply costs and differing levels of competition. It is not surprising that, for the reasons that I have indicated, these sorts of variations in pricing that do occur are as they are; it is simply a function of seeing a competitive market at work.

I have not been persuaded in most of the specific instances that have been drawn to my attention that country consumers are getting a much worse deal than one would expect them to on the assumptions of a wholesale maximum price being imposed, plus transport costs, plus the margins that are appropriate to essentially small retailers. The difficulty is not so much that prices are being escalated to higher levels than they should be by some collusive activity by the oil refiners and others in country areas; the problem, for country consumers is rather that they have, as I have said, added to the initial disadvantage of extra transport costs and so on, the disadvantages that flow particularly from being so far removed from the hot competitive environment that does give consumers in the major metropolitan areas a benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the definition he gave in his reply to Senator Chaney on the question of conflict of interests. I understand that he also gave a similar definition on the 7.30 Report last Friday. I also draw his attention to the statement by the Prime Minister last Friday that a conflict of interest may exist in individual circumstances even though the personal interests of a Minister or those of his immediate family are not involved. Therefore, I ask: Does the Leader of the Government still say that conflict of interest can occur only in situations where a Minister stands to benefit personally?

—Where a Minister's state of mind in terms of making a decision, as in the exercise of his public duty, is affected by interests of which he is aware and which are of a private nature there would be a conflict of interest. If it is not so affected, there would not be a conflict of interest.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister able to advise the Senate how successful were recent joint defence exercises with Indonesia? Are these exercises likely to continue and possibly include air defence systems? Is the Minister of the opinion that such exercises have enhanced the defence co-operation program between Australia and Indonesia?

—I am advised by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, that since 1972 Australian and Indonesian naval forces have conducted combined maritime exercises in the New Horizon series. The last of those was held in 1984. Those exercises met the aim of improving combined operating procedures between the two navies. As to whether those exercises are likely to be continued and possibly extended, the Minister has advised me that exercises in the New Horizon series will be continued. The next is scheduled to take place later this year in waters off Western Australia. As Mr Beazley indicated during his visit to Indonesia last week, we would also like to see joint exercise activity at some future time in the air defence area, which was specifically mentioned by Senator Elstob. This opportunity and other opportunities for joint exercising are being considered. As to the last part of the honourable senator's question, joint exercises do play a significant role in the enhancement of our overall defence relationship with Indonesia, as do activities such as joint projects and training under the defence co-operation program, senior level visits and professional exchanges. These activities do contribute to the development of a mature and mutually beneficial defence relationship with Indonesia, which supports our own common interest in regional stability and security.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the Minister yet confirm reports that the Indonesian Research and Technology Minister, Dr Yusuf Habibie, has cancelled an official visit to Australia because of the publication last week of an article in the Sydney Morning Herald referring to President Suharto and his business dealings? Will the Government inform Indonesia officially and forthwith that Australia does not accept media censorship from it or any other country? In relation to that, has the Government ever received any sort of information from the Indonesian Government regarding any sort of official inquiry into the murder of five Australian journalists in East Timor by the Indonesian Army in 1975?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, that Dr Habibie has told our Ambassador in Jakarta, Mr Morrison, that he felt he had no option but to cancel the visit because of the publication of an article about President Suharto in the Sydney Morning Herald last week, on 10 April. The only additional point that Mr Hayden would make on behalf of the Government in this respect is that he, on behalf of the Government, has always made it clear to the Indonesian Government that Australia is a pluralistic democratic society and that the right of the media to express itself freely, independently and critically is something which, although it causes us discomfort, we are bound to uphold.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the latter part of the question, the fate of the journalists was one of the matters Mr Hayden raised with the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Dr Mochtar, on his first visit to Indonesia in April 1983. Dr Mochtar assured Mr Hayden on that occasion that no new information had come to light. Official inquiries into the deaths of the journalists have been vigorously and persistently pursued over many years. We regret to say, however, that the information that we have collected is a mixture still of direct and hearsay evidence containing major internal inconsistencies and contradictions. After all this time the Australian Government cannot realistically hold out much hope that firm information will come to hand that will allow us to draw definite conclusions.

ANSWER.PARA: In the general sense, the Queensland Premier and the Bjelke-Petersen Government are dragging Australia down, but in this instance there is the additional reprehensible fact that that Government is dragging down Queensland's second most important industry as well because of the Premier's obstinacy, ignorance and Otto the Hun-like attitude towards any form of co-operation with the Commonwealth Government for the benefit of a major Queensland industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and it follows his extraordinary answer to Senator Collard that suggested that the existence of a conflict of interest, where there is no personal interest, depends on whether a Minister's state of mind is affected. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether in a case where a Minister is involved in decisions to pay Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd more than $70m a year by way of bounty for each of the five years from 1 January 1984, there is no need to declare the interest if the Minister decides that his state of mind is unaffected or if he does not bother to check on a shareholding which existed when he was an active director of a company of which he was still a director when the decision was made. Is there any objective test or is this a totally subjective matter, depending on the whim of the Minister's mind at the time of the decision-making?

—It is not a question of whether there is any objective test. The first and most essential point is whether the Minister has anything personally to gain financially from exercising his ministerial discretion in a particular way. That is what conflict of interest is all about.
—That is not what the Prime Minister said.

—Senator Chaney interjects that that is not what the Prime Minister said. I am quite aware of what is in the Prime Minister's statement on this matter and I commend Senator Chaney to read it with greater care.
—It goes beyond personal interest.

—Do not get excited. The fact of the matter is that there is an objective test in that regard and there is also a series of subjective tests-so subjective in the case of the previous Government that it was not prepared to tell the public at all what Ministers' interests were. That was a matter for the privacy of the Cabinet. Senator Chaney talks about subjectivity, but he should have a look at his own Party's standards in relation to subjectivity before he makes pious and sanctimonious judgments about me.

—My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. While I and other senators are aware of the efforts he has made to overcome the long delays in the repatriation determining system, the Minister will be aware that we are continuing to receive complaints about delays. Can he indicate what progress has been made to date in bringing determination times down to acceptable levels and when, on present trends, he expects to achieve his target?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —All senators would be aware of the completely unacceptable and inordinate delays that have occurred in the determining system in recent years. No Minister or government could be satisfied with the delays, having regard particularly to the age component of veterans who served in World War I or World War II. Questions similar to the question asked by Senator Devlin have been asked in Estimates committees and in the Senate. It is true that there have been long and unacceptable delays. The Government has taken a number of steps to overcome these intolerable delays, including the new legislation which the Senate passed in 1984 and which led to the overhauled and streamlined determining system which began on 1 January 1985. In addition to that, the Government has put on extra staff and arranged for more outside medical appointments within the medical profession to assist in the determination of claims.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I have to say that, despite all those steps that have been taken, unacceptably long delays are still taking place. However, I am able to tell Senator Devlin and the Senate that in this financial year at the primary level we have reduced the backlog of entitlement claims by 29 per cent and assessment cases by 43 per cent. We have taken steps to ensure that those new processes will achieve even greater success in the immediate period. All told we have finalised 57 per cent more cases at the primary level to date this financial year than we did in the first nine months of the previous financial year. However, no matter how encouraging that evidence is, we are still concerned at the growing backlog at the level of the Veterans Review Board.

I am not able to tell Senator Devlin precisely when we will achieve the target that we had placed in the determining system of a 90-day average processing period. A table has been provided, arising out of questions asked of me in the Senate Estimates Committee last Thursday. This table shows some progress in determining the claims with which the system is plagued. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this table, which shows that, while considerable progress has been made, we are still in a position of not finding it as satisfactory as we had hoped.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to earlier requests for the release of information given to the ministerial committee by Bell Resources Ltd and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd on which the committee based its view that no action was required in the national interest. I ask: Will the Government release the information without further delay?

—Certainly, as Senator Sir John Carrick knows, I indicated that it was the Government's intention to release those documents at the conclusion of the case in the Supreme Court of Victoria before Mr Justice Marks. Of course, further litigation is proceeding in the Supreme Court of Victoria and the Federal Court of Australia at this time relating to some of the issues which were in dispute at the time that the original Part A statement was lodged by Bell Resources Ltd. I cannot answer without referring this matter to other colleagues in the Ministry who are concerned with the matter, but it is still the Government's intention to publish the documents. I am not sure whether we can do so with good faith to the parties at this time.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs: What is the Government's attitude to the possible escalation of tensions between the United States of America and Libya? Will the Minister advise the Senate how many Australians are currently in Libya and whether they will be advised to leave that country, considering the present situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators will of course be aware of speculation about a further United States military engagement with Libya. Following the engagement between the United States and Libya in the Gulf of Sidra last month, Libya threatened terrorist acts against United States diplomatic missions around the world. Since then there has been the bombing of the Trans World Airlines aircraft over Greece and the terrorist attack on Americans in West Berlin. It is a matter of most serious concern that there is a substantial and growing body of evidence of Libyan involvement in international terrorism. Such behaviour is totally unacceptable to the international community and represents an extreme act of hostility towards other nations. The United States has been, with justification, deeply concerned at the number of terrorist incidents in recent months in which American property and American citizens have been subjected to violent attack. While the frustration of the United States over these attacks and threats can be fully understood, it is the Australian Government's position that it hopes that confrontation between the United States and Libya will not escalate further and that restraint will be shown by both sides. Mr Hayden has already publicly expressed the Government's views on this matter to that effect.

ANSWER.PARA: The current tension between the United States and Libya is being discussed in the Security Council, and Mr Hayden has instructed our delegation to participate actively in the Council's consideration of this matter. I should add, finally, on this general issue that it remains the firm view of the Australian Government that terrorism in all its forms must be unreservedly condemned and that it will only be through concerted international action and attention to the root causes of terrorism that this problem will be effectively combated. The Australian Government, once again, calls on all nations to work together to actively discourage and counter terrorism.

As to the latter and more specific part of Senator Foreman's question, the latest information available, I am told by the Department of Foreign Affairs, is that 44 Australian citizens are known to be in Libya. The Embassy of the Federal Republic of Germany, in Tripoli, represents Australian consular interests in Libya. In March, when there was heightened tension in Libya, the Australian Government did not issue a travel warning to Australian citizens. It is not considered appropriate to issue a travel warning at this time. However, the Department of Foreign Affairs is closely monitoring the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance, both in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to weekend reports that the Government will not be able to bring down a mini-Budget or statement of expenditure cuts in May or June. Will there be a major statement on Government spending this year, as there was in May 1985, even though that was shown to be quite unsuccessful? If not, is that because Ministers on the Expenditure Review Committee have been unable to come up with savings of more than about $300m, or is it because of fears of provoking delegates to the July conference of the Australian Labor Party?

—I am not going to satisfy Senator Messner's idle curiosity about whether there will be a statement in May or June, or at any other time. He referred to the 1985 statement as being unsuccessful. I do not know on what grounds he judged it to be unsuccessful. It is true that a number of the savings which had been identified in the May statement were subsequently not achieved because they were sabotaged in the Senate by Senator Messner and his colleagues. Therefore, the entire savings have not been achieved. However, compare that with the previous puny effort of the discredited Fraser-Howard Government in 1981, which produced a lot of propaganda over many months over his razor gang exercise and the huge slashes that were going to be made into government expenditure as announced in May 1981. As I recall it, that amounted in total to a saving of about $200m, most of which was never achieved.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Recently the Minister announced grants to ex-service organisations for joint venture projects to assist elderly veterans and war widows. Unlike other States, Queensland had a high number of approvals for projects to provide help with the home and garden maintenance. Why was this so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government provided $600,000 in the last Budget for the establishment of what were called joint ventures. This has been a recognition of community initiatives to keep elderly veterans in their homes, as well as war widows, as long as that is possible and safe. The response to this Government initiative from community organisations has been overwhelmingly successful. An examination of the schedule shows that the response has been particularly high in Queensland. Part of the Government's philosophy in respect of care of the aged is that the quality of life for aged persons would be improved if we were able to avoid unnecessary institutionalisation. That, of course, is part of our experience from the home care initiative that we took two years ago. Approval generally throughout Australia, and particularly in Queensland, has been given to such programs as day clubs, wood chopping, exercise programs, garden and home maintenance, craft programs and telephone links for blinded soldiers, all of which are designed to provide a better quality of life for the people concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: However, an examination of the initiatives that we have received shows that Queensland provides very little assistance to the aged and pensioners. The Grants Commission estimates that Queensland spends 60 per cent less on welfare than the average in other Australian States. That explains why we had this overwhelming response from Queensland where a means test on community care projects severely affects the eligibility of a great number of pensioners, particularly veterans. Therefore, there are many more applications for home help projects from Queensland ex-service organisations than from those in other States. The Government is currently giving consideration to approving the greatest number of these projects in the hope that it will assist in improving the quality of life for Queensland veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Senator Button will be aware of the latest balance of payments figures for March which indicate yet another deficit in excess of $1 billion. This means that for the first nine months of this year the deficit is in excess of that for the 12 months for 1984-85. Does the Minister see any basis for comfort in the balance of payments figures for March released today, or does he believe that the elusive J curve effect is still as far away as ever?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Parer on his question. I agree with Mr John Elliott, the new principal shareholder in the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, when he finds it quite staggering to think that the sorts of issues that the Liberal Party of Australia seeks to score points on today have any significance to Australian politics.
—Declare your interest now.
—I am sorry?
—Declare your interest on that matter.

—Of course, the balance of payments figures are not as satisfactory as the Government would wish. The depreciation induced improvement in the current account was expected all along to take some time, particularly when new capacity has to be installed in Australian industry and the essential and large element of imports remains in the transport and heavy equipment area. On a seasonally adjusted basis, I think the March balance of payments figures show some improvement on the February figures. There are, again, one-off factors, such as the purchase of $210m worth of aircraft for Qantas Airways Ltd, which is a large sum having regard to the relatively small difference between the February and March figures. So there are some explanations. I think there is some room for some reasonable encouragement from the figures.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the important point is that in the nine months to March compared with the same period a year earlier, imports have increased by 29 per cent. As I said, that increase was 35 per cent in relation to machinery and transport equipment. That sort of importation will, hopefully, underpin domestic industries' capacity for both import replacement activities and exporting activities which will strengthen the trading position in the longer term. I think it is quite clear now as a matter of public record that I have never had great anticipations about a speedy and deep J curve effect following the devaluation. That has been a matter for judgment by various people concerned, and I suppose my judgment has been a bit more pessimistic than others. It is worth pointing out that a lot of the economists expected a much quicker J curve effect that we have had.

TALK.START.PARA: —So did you.
—No, not I. I do not think that anybody with a knowledge of some of the structural problems of Australian industry would have been so sanguine in assuming that result.

—Has the Minister for Resources and Energy seen Press reports over the weekend which largely are syndications such as Saturday's Melbourne Sun exclusive, headed: `$125 Million Handout to Oil 6'. Do these reports clearly set out what in fact is the Government's position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they do not. If that is the best that the Sun can do by way of an exclusive I fear for the future of the Herald and Weekly Times. The proposed payment was clearly announced by the Treasurer and myself in a very widely reported joint Press statement on 24 February relating to the 1 March import parity price reduction. We then indicated that of the $600m approximate stock loss that was then thought likely to be incurred by the industry, the amount of compensation which the refiners could justifiably claim-both in the market place and through direct Government reimbursement-was of the order of $220m. The figure mentioned in the story over the weekend is clearly consistent with that order of magnitude in identifying a likely government reimbursement under legislation introduced this week of around $125m. I should say that there is a clear justification in principle for at least partial reimbursement of the industry for stock losses incurred as a result of major recent IPP adjustments. It ought to be understood that after all it was as a result of adhering to the Government's domestic crude allocation policy that the industry acquired certainly a good proportion of its higher priced stock in the first place, and secondly it is as a consequence of adhering to the Government's maximum wholesale price policy-as administered through the Prices Surveillance Authority-that it has been unable to fully recoup its stock losses in the market place. To that extent the oil refiners are operating very much in a regulated environment which has to be acknowledged.

ANSWER.PARA: A more immediately significant consideration from the point of view of the Government was the justification for payment of this kind on straightforward revenue protection grounds. If the Government had not in February indicated its willingness to put together a compensation package of the kind that is involved here, with elements both of market place recoupment and of government reimbursement, the reality is that the refiners would not have proceeded with liftings of domestic crude until after the 1 March IPP adjustment had occurred, with a consequent reduction in Government revenue in the order not of $125m as is involved here but of something like $350m. There is the further consideration that in the aftermath of the massive oil price plunge in January, not only the short term operation but also the long term survival of the whole allocation system was at stake. The collapse of that system, had it occurred-which would again have been very likely in the absence of the Commonwealth Government's announced compensation package-would have had quite massive implications, measure- able in many hundreds of millions of dollars, for the balance of payments, for Government revenue, and for the viability of the domestic exploration and production industry, the interests of which are very much present in our minds at the moment. There is much more that can be said about this matter, and there is much more that will be said when the issue is debated in Parliament, but it is useful to clarify the record at the outset in that particular respect so people can appreciate that the story which occupied the entire front page of the Sun on Saturday was in fact a quite considerable beatup.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of an article in the Australian Financial Review of Friday, 11 April, entitled `Labor tilts closer to freer wage policy'? I further ask the Minister whether he agrees with some of the comments made within that article in particular:

QUESTION.PARA: But with the trade account in such a bad state and the need for export growth from outside the traditional agricultural and mineral sectors they want industry agreements that can help the manufacturing sector effectively compete in achieving overseas contracts. As such wage flexibility is being talked about in government circles as a crucial element in achieving long-term economic growth.
Is the Minister able to give any information to the Senate with regard to the development of a freer wage policy or is there no basis at all for the article to which I have referred?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asked me whether I agreed with some of the things in the article. It is very difficult at Question Time to say that I agree with some of the things in the article without having it in front of me--
—You are a very agreeable person.

—It is very difficult to say whether one agrees with some of the things in an article or not without actually seeing them or identifying them. I think the best thing I can say in answer to the general question is this: Of course, the Government relies, has relied and will continue to do so on a centralised wage fixing system as the basis of its wage fixing policy because of the very widespread benefits which we believe it has brought to both wage and industrial stability in Australia. It would be a dogmatic, narrow-minded and thoughtless government if it was composed of people who did not think about issues involving greater flexibility in the wages system at some time in the future. Certainly those thoughts have crossed Ministers' minds. I do not regard this as a dogmatic, inflexible or thoughtless government and, of course, those things have crossed Ministers' minds and have to be discussed from time to time. Having said that, I have no announcement to make at Question Time in the Senate which will satisfy the honourable senator's thoughtful and natural curiosity.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services. I ask: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article by Andrew Casey in the Sun-Herald of 13 April 1986 which says that the Government will cut nursing home beds, and which is very critical of church and charity nursing homes? Do the views expressed in this article represent the views of the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see the article. It was a front page article and was hard to miss. I think the most prominent thing about the article was the fact that the headline which, as Senator Jones said, suggested that the Government was to cut the number of nursing home beds and funding for nursing home beds, did not reflect the article itself. This happens sometimes, of course, when sub-editors or editors are looking for sexy headlines to fairly dull articles. The article did say that it was thought that the Government probably thought that the rate of increase of nursing home beds in the future would not be as rapid as it had been in the last 10 or 15 years. I think that is true. I have said that in this place and a report I will be bringing down later today says that.

ANSWER.PARA: The article does go on to be critical, by implication, of some of the charitable and religious nursing homes-the deficit funded nursing homes-but I think the article was less than fair to them. The article suggested that these nursing homes, in fact, provided care and attention largely for middle class people of the same religion as those who run the nursing homes. Certainly it is true from reading the McLeay Report of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee, the Giles report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes and Senate reports on nursing homes that fewer poor people are in these deficit funded nursing homes than would have been intended by the governments which previously administered the deficit funded scheme, but I think this was the result of faults in the system rather than faults in the churches or charities. I will also be saying something about that later this afternoon when I bring down a report. The headline certainly does not reflect the views of the Government and the report, insofar as it is over harshly critical of religious and charitable nursing homes, equally does not reflect the views of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask: Firstly, what is the Government's attitude to Pine Gap's electronic spy satellites being used to spy on Libya as they were used to spy on Greece and Israel last year? Secondly, has the Government been consulted over the use of North West Cape to communicate with United States naval forces preparing for an attack on Libya? Thirdly, can the Government offer assurances that Darwin will not be used as a staging post for B52s en route to Diego Garcia to support United States actions in Libya? Finally, does the Government believe that such involvement by Australia in attacks on Libya may lead to conflict with that country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to that part of the question concerning Pine Gap, the honourable senator will recognise that I cannot answer his question without being drawn into his speculations about operations of the joint facilities. For very good reasons the Government is quite unwilling to do that, as Senator Sanders well knows. Might I mention though, specifically in relation to his assertion about Greece, that this was a matter well and quite specifically addressed by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, in his Press conference statement of 9 April last year, which I will not now read into the record but I will refer to him afterwards, unless he wants me to read it into the record.
—Yes, read it.
—It states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government maintains its position that it could not confirm or deny anything that is reported to be associated with an operation at Pine Gap. However, we were able to give the community assurances-
he is referring here, of course, to his meeting with representatives of the Greek community which had preceded this conference-

that the judgments made as far as we are concerned about the use of Pine Gap, and indeed our intelligence operations altogether, were made in the light of the fullest consideration of all aspects of Government foreign policy . . . particularly in the area of our being concerned that we operated in a manner that did not destabilise friendly governments. We also gave assurances that we were aware of developments associated with the usage of joint installations and any operations at those joint installations required the acquiescence of the Australian Government at not just official level, but also at the level of Ministers.

I also mention in respect of the Pine Gap reference to Greece that there was a Sun article this morning, 14 April, entitled: `Greek Prime Minister to raise spying row', which I am now assured, through the office of the Prime Minister, is absolutely false. Indeed, there has been a communication from George Papandreou, the Deputy Minister for Culture who is said to have raised this issue when in Australia, to that effect. So if we could manage without some of the more lurid and inaccurate speculations about Pine Gap's operations in the past, we might have a slightly more sensible approach to its operations in the present and future within the limits of what it is possible for any government to say about the operations of that facility.

As to the second part of the question relating to North West Cape, as the honourable senator will appreciate-I hope he does-Libya is a long way from North West Cape. I understand it falls outside that facility's area of operations. North West Cape is concerned primarily with very low frequency communications with submarines in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. Reported US deployments in the Mediterranean off Libya involve primarily aircraft carrier battle groups. Under the arrangements which govern the operations of North West Cape, the Australian Government must be informed of any change of alert status, and specific procedures exist for consultations between the Australian and US governments on developments which may affect the operation or use of the North West Cape facility.

As to the question of Darwin being used as a staging post for B52s en route to Diego Garcia to support US actions in Libya, which was the third part of Senator Sanders's question, I am advised by the Minister for Defence that US B52s staging through Darwin are engaged solely on routine navigational training and maritime surveillance missions. They do not stage through Diego Garcia and they are unarmed. No change in these arrangements is contemplated, and the US has not asked for any.

As to the last part of his question, it should be clear from my previous answers that the Government does not endorse Senator Sanders's supposition that Australia is involved in any way in the tension between Libya and the US. There is, I understand, no specific indication of any threat to Australia arising from the tension in the Mediterranean. Nonetheless, I am advised that the Minister for Defence has taken the precaution of asking his Department to assess whether any additional security measures are called for at US-Australian joint facilities during the current tension.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Education to the announcement last December by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on Youth Affairs concerning the young homeless allowance which was to be implemented in January 1987. Will the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government still intends to proceed with this allowance? To what extent, if any, will the allowance increase the educational opportunities of homeless youth, and will the Minister say what is the amount of the allowance to be paid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the Government was committed to introducing this new allowance which would cover young people who have no support from their families and who are not able to earn income but who wish to continue their education. It was our intention to bring in that allowance at the beginning of next year. However, because we were acutely aware of the number of young people in that situation and of the inadequacy of current allowances or support services to assist them, I am very pleased to inform Senator Crowley and the Senate that we have decided to bring forward by six months the implementation of that allowance scheme. In fact, the new young homeless allowance will be implemented from 1 July this year. This is a very important decision because it will ensure that unsupported young people in genuine need will be provided with adequate and equitable support which, of course, was the objective we announced in the Priority One program.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the effect of the allowance on educational opportunities for those disadvantaged young people, I hope that it will have a very positive effect on improving educational opportunities for them. The situation up to the implementation of this allowance is that such young people normally have no option other than to go on the dole. Once they are in receipt of the dole they are not eligible to pursue studies on a full time basis. This was a particularly unsatisfactory situation for young persons of, say 16 and 17 years of age or, sometimes, even younger, as they would have absolutely no marketable skills and, of course, being on the dole does not give them an opportunity to gain them.

The new provisions will extend the level of assistance to be equal to the independent rate of the tertiary education allowance which, at this stage, is $73.28c per week. That rate will be paid to homeless junior rate social security beneficiaries and to homeless full time students in post-compulsory schooling. I hope, and John Dawkins, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs who, with me, was involved in developing this new scheme, also hopes that it will mean that those young persons not only will have improved economic security but also will be able to use that security to pursue their educational opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. In view of the recent cutbacks in exploration expenditure and, therefore, the cutbacks in employment by oil companies and companies associated with them in the exploration for oil and gas due to the recent and continuing fall in world oil prices and also the high cost structure in Australia, will the Government provide some taxation relief to oil producers, or at least to the smaller producers, such as a cut in the crude oil excise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I announced at last week's Australian Petroleum Exploration Association conference in Adelaide, at the same session at which Senator Durack and the Opposition were given a fairly comprehensive serve by Mr Ted Harris of Ampol Exploration Ltd for the Opposition's numerous misconceived statements about oil industry policy, the Government has embarked on a full scale review of measures that might conceivably be suggested as helping the present situation, particularly with regard to the smaller explorers and producers and the Government will be closely looking at what might be able to be done with regard to excise scales. I am not yet in a position to announce the result of that review. I should make it clear, however, as I made clear at the conference, that even if one were to remove Commonwealth crude oil excise completely on on-shore oil production the amount of revenue involved, on current estimates of on-shore production this coming financial year would be around only $10m.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, concessions of that magnitude, although they might have some marginal utility for some producers, are hardly likely in themselves to solve the problem presently confronted by that category of producer-developer-explorer. The reality is that when one is confronting the kind of tidal wave that the oil industry has been confronting in regard to the plunge in oil prices, an extra oar or two will not necessarily make very much difference in how one handles that market situation. But the Government is extremely sensitive to the problem, sympathetic to the plight of that sector of the industry in particular and will be very closely reviewing the situation in the period immediately ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. What is the purpose of the cost recovery program operating in the airline industry? Is it justified and what is its cost to taxpayers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The early formative years of the Australian airline industry required a great deal of government assistance, encouragement and subsidisation. Consequently, taxpayers were called upon to pay a substantial sum towards those infancy years. However, I think it would have to be accepted by Senator Morris that those days have long passed and the airline industry in Australia is now thriving, to the point where companies, for example, are seeking to break into the industry and overcome the current two airline agreement. The time when the Australian airline industry was entitled to the subsidisation which was necessary to those early days has long passed. We have moved more and more towards a new industry, and one that is capable of standing on its own feet.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that currently taxpayers are paying in excess of half a million dollars a day-precisely $550,000 a day-towards the cost of providing aviation services. The Government believes that that cost should be met fully by the industry. So we are moving towards that position. The Bosch Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery, which was established by the Government to examine ways and means of reaching that more equitable position, has made suggestions to realise the objective. Currently consultations are taking place with both the industry and unions to establish a timetable to ensure that by the time the next Budget is brought down savings of that magnitude-which, if my arithmetic is correct, represent about $200m a year by taxpayers subsidising the industry-will be made. I think we are entitled to suggest that that matter ought to be thoroughly examined with a view to saving taxpayers' money generally.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DARLING HARBOUR BICENTENNIAL PROJECT: EMPLOYMENT OF BUILDERS LABOURERS FEDERATION MEMBERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Government agreed to allocate $30m, including $8m in supplementary estimates currently before the Senate, to the Government of New South Wales for work on a bicentennial project at Sydney's Darling Harbour? Is the Government aware that the New South Wales Labor Government has entered into what is claimed by the union to be a water tight arrangement with the Builders Labourers Federation which guarantees the continued employment of BLF members at Darling Harbour, regardless of the deregistration of the union and its exclusion from the conciliation and arbitration system? Does the Government believe that it is proper to pay taxpayers' money to the New South Wales Government which can only spend it on a project which exclusively employs members of the BLF as part of some covert sweetheart deal?

—I have heard something, either on the wireless or in a newspaper, about an allegation by the Builders Labourers Federation that it has an agreement of the type described. I do not know whether it is true, but I will refer the question to Mr Willis for definitive answer, if he can get a definitive answer.

—I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program Background Briefing of 13 April in which it was alleged that there is documentary evidence of at least 150 nazis and other war criminals entering Australia shortly after World War II. Is it the case, as alleged in the program, that the then Australian Prime Minister, Robert Menzies, agreed to British and American requests that our normally stringent immigration procedures be relaxed as many such immigrants would be potentially valuable in prosecuting the cold war? In view of the allegations that 66 of 99 archived files pertaining to these immigrants and held by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation are missing and others have been released only in severely censored form, is the Minister satisfied that ASIO is co-operating properly in accordance with its charter in the investigation of these allegations?

—I do not appear to have a brief on this matter. I will seek an answer from the Attorney-General and let the honourable senator know. This might also involve some input from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in which case I will seek to liaise accordingly.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Territories aware of the long waiting time experienced by the frail aged in the Australian Capital Territory to obtain nursing home accommodation? Is he aware of the bans imposed on admissions to Morling Lodge Nursing Home, which have nothing to do with quality of care, but are merely the result of a demarcation dispute between the Hospital Employees Federation and the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia as to which union the kitchen staff of the home should belong to? Is the Minister aware of the hardship that this demarcation dispute is causing? In view of the employees' refusal to abide by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's order made last Wednesday that the bans be lifted, which has been ignored, what action will the Government take to end this dispute?
—I have some peripheral knowledge of the issues raised by Senator Reid, but I think I should draw that matter to the attention of the Minister for Territories for a precise answer.

—Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that since January 1983 excise duty on fuel has increased from 6.155c a litre to more than 15c a litre? Does the Minister not agree that an increase like that is as good to the Government as income tax at around 30c in the dollar? Does he not agree that the excise duty on fuel should be lowered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the utmost respect to Senator Bjelke-Petersen, I am not sure which country she has been in for the last three or four months because that escalation in the product excise on petroleum products has been a result of a quite deliberate Government policy designed to substitute a source of revenue for the disappeared source of revenue which has resulted from the plunge in world oil prices as far as crude oil excise is concerned. The increase to which she referred has not been a matter of some piecemeal, bit by bit, incremental action taken by the Government to tax petroleum products to consumers. The Government's decision was quite up front, quite open and explicit and it was made with the aim of recouping first a proportion and then, more recently, the whole amount of the revenue lost as a result of the collapse in world oil prices.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind Senator Bjelke-Petersen that it is only with appropriate revenue resources being available to the Government that the Government can spend money on defence, social security, health, transport, support for the farming industry and all the other things which she and members of her Party hold dear. In fact, 28c of every single dollar we raise through fuel excise and other revenue sources is devoted to social security; another 10c to health; another 7c to education; and another 20c, in fact, goes to the States-so that the other part of the family can spend money on useful services to Australian citizens. With the utmost respect, I must point out that it is pointless to talk about these sorts of issues in the abstract without recognising what is involved. When one buys a gallon of petrol, one is buying something more than petrol-one always has in this country and one still is. One is buying defence, health, social security, services to the States and all the other things on which the Government spends money.
