DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PRIVATE HOSPITALS AND NURSING HOMES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement in response to the report on private nursing homes in Australia by the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a brief statement to the Senate on 21 August last year I foreshadowed that I would provide a response to the report of the Senate Select Committee and I now do so.

SPEECH.PARA: First, let me express the Government's appreciation of the work done by parliamentary committees in this most important area. The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, know as the McLeay report and entitled `In a Home or at Home', made a major contribution to debate on care of the aged, particularly about the imbalance between home and community care and residential provision. Many of the initiatives taken by this Government, including the establishment of my Department and the Office for the Aged, the implementation of the home and community care program and the development of geriatric assessment teams, represent a response to the issues identified in that report.

The Senate Committee's report has made a major contribution to the debate about the provision of residential care, focusing on the lack of planning and need for significantly tightened growth control, together with the need to introduce funding arrangements which provide incentives to operators to be more efficient. Quality of patient care, the need for more consistent inspection and better quality control arrangements, and the crucial place of assessment and rehabilitation were also key elements of that report. These major parliamentary reports are not the only indication of concern about the current program. The Auditor-General in the efficiency audit `Commonwealth Administration of Nursing Home Programs' expressed considerable disquiet about the operation of programs now costing over $1 billion a year. The report of the Committee on Care of the Aged and the Infirm in January 1977 foreshadowed many of the concerns which were to be more fully articulated in the various reports which followed. These reports cover private, government, and religious or charitable-so-called deficit funded-homes. There is broad consensus that, firstly, there is a lack of balance in government and community provision for the aged with nursing home accommodation favoured at the expense of hostels and home and community care programs; secondly, there is an urgent requirement for effective assessment and rehabilitation procedures through which to better match services to the individual's particular requirements; thirdly, there is insufficient co-ordination between the efforts of various levels of government, including in the area of inspections and maintaining standards; fourthly, the current nursing home cost reimbursement funding arrangements discourage efficiency, and fifthly, the results of government intervention in aged care have largely been unseen, unplanned and unco-ordinated.

Against that background I commissioned an urgent report from my Department into our residential care programs, with the objective of developing a strategy for change drawing on the constructive analysis and recommendations of the Senate Committee. I made it clear that to be acceptable to this Government the strategy would need a clear statement of philosophy and goals, including, firstly, that aged and disabled people should, as far as possible, be supported in their own homes, in their own communities, and that nursing home accommodation should be provided only where community services or hostels are not appropriate to people's needs; Secondly, the point of entry to any form or level of service should be through an assessment process to help people gain access to a range of appropriate rehabilitation and caring services. That assessment should provide ongoing monitoring of the need for services or for higher or lower levels of care. Thirdly, there should be an assurance of a reasonable and appropriate standard of care which should focus not only, as in the past, on staffing and other inputs, but also on consumer outcomes reflecting the quality of life provided for the client.

The Government endorses the broad strategy and general directions for change in this review report. While we acknowledge that there will be costs associated with the proposed changes, including the building up of home and community care and development of geriatric assessment services, the Government is, of course, reserving its position on the specific funding implications in the report. We will be considering these matters in this year's Budget, in the light of views put forward in this Parliament and after consultations on the report with the States, the nursing homes and hostels industry, consumer and other welfare groups and professional and staff bodies.

Arrangements for these consultations are being made by my Department at the national level with a view to sufficient progress being made for some decisions in the Budget context. Over 5,000 copies of the report will be distributed. State offices of my Department will be available to provide information and promote discussion of the changes proposed in the review amongst organisations and individuals in the community with responsibilities for, or interests in, care for the aged. Families of elderly people in residential accommodation also have a contribution to make. My objective at this stage therefore is to provide a focus for consultations on changes in current program arrangements.
There are a number of factors which the Government believes are crucial in planning a new residential care program for elderly Australians. They include:

(a) The fact that the client population is aging rapidly with particular acceleration in numbers of those aged 80 or over. The issue for this Government is not whether expenditure on residential care will grow nor whether there should be growth in the overall provision of residential care. In both cases there will undoubtedly need to be growth for the next few decades to meet needs brought about by general demographic trends. The issue is how additional resources should be allocated.

(b) There is no information available which would support the differences in the level and nature of assistance for aged care between States, and hence in Commonwealth expenditure. Since there is no evidence that the needs of aged people vary significantly between States, there should be more consistent arrangements across States.
(c) The overall provision of nursing home beds and hostel places should be maintained at approximately its present level in relation to the population aged 70 years or more.

(d) There should, however, be much more rapid increase in hostel provision in recognition of the growing body of evidence that there is considerable overlap in the population of nursing homes and hostels and of inappropriate admissions to more intensive levels of care. The increased role of hostels, in turn, will require a greater Government priority for strengthening the social support and personal care aspects of hostels.

(e) There is insufficient flexibility and capacity for innovation within the present residential program which is incapable of responding quickly to changing needs. This is now most evident in respect of the ethnic communities, the Aboriginal groups, and those who suffer from dementia.

(f) A planning framework is needed which will enable a clear determination of government priorities as between residential programs and other services. A rolling triennial planning process, based on a determination by Government of the number of new nursing homes and hostels beds that it would be prepared to fund in any period, is probably the preferred option.

(g) The distribution of low income categories of persons aged 70 or more in nursing homes and hostels should closely reflect the distribution in the general community. About 90 per cent of residents in nursing homes are required to pay no more than the standard amount which is 87 1/2 per cent of the pension and rental assistance. The review proposes that any new arrangements should continue to provide at least this degree of financial protection for low income groups.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the statement goes on to outline the strategy proposed in the review over about 12 further pages. It was distributed to the Opposition some two hours ago, as is the rule. I ask that the rest of the statement be incorporated in Hansard to enable any debate to occur now, or, in particular, to enable more time for the business of the Senate to go ahead. I seek leave to incorporate the rest of the statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the statement read as follows-
The Strategy
Assessment and Rehabilitation

11. All the major reports on residential programs have endorsed the importance of developing assessment and rehabilitation services to ensure appropriate care for elderly people based on their physical, medical, psychological and social needs. An essential element in a geriatric assessment service is that if advice is given that institutional care is considered inappropriate the assessment team should be able to arrange access to alternative services, including home care.
12. To manage these functions it is envisaged in the Review that geriatric assessment teams would need to be:
multi-disciplinary and backed by a specialist physician with experience in geriatrics and other medical and paramedical services;
regionally based;
linked to an acute hospital with general access to inpatient beds for treatment and rehabilitation, respite and day hospital care; and
able to depend on co-operation from non medical community service providers for personal and social support services.

13. The States have been quite active in developing multi-disciplinary geriatric assessment and rehabilitation services. The Commonwealth is currently spending about $4m a year to increase the availability of assessment services. Information systems are being developed which will be helpful to those engaged in planning residential accommodation, and community services and assessment services are being evaluated.

14. The further development of assessment will require cooperation between the Commonwealth and States. Discussions will be initiated with the States to develop a strategy for expanding the availability of assessment and to explore the possibility of instituting some delegation of nursing home admission approvals to appropriate geriatric assessment teams. The pace of development will be dictated not only by the amount of resources which the States and Commonwealth are prepared to provide but also by the availability of suitably qualified staff to operate assessment teams.
Program Structure

15. We believe a relatively simple program structure should be retained for residential care within which carers and assessment authorities can respond with some degree of flexibility. Therefore we intend to retain the present tiered structure of hostel, respite and personal care categories in hostels; and the ordinary and extensive care categories in nursing homes.

16. Within that structure we believe that hostels should expand the role which they are already assuming in caring for the frail aged, while nursing homes should concentrate on the most highly dependent group.
17. We will need to develop a strategy which will:
significantly increase hostel places over the next 10 years;
build up assessment processes for hostel residents;
adjust hostel subsidies to ensure that the industry can maintain or enhance its care role; and

promote greater flexibility in recurrent funding arrangements to enable those hostels which are prepared to be innovative in caring for the more frail aged and for dementia sufferers to receive additional funding.

18. The present funding arrangements recognise the additional care required for the most highly dependent aged people in nursing homes by providing an additional extensive care benefit on their behalf. This will continue. However, an effective system of aged care must be sensitive to concerns that people placed in settings providing more intensive levels of care may very quickly become dependent on that level of care. We should therefore ensure that the community's resources for caring for the aged are concentrated on those who have most need of it.
Growth Control

19. Control over the growth in number of nursing home beds was introduced in 1973 as a result of Commonwealth Government concern about the rapid growth in beds which had followed the introduction of the nursing home benefit scheme.

20. The Senate Committee reached the conclusion ``that the significant growth in the numbers of nursing home beds since 1963 has been the result of funding policies of successive governments rather that a mere response to population change or socio-economic factors''. In addition, the Committee expressed concern at the present high level of provision of nursing home beds and drew attention to the likelihood that the current control method could actually result in a significant increase in this provision. The Committee recommended an alternative method of controlling and limiting nursing home bed growth with a view to setting a lower level of growth.

21. The Government accepts the main thrust of the recommendations made by the Senate Committee on this issue, but believes that it should go further in including hostels within the growth control arrangements.

22. The Government accepts the principle advanced by the Senate Committee that growth control be expressed as the maximum addition to the total stock of nursing homes and hostel beds over a given period. Decisions on the bed numbers which the Government is prepared to fund over the next 3 years will be indicated in the 1986/87 Budget.

23. The main features of the Review's proposed arrangements are that a national ratio be adopted of 100 hostel and nursing home places per 1000 people aged 70 or over. While this ratio approximates the current place/bed provision, it would represent a significant change in existing arrangements which impose no finite limit on places.
24. The main result of implementing the recommendations in the Review would be:
(a) over 38,000 additional nursing home and hostel places would be provided over the next 10 years, of which a maximum of 10% would be nursing home beds;
(b) the proportion of people receiving extensive care in nursing homes would be specified, with the long term aim of using all nursing home bed stock for that group only; and
(c) improved equity between States in terms of bed numbers and the proportion of elderly people receiving the extensive care.

25. The outcome of consultations with the States, and nursing home and hostel industry and community representatives will be carefully considered when the Government takes decisions on the level and type of residential care to be provided.
Innovation and Flexibility

26. The Senate Committee sought greater flexibility within current arrangements to provide special programs for the confused elderly, ethnic aged, Aboriginals and rural communities. There is an urgent need for a capacity to provide for flexible approaches to the provision of care and, in principle, I support the concept of the new Innovative Projects Program proposed in my Department's Review.

27. The Review proposes that this new program would put the funding of day centres attached to deficit funded nursing homes or hostels onto a new basis. It would provide, for example, for care of dementia sufferers together with rehabilitation programs and respite care. It is envisaged that nursing homes or hostels would receive special grants, but only in respect of planned programs with defined aims and objectives, staffing hours, patient throughput and method to be used, training components and arrangements for evaluation.

28. This Government has already recognised the requirement to give greater consideration to the special needs of ethnic communities through earmarking funds in the capital program and in the development of special guidelines for ethnic nursing home provision. The numbers of ethnic aged, many of whom are non English speaking, are increasing significantly, and a new residential care program must necessarily respond to the special needs of those groups.
Standards

29. The Senate Committee highlighted two important issues relating to standards. First, the importance of establishing uniform staffing levels progressively throughout Australia and, secondly, the urgent requirement for action in respect of nursing homes providing sub-standard care.

30. The Government shares the view of the Senate Committee that the Commonwealth should indicate the level of care for which it is prepared to pay. If we do not take the initiative in establishing uniform staffing levels, significant inequities will continue between States and we will continue to have no effective national control over the level of resources provided for residential care.

31. Difficult though it has proved in the past to achieve agreement on these matters in Commonwealth/State discussions, I am hopeful that progress can now be made within a framework for change embracing funding and assessment arrangements. The consultancy which I commissioned on the quality of care in nursing homes and which is due to be provided to me shortly will lay the basis for a better understanding of the provision of care across Australia and for discussions between Commonwealth and State officials.

32. All Senators would share a common concern with the Senate Committee about the need to take action against those few proprietors suspected of providing sub-standard care. The short term imperative is to ensure that:
inspection and enforcement activity is focused on homes which give cause for concern;
the Commonwealth and States act co-operatively in the inspection and enforcement of such homes;
a more active role is given to Commonwealth Medical Officers; and
better use is made of sanctions where necessary.

33. The Senate Committee was also concerned about achieving a framework within which the individual rights of those in residential care can be better protected. I support that view and believe that the longer term objectives which underlie the recommendations made by the Senate Committee can only be achieved on the basis of a comprehensive strategy which would include:
(a) the ready availability of information about the range of community services and programs;
(b) agreement between service users and service providers on user participation in the management and policy making processes of service providers; and
(c) adequate consultation and complaint resolution mechanisms.

34. These issues are the subject of a joint exercise between my Department and the Attorney-General's Department with the aim of developing a departmental ``user rights'' strategy. Already there have been discussions with New South Wales and Victoria and it will be important to broaden those discussions out as soon as possible.

35. The promotion of adequate standards in all nursing homes requires a process of public debate about quality of care and minimum standards. My Department has a draft document in hand which will be the subject of discussion as soon as possible with the industry and consumer groups with a view to developing a more effective system for the determination and enforcement of standards within three years.
Funding

36. The Senate Committee recommended that present recurrent funding arrangements for both participating homes and deficit financed homes be replaced by a system of program grants. In the interim the Committee suggested that measures be taken to ensure that nursing homes with very low profitability receive a level of profit sufficient to ensure their viability, until the program grants scheme commenced operation.
37. The Government took action in early 1985 to improve profitability in the nursing home industry. Most nursing homes gained from this and a number with low profitability received substantial gains.
38. Let me now remind the Senate of some of the other major concerns often voiced about current funding arrangements:

(a) the dramatic increase in nursing home recurrent expenditure from $93m in 1973 to $940m in 1985 in current prices. In terms of expenditure per average bed day in nursing homes there has been a 606% increase in nursing homes compared to an increase of only 233% in the CPI and 308% in the average weekly earnings index;

(b) the lack of equity in nursing home funding between States. Commonwealth nursing home expenditure ranges from $717 per head of population aged 65+ in 1984-85 in South Australia and Northern Territory and $621 in Victoria to $519 in Tasmania and $549 in Western Australia;

(c) the administratively complex arrangements for fees control and the lack of incentive provided to nursing home operators to be more efficient. Matters relating to fees control are the continuing subject of complex and costly legal proceedings and generate considerable bad feeling between all parties;

(d) the need for a uniform system of funding all nursing homes. Both the Senate Committee and the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee made recommendations in favour of a uniform system of funding both private and non profit-making homes and noted the higher cost structure in deficit financed homes than in participating homes. Both suggested that deficit financed homes were not providing any greater access for the financially disadvantaged than participating homes.

39. On the basis of the work done by the Senate Committee, my Department has recommended a fundamental change in funding nursing homes phased in over a period of 5 years. Under this proposal, we would move from the current cost reimbursement arrangements based on assessed costs of individual nursing homes to a benefit system based on a standard fee and benefit structure across Australia. This would be derived from average costs of ordinary and extensive care. The Commonwealth would stipulate the standard of care to be provided. It is envisaged that the same system would be broadly applicable to participating and deficit funded nursing homes. However, deficit financing arrangements will need to continue for those homes operating outside the cost structure applying to aged persons homes, such as special purpose homes for younger disabled people.

40. The changes proposed are consistent with the essential feature of program grants which is to require organisations to provide a specified level of service in return for a specified level of grant and to move away from the present cost reimbursement system and its emphasis on inputs. The proposed arrangements would provide:
a system for funding participating private and voluntary homes on broadly the same basis;
some scope for nursing home owners to increase efficiency;
better control over cost escalation;
less detailed administrative control over individual cost items; and
a means of directly tackling concerns about funding inequities between States.

41. Establishment of the Review's proposed system would, of course, involve discussions with the industry on major issues relating to the setting of the standard fee and consideration of the transitional arrangements which should be made for moving the fees charged by the industry towards that standard fee. The cost data contained in the recently published consultancy report on the Cost of Nursing Home and Hostel Care Services would be helpful to these discussions.

42. No changes are proposed in the structure of the recently introduced hostel subsidy arrangements. The 1985 Joint Review of Hostel Care Subsidies Arrangements found that the structure and levels of subsidy introduced by this Government had significantly improved the financial situation of most hostels. But the view that hostels should cater increasingly for the frail aged will require a reassessment of the personal care subsidy necessary to enable the care needs of those residents to be satisfactorily met.
Capital Funding

43. The Senate Committee recommended that Government priority for the provision of capital subsidies for nursing homes be redirected towards the provision of other forms of accommodation. The Government supports that objective, and in recent years the priority has been to redirect capital funding resources to hostel accommodation. It is evident, if hostel accommodation is to expand by some 35,000 places to 1996 as proposed in my Department's Review, that specific strategies will need to be developed including through the capital program.

44. The capital program should be used to expand services in high need areas and for special groups. It will be important in terms of Government priorities to give increasing assistance to ethnic groups and Aboriginals.
45. Greater flexibility will be introduced into current funding arrangements to ensure that priority is given to the needs of the most disadvantaged.

46. It is proposed that a capacity for funding self contained units should be retained in the program to ensure innovative projects can be funded (e.g. in rural areas), and to promote new approaches to community housing. I will be taking up with the Commonwealth Minister for Housing and Construction longer term issues which relate to the provision of housing and community programs with a view to initiating discussion with the States.
Home and Community Care Services

47. There is no doubt that the vast majority of elderly people want to be able to live as independently as possible, for as long as possible, in their own homes in familiar surroundings. This is their first preference.
48. The Government understands and supports this view. The introduction and promotion of the Home and Community Care Scheme represents a direct response to this obvious need.

49. In the first two years of the HACC program the Commonwealth and States will make available up to $88 million for the extension of existing community care services or for new services. This program is designed to grow at the rate of some 20% per year from 1987-88.
50. Although the focus of my Department's Review was on residential care services, the Review recognised the need for more resources to be directed to home and community care as a means of:
ensuring that care services would be better matched to all elderly people's needs;
addressing current shortfalls;
enhancing people's independence and preventing premature deterioration in their health and general well being; and
avoiding unnecessary entrance to more intensive and inappropriate residential care.
Next Steps
51. The major changes which the Review is foreshadowing in current arrangements for the provision of aged care would:
(a) provide for a planned expansion of nursing home and hostel accommodation, with an emphasis on the provision of greatly expanded hostel accommodation;
(b) seek changes in funding arrangements for nursing homes based on a standard of care determined by the Commonwealth;
(c) result in the more rapid development of assessment teams to assess the appropriate level of care for an aged person;
(d) require adjustment in the subsidies available to hostels to reflect the increasing role which hostels will take on in respect of the more frail aged;
(e) provide for greater innovation and flexibility in mainstream provision through a new innovative grants program;
(f) require a redirection of resources in the capital program to provide for additional hostel places and provision for special groups;
(g) encourage the development of standards of care and quality of life measures against which to better assess the care provided for our aged and disabled people; and
(h) a strengthening of home and community care services to ensure a better balance in the provision of care.

52. Taken together these changes will provide a better range of services for elderly people and their families, particularly through the development of enhanced community services and a stronger hostel sector.
53. Further work is also being done on residential services for the non-aged disabled and those ageing with severe disabilities. This will be released at a later date.
Conclusion

54. We are faced with the fact that a succession of major reports have highlighted major deficiencies in the present arrangements for care of the aged. My Department's Review is about responding to those criticisms in a way which leads to changes in the overall balance of the provision made for care of the aged whether through community services, hostel accommodation or nursing home beds. The underlying concern is to ensure that the care provided to elderly people is sensitive to their medical and social needs. The clear message is that there is a need to reflect now on how resources are used for care of the aged given the anticipated rapid ageing of the population between now and the end of the century.

55. A new framework is needed within which it will be possible to plan the increased resources which will be needed to care for an ageing population. The Review provides the basis for consultation on the changes necessary and for promoting a wider community understanding of these important issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I table the report entitled `Nursing Homes and Hostels Review' prepared by my Department. I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) for making the statement available in advance and for allowing me to be briefed on some of the contents.

SPEECH.PARA: We receive a large number of representations from elderly Australians concerned about their future and their circumstances. They are concerned about where and how they are going to live. They have a number of complaints in relation to sheltered accommodation, whether it be nursing homes or hostels. The first complaint is that there is nowhere for them to go. Irrespective of whatever plan is in place, many people come to me and say: `Our need is now. We have someone who is dependent and there is nowhere for them to go. They cannot find accommodation anywhere'. I look to the Government to meet, as a first outcome goal, the provision of accommodation where it is needed and where it is not now available. The Minister may well want to respond to that.

One of the reasons that accommodation is not now available is that some of the existing accommodation is being inappropriately used. I understand and acknowledge that. But the fact remains that a cohort of dependent people is now occupying places. These people, who may not have been dependent previously, are taking places. Large numbers of people tell me that no accommodation is available for their relatives. I am not so much interested in looking at a new structure or new processes alone. I want something to happen in terms of outcomes. I want a guarantee that places will be available, if needed, for Australians who have contributed so much over the years; if they are properly assessed, if their need is genuine and if their need is accepted. That is not presently the case.

The second reason people come to me is that there are gaps in the funding which put them under particular pressure. One example of this is where the fees charged by a nursing home exceed the pensions by an amount which pensioners cannot meet. People say to me: `What are we to do?' If they do not have a family or any means of support and there is a gap of $10 or $15 a week, they say: `What are we to do? Are we to be turned out?' The proprietors come to me and say: `What are we to do? We do not wish to turn these people out. Will you tell us how we are to cope with the situation?' My constituents present to me again and again the very real problem of the gap between the fees which are payable and the refunds which are available. Tied to this problem is the fact that over time there have been very considerable delays and failure to upgrade the amount of recurrent support for aged persons' accommodation. Therefore, the refund is not upgraded as costs go up. Indeed, there is often considerable delay before it is upgraded. As an ex-Minister I know that this is the kind of slippage which the Department of Finance might be happy about because it helps the national bookkeeping. However, Ministers for Community Services are not happy about such a situation because of the extra hardship it puts on their client group.

Let us for one moment assume that we are dealing with a group of proprietors who genuinely have had cost increases, who genuinely require some increase in the refund so that fees can be kept within the reach of their clients and who are finding it difficult to get determinations from the Department in respect of those new fees. This is not happening, the gap is increasing and financial pressure on people continues to mount. We continue to have representations from aged Australians who ask: `What are we to do this week and next week? We are being asked to fill a $15, $20 or $25 gap and we do not have families to help us'. So the second outcome that I am seeking in terms of aged persons accommodation is for something to be done about the fixed pressure on people and the homes themselves.

It seems to me that the Government has taken an approach of seeking to overcome some real and significant problems. Some problems need fixing: The problems of mismatching between the type of care required and the type of care available; mismatching, say, between States and areas and mismatching between different types of accommodation. The Government is attempting to address the question of the assessment of people before they enter this kind of accommodation. That assessment is said not to be adequate at present. If the figure of between 10 and 25 per cent of people being in nursing homes unnecessarily is true, it is correct that we should seek to have better assessment because it may be that better alternatives may meet the needs of some of these people. It is correct that the Government seeks to attack the problem of unevenness of provision between homes, between areas and between States.

One of the problems which I am not sure has been adequately addressed is that some of the State administrations are themselves creating some of the problems because of their different requirements by way of standards of provision. The States make these standards and then looks to the Commonwealth to fund their largesse. That has to be fixed. I am interested that the Commonwealth will seek to provide a uniform, standard provision. Even if this takes the Government 10 years, it is a desirable thing to be seeking. If the Government wants to address the question of poor quality of provision in some homes, we will welcome that because we want every aged Australian, in whatever kind of care, hostel or nursing home, to receive the best quality care. If that relates to inspection services in part we want to see that looked after. If the Government has identified, as it tells me it has, that deficit-funded nursing homes have, to a large part, failed in the objective of helping lower income people find accommodation, it is correct that we try to do something about that. If the Government wants to address quality, I am not certain that it is correct that it do so through a government agency or through government bureaucratic measures.

In the public hospital system a body known as the Australian Council on Hospital Standards has emerged. That body uses self-assessment within the public hospital system. I understand that the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in Sydney, for example, failed to get accreditation from the Australian Council on Hospital Standards. So even the most famous hospitals may not get their accreditation. That body exists to define standards and to seek to have them accepted from within, in this case, the public hospitals. I believe the same thing can be done with the nursing home industry and with hostels to develop some mechanism of a seal of good housekeeping, some standard of provision, and have them accepted and endorsed, and seek to achieve the standard which is laid down.

There are many uncertainties, but above all the uncertainty that stands out is the uncertainty about funding. The Minister has told us that until the Budget comes down we do not know the level of funding which will be provided to meet some of the goals he has laid down, or some of the programs he is seeking to implement. Of course he cannot tell us until Budget time-no Minister can. But the level of resources, the amount of money made available, will in the end determine whether better outcomes can be achieved. The amount of money will determine whether aged Australians will be better off or whether they will be worse off. Unless adequate resources are provided they will, in fact, be worse off. If the Government wants to save money in this Budget-of course it must-it must do so by cutting back some of the optional extras; cutting back on some of the circuses. What I fear is, and our concern is, that some of the savings will be sought and made at the expense of the needy and the aged, and this is par excellence, one of the areas where need is very great, where the need is very real and where, I hope, the Government will respond to the Minister's program with adequate resources.

In relation to the Commonwealth-State issues which have been raised in the Minister's statement, including the part that he has not read out, there will be some very delicate negotiations to be made. After all, the States are sovereign in certain areas and some of the States have laid down very lavish standards of provision. My concern is that having laid them down they make no effort to fund them and look to the Commonwealth to meet the bills for what they have laid down as necessary. The only effect this has is to leave a very large cash gap for the clients themselves to meet. The Minister says-and I understand his reasoning-that he wants to move towards a standard provision of benefit. That is fine as long as every aged Australian knows that there will be winners and that there will be losers, and there could well be some homes for which this will involve a lesser degree of funding and some people living in the homes for whom it may involve extra expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope not, Senator.

—It could mean that, Minister. The only other matter that concerns me is the question of whether we are using our existing stock adequately and whether we are going to make adequate provisions for what are the undoubted needs of aged Australians. For example, there is still a need for large numbers of new nursing home places in certain areas, if not in others. There is a need that we should be putting our existing stock of public hospital beds to better use, particularly in areas where those public hospital beds are serving nursing home or hostel functions. If that involves some renegotiation of Commonwealth-State funding, I hope it can be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Lastly, there is the question of making the distinction between capital and recurrent provision. The Minister talks about the kinds of things he wants to do-more money for home and community care, more money for hostels, new money but not quite so much for new nursing homes, new innovative programs-which will all be expensive. It will be interesting to see what the Minister can provide by way of capital and by way of recurrent funding, because only then will we know that aged Australians are better or worse off. Until we see how the Government will support what is contained in the statement we do not know whether aged Australians will get anything out of it; I hope they will. I do not know whether people in desperate situations who phone my electorate office seeking advice-as they phone everybody's electorate office-will have some of their problems met and needs satisfied or will continue to phone me when the amount of funding is announced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the report that the Government has put down today in response to the report from the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. Although I realise that it is traditional to label those reports with the surname of the chairman of the particular committee, I would like at least to put on record the fact that that Committee would not have been established in October 1981 had it not been for a motion that I, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, put before the Senate. As I recollect it met with some considerable opposition from the then Government, but with the assistance of the Party which was then in opposition and is now in government, we got it off the ground. It may well turn out to be the longest serving Senate Select Committee on record, since we are still meeting and, indeed, had our sixty-fourth or sixty-fifth meeting only last week.
—It is composed mainly of women.

—Yes, it was the first committee that was established in the Senate entirely composed of women. On it served a number of senators whose previous occupation was in the nursing profession and who brought a lot of commitment, expertise and knowledge to that Committee. I take up Senator Robertson's interjection because I suspect that behind it was a suggestion that the reason the inquiry was lengthy was that the Committee had women on it. I point out that we have been extremely enthusiastic in probing the problems that have arisen in both the private hospital sector and the nursing home sector. The recommendations we brought forward in the first of our reports and the recommendations that will come forward on private hospitals will bear testimony to the fact that we have left no stone unturned, so to speak, to get at the anomalies, problems and difficulties that arise in providing adequate, appropriate and cost effective care for the sick and the elderly in Australia's institutions and in looking at ways in which better care, perhaps less institutionalised care, could be provided to those people.

SPEECH.PARA: Just a moment ago Senator Peter Baume mentioned the very desperate need to provide appropriate and adequate care. He mentioned that there are some people who are inappropriately in nursing homes and who, by their very presence, are denying the necessary care in an institution to people whose needs are sufficiently great for them to require 24-hour a day nursing care in a nursing home of whatever sort. Whether it is private enterprise, religious and charitable or deficit financed is not relevant. The fact of the matter is that what we need to strive for as a government, as a parliament and as a community is appropriate, adequate and cost effective care for those who need it. This report, following the Senate Select Committee's report, will go some way towards that.

I have most recently had a personal involvement in just the sorts of problems which the Senate Committee's report raised which this report looked at and which Senator Peter Baume previously mentioned. It was drawn to my attention that somebody very close to me was having difficulty in getting appropriate care. The lady concerned is 77. Her husband is 90. They live in their own home and were perfectly capable of doing so until last year when the lady became ill. She is mentally very alert but is becoming increasingly frail physically. Living in a country area there are, of course, very limited opportunities for being placed in appropriate nursing home care, so she was placed in the local hospital where, after the appropriate 35 days, her doctor had to sign a section 3B form, which was no real problem, but at the end of the next 35 days she was put back into her home under the care of her 90-year-old husband. That was beyond his capacities, partly because at 90 he himself is becoming physically frail and because the nature of her illness meant that for periods she was blacking out and falling to the floor and needed to be lifted up, moved and so on. He was not able to do that.

Their only option, because they could not get her into a nursing home in that country town, was to hire private nursing care at over $800 per week, with a very limited return from medical benefits. That lasted for a fairly short period of time, quite obviously, since these people are pensioners. They had to satisfy themselves with day care provided as an adjunct, so to speak, by the hospital to this lady. They are living from day to day and hope that her case does not get any worse because then the only option is going to be for her to be moved to Adelaide, away from her family and friends and completely isolated, which means selling their home and doing all the sorts of things that only make it additionally stressful for a family.

It is appropriate that we start to move away from early twentieth century attitudes to the institutionalisation of the frail aged and of the sick generally. The Government's report looks at a number of issues from the provision of respite care, which it acknowledges on page 50 of its report has barely been investigated to an appropriate level, to the question of assessments and standards of care. It looks not only at the institutionalisation in nursing homes of the elderly but also at the institutionalisation of younger people, particularly those with disabilities. This was something that the Select Committee discovered when it was making inquiries into the nursing homes sector.

There are numbers of young people in particular with disabilities, often caused through accidents, who are placed in nursing homes along with elderly patients. This is not always appropriate. In fact, very rarely is it an appropriate thing to do, and those who are in a form of institutionalised care on their own, such as in Ashton House in Sydney, find that they run into council regulations or other forms of regulations which are inappropriate to their circumstances although they may be appropriate to nursing homes which cater almost entirely for the very elderly. For example, a requirement that one room be set aside for a morgue is no doubt appropriate in a home where the majority of patients are very elderly indeed, but is highly inappropriate in a place such as Ashton House where the patients are all pretty much under 30 and, apart from the fact that they are in wheel chairs, are otherwise assured of not leaping off this mortal coil within a short space of time. They felt repressed by the fact that this regulation applied, as do similar regulations that are appropriate for large nursing homes which cater for the elderly but which do not necessarily cater for them.

The Government, like the Select Committee, has picked up a number of anomalies that exist in funding mechanisms for nursing homes and for nursing home patients, in particular the question of the extended care benefit, which the Committee discovered was quite inappropriately allocated in a number of instances. For example, it meant that nursing homes which had a large number of chair-fast or bed-fast patients were in receipt of the extensive care benefit where those patients do not necessarily require the extensive nursing care and hence the high number of qualified staff that people suffering from dementia require. The frail aged who are ambulant but who are likely to wander off need far more attention from nursing staff, as do patients who are not bed-fast or chair-fast but who may suffer from, for example, incontinence. Those sorts of people are far more likely to require extensive nursing care and hence ought to qualify for the extensive care benefit than those people who are simply chair-fast or bed-fast.

Even worse, we occasionally ran into situations where it seemed suspiciously likely that patients were being kept bed-fast or chair-fast, if the drug schedule that was pinned up on notice boards was any indication. It would appear that at least in some circumstances patients were being kept drugged to keep the running costs of the nursing home down but also to gain the extensive care benefit. I point out that that was in a minimum number of cases obviously; nevertheless, it was there and I suspect it was in response to the fact that the extensive care benefit was available in the main only to those patients who were bed-fast or chair-fast because that was the definition of somebody who required extensive care.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be a problem of prescribing practices to the elderly, which is another big issue.

—Yes. The number of patients who were swallowing serepax, mogadon, valium or various other forms of those sorts of drugs in some nursing homes was horrific. While not wishing to be overly critical of the medical profession, one sometimes wonders why, in a particular nursing home, one runs into a situation where the bulk of the patients are being kept sedated for long periods at a time, both day and night.

SPEECH.PARA: The recommendations that are included in the report before us today then look to making more appropriate the availability of the extensive care benefit. They look at evaluating special purpose nursing homes for young people with disabilities and have as their objective the development of less restrictive alternatives to the current models of residential care. Going back to the question of Ashton House, when that group of disabled people attempted to set up a home for themselves they ran into the sort of paternalism that exists in some government areas. In this case they were offered accommodation in a fairly outlying area of Sydney which was not particularly appropriate when they wanted it to be on a main road with access to transport and so on. So we need to look too at our attitude to the requirements of young, disabled people for some form of residential care and what they believe they need.

The report then goes on to talk about respite care and appropriate residential and alternative forms of care. I suggest that, if the Government is committed to appropriate, alternative, flexible and innovative forms of care particularly for the disabled, and for the elderly as well, it do something a little bit more enthusiastic about its attendant care program which is not exactly moving on apace and is causing some concern not only from those who are part of the pilot project, but also from those who would ultimately like to become part of the whole program. As one member of the pilot group pointed out to me and to anybody else who would stand still long enough to listen, taking part in the program-that is the attendant pilot program-has allowed him to lead a normal, independent existence in the community. Surely that is something that we are aiming for, not only for people with disabilities but also for the elderly for as long as they are capable and able to live that way.

I suggest that, if the Government does put into effect any of the recommendations with regard to respite care, to other sorts of planning for appropriate, adequate and flexible care to the question of geriatric assessment programs and so on, it do not simply as a cost cutting measure, but as an overall integrated program with the aim of improving facilities not only for those who need to be looked after, but also for those who are providing the care, because their needs have to be met as much as those of the person in receipt of the care. I ask the Government not to proceed with the nursing home changes that are envisaged in the recommendations contained in this report until a totally integrated replacement system is capable of being put down in its stead, incorporating all the good recommendations, such as respite care, assistance for people who are caring for somebody with a disability or an aged relative in the home, the proper sort of geriatric assessment programs and to generally put into effect, rather than simply into rhetoric, its apparent commitment to flexibility and innovation in this area.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 14 April, from Senator Haines:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
