(d) creating the possibility that Australians will be paying over 20 per cent for home loans,
and the urgent need for the Government to
(e) reimpose the interest rate ceiling on new home loans;
(f) guarantee that the interest rate ceiling on existing loans will not be removed; and

(g) introduce as an alternative the plan proposed by Senator Haines which would provide subsidised and affordable interest rates for home loans so that all Australians could afford to own their own homes.'.
Yours sincerely,
(Janine Haines)
Senator for the State of South Australia
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The reprehensible conduct of the Government in:
(a) selling out all future Australian home buyers by deregulating the interest rate ceiling for new homes buyers;
(b) selling out to banks and discriminating against building societies;
(c) making home ownership the exclusive preserve of the wealthy in Australia; and
(d) creating the possibility that Australians will be paying over 20% for home loans,
and the urgent need for the Government to-
(e) reimpose the interest rate ceiling on new home loans;
(f) guarantee that the interest rate ceiling on existing loans will not be removed; and

(g) introduce as an alternative the plan proposed by Senator Haines which would provide subsidised and affordable interest rates for home loans so that all Australians could afford to own their own homes.

I make no apologies for the fact that this urgency motion before the Senate today is long and detailed. I make no apology for it because the problem will affect a very large number of Australian families, a very large number of people who are currently trying to own their own home and an equally large number of people who would like to be in a position to own their own home.

I begin by referring to a cartoon that appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser some days after the announcement was made that the Government was going to bow to the blackmailing pressure from the private banks in this country and lift the ceiling on interest rates for home loans for those borrowers who did not currently have a home. I mention this cartoon, not because I think the issue is a laughing matter-I do not think it is a laughing matter-but because I think that this cartoon encapsulates the attitude that the Australian Labor Government has to the promises it makes to the people of Australia. The cartoon is in several segments. It is one of Michael Atchison's On the Rocks series with which all South Australians who are in the chamber-of whom you are one, Mr Acting Deputy President-will be familiar.

It has a very recognisable Mr Hawke standing on a rock-type platform. For the purposes of this cartoon his name is spelt Hork. He is standing there waving his arms to a little man who is hopping up and down on the ground in front of him. The first balloon coming from the Prime Minister says the following: `Simon sez ``Vote for Horky!'' Simon sez ``I promise your hart's desire'' '. The little man down on the floor hops up and down and says: `Hooray!' The next balloon says: `Simon sez ``I promise peace throughout the land!'' Simon sez ``I promise prosperity for all!'' ' The little man on the ground hops up and down again and says: `Hooray!'. The next one says: `I promise not to raise the ceiling on interest rates'. The little man hops up and down again and says: `Hooray!' The fourth one has Mr Hawke saying: `Ha ha. Gotcha! I didn't say Simon sez'. I think that pretty much encapsulates what has happened here. In the past Mr Hawke has quite definitely made the statement that housing interest rates would not be raised. In the 1983 election campaign he committed his Government:

To provide a stable and adequate flow of funds for housing at affordable interest rates. The Labor Government will: maintain interest rate controls on bank mortgage interest rates and extend those controls to building societies-
How he intended to do that without bringing building societies under the control of the Federal Government, I am not quite sure. He continued in relation to the Labor Government:

. . . require the savings banks and building societies to lend a set proportion of their funds for housing and establish an Australian Housing Fund in the Reserve Bank made up of deposits by non-bank financial institutions and channelled through the banks and building societies.

We have yet to see that being implemented. A week and a half ago the Government, as I said a moment ago, bowed to the blackmailing pressure of the private banking sector and raised home loan interest rates for people who did not currently hold a loan from 13 1/2 per cent to 15 1/2 per cent.

The Government did that at a time when banking profits were the highest they had ever been; when, for yet another year, the private banking sector is making record profits, on occasions in the vicinity of a 28 or 29 per cent increase on what it had made in the previous year.

Last year the banks made profits in excess of $1 billion. Yet, mysteriously, they were unable to find the funds to lend for housing. I point out that they were unable to find those funds only when the interest rate was 13 1/2 per cent, which is what it was last Wednesday week. By Thursday, when the rate had gone up to 15 1/2 per cent, suddenly the banks had sufficient money to lend. In the days that followed the Government's announcement that the ceiling on home loan interest rates was to be lifted, the banks were advertising feverishly for applications. Twenty-four hours after the Government's announcement that the banks could increase their interest rates from 13 1/2 per cent to 15 1/2 per cent, those same banks that had been crying poor on the previous day and had been threatening not to lend any more money for housing were advertising that money was available for housing and people who had recently been refused loans could apply again.

TALK.START.PARA: —It worked.
—It worked?
—Yes.

—Suddenly, money for loans came pouring out of the banks, a day after they had been talking about the funds drying up altogether. The banks had had no time to attract additional deposits at the higher interest rates. From somewhere they suddenly found money for housing at 15 1/2 per cent that was not available at 13 1/2 per cent. That was a clear indication that the banks were deliberately not lending money for housing in order to persuade the Government to deregulate. I consider and my Party considers that action reprehensible at a time when, as I said, the banks were making record profits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has sold out all future Australian home buyers by deregulating in that fashion. It is making it excessively difficult for people, particularly those on or around average weekly earnings, to be able to meet the necessary repayment requirements, much less to acquire the deposit that they will need in order to qualify for a loan in the first place. Currently, average earnings for the Australian male are around $21,500. Given that there is a large number of people on very high incomes, something like 60 per cent of wage earners actually earn below the so-called average income. But $21,500 is classified as the average income for the Australian male. In many cases that means the Australian family which does not have two incomes coming into the home. Of this $21,500, over $5,000 goes in tax. Assuming that the other spouse is not earning a second income, that family would get an additional $1,030 from the dependent spouse rebate. Let us take, for the sake of argument, a family with two dependent children, because that family would get an additional $664.20 a year in family allowance. That family of a sole income earner, a dependent spouse and two dependent children would be left with a disposable income a little under $18,000 a year. That family, to be able to afford the average $50,000 loan at 15 1/2 per cent to put itself into a very average home, will have to repay in excess of $7,500 a year in interest alone, leaving around $10,000 per annum, or about $200 a week, for living expenses, to feed, clothe, transport and entertain four people-two adults and two children. I am not quite sure how the Government thinks that family would be able to do that or how many people it thinks will now be able to afford to take out home loans.

Of course, the fewer people who are able to buy or build a home, the fewer commodities are sold that go into homes. I am rather surprised that those organisations that represent small and middle business in this country have not issued Press releases to show their outrage with regard to what has been happening. These businesses learnt, or should have learnt in the early 1980s, when similar high interest rates were occurring under the Fraser Government, that for every house which is not built an assortment of white- goods, soft furnishings and so on is not purchased. For every one of those items that is not purchased, business is making fewer profits, productivity goes down and employment is affected. That is not a figment of my imagination or anybody else's. Anybody who can count ought to work that out.

I point out to members of the current Government that in the early 1980s they were as angry as I was at the effect across Australia of the Fraser Government's high interest rate policy. We find now that the Government deliberately is putting itself into the same situation. It is selling out to the banks. In doing so it is discriminating not only against potential Australian home owners but also against the building societies. This is a fact which has not escaped the attention of those organisations that have been moved to take out multi-page advertisements pointing out to their borrowers and, indeed, to the people who lend to them that this decision will have a considerable impact on the building societies themselves and on the people who borrow from them. I quote from one of those advertisements placed in the Weekend Australian of last weekend by the United Permanent Building Society:
Last week, as you're no doubt aware, the banks lifted their interest rates on new home loans to 15.5%.
This 2% increase was the direct result of a very swift turnaround in Federal Government policy, as well as a handout of federal funds of some $120 million in the form of a subsidy to the banks.

I interpolate at this point that I find it extraordinary that on the one hand the Government is complaining that its razor gang cuts are not particularly effective and that it will be strapped for money this year when, on the other hand, it can find $120m to hand out to an organisation which is making record profits and, a week or so later, it can find another $125m to hand out to the oil companies, which are not exactly going broke, in order to compensate them for fluctuations in the price of oil. The sum of $245m was handed out to organisations that are well able to take care of themselves, and a commensurate amount of $245m will not be available to Australian families, particularly those who are trying to buy their own homes. I suggest that that money would have been far better spent if it had been directed at providing some sort of tax concession or other assistance to help Australian families get into homes such as the tax concessions which are part and parcel of the assistance which is provided by the United Kingdom and Canadian governments in their commitments to helping families and individuals own the roof over their heads.

The advertisement that was placed in the Weekend Australian by that building society points out that a subsidy will not be forthcoming for the 30 per cent of home owners who borrow money for housing from building societies. This will place an enormous burden on those building societies in their efforts to keep up. They will be forced to raise their interest rates. I point out that they are not making the sorts of record profits that the banking industry is making. It can only mean that a decreasing number of people will be able to afford their own home. Anybody who believes that interest rates will stay at 15 1/2 per cent and not rise any further, or who believes that the Government will not extend the deregulation to people who already own their own homes, is not right in the head.

New Zealand rates for home loans have gone over the 20 per cent mark. It is highly likely that within the next 12 months something similar will happen here, unless the Government takes some sort of steps to prevent that, either by reimposing the ceiling or by doing what the Prime Minister said he would do during the 1983 election campaign-that is, requiring the savings banks and building societies to lend a set proportion of their funds for housing. That is surely not an inappropriate thing to do when one considers the impact that home ownership has on the general economy of this country. There is an urgent need for the Government to reimpose the interest rate ceiling on home loans. There is an equally urgent need for it to guarantee that the interest rate ceiling on home loans will not be removed, although one could forgive the Australian community for being somewhat sceptical about any guarantees that are given by governments when the sorts of election promises that the Hawke Labor Party has made in the past are so easily broken.

If the Government does not want to take either of those two steps, there are a number of other measures that it could look upon more favourably than it has done in the past. One of those is to reconsider a proposal that I, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, put before the Senate in 1981-that is, to encourage people to put their savings into accounts which pay lower than the highest interest rates that are operating in the market, and to encourage them to do that by offering a tax concession as an incentive. What we put forward then as a reasonable scheme was that people should be encouraged to put their money into savings bank and building society accounts-that is, into institutions which lend money for housing loans-which pay 10 per cent or less on the money. People would be encouraged to do so by the Government giving a tax concession so that, for example, the first $1,000 that people earned on money that they had invested in bank or building society accounts paying 10 per cent or less would not be taxed. That would have given those investors an actual rate of return of about 14 per cent to 14 1/2 per cent, which is not bad, even under current interest rate circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much revenue will be forgone?
—We costed it in the vicinity of $800m. That, in itself, is not excessive.
—Terrific. That is all we need.

—Just let me finish, Minister. When one considers that attendant on that was the removal of things such as the first home owners scheme, which is a discriminatory scheme in every sense of the word, being means tested as it is, and applying only to a limited and not always appropriate group of people in the community, costs would have been cut considerably. If the Government has $125m to throw in the direction of the oil companies and another $120m to throw in the general direction of the banks, it can certainly come up with that and more to assist ordinary Australian taxpayers and Australian families, particularly those with dependent children, to buy their own homes. The pressure that is currently being applied to the private rental market is forcing a great many of those families out of that area, which is their main alternative, into the public housing sector, thereby pushing further down the list those people who are in desperate need, financial and other, for public housing assistance from the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the whole question of home ownership, the money that people pay for the loans that they need for home ownership, is a matter of considerable urgency. This Government has broken every promise it has ever made on this issue and ought to be called to account for that. Instead, the Opposition in this place is in collaboration with the Government in its attempts to deregulate this market and is making an uncharitable and churlish attempt, through its amendments, to reduce this urgency motion to something which is meaningless.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the Australian Democrats have to make their weekly bid to get themselves some media coverage. But it is not really very helpful when Senator Haines, who professes to have concern for home owners, people paying off mortgages and people who would like to pay off mortgages, subjects the Senate to the most garbled, distorted account of how housing finance can be, and is being, made available. It is simply not helpful to those who wish to buy houses or to those who are struggling to pay off mortgages to have this sort of misinterpretation and distortion thrown into the public arena. There was a series of inaccuracies and misinterpretations in Senator Haines's presentation today. I will not waste the time of the Senate by going through them all. I say simply that if Senator Haines or her colleagues in the Democrats want to shout about broken promises, they should remember a couple of things. They can make as many promises as they like because they will never be in a position to have to deliver on them. Of course, they indulge themselves in that luxury of powerlessness, which is a luxury they seem to enjoy, since they take every possible--
—Are you saying we will never deliver on the tax package?

—We have here a group of people who will never run the economy of this country, who will never have to juggle the various legitimate demands on the public purse and who will never really have to deal with the problem of poverty in our community, the problem of unemployment or the problem of homelessness. The only problem they ever deal with is whether they will get into the papers this week. Of course, they will stop at nothing. They will say absolutely anything to attract attention. What they are saying is wrong, mischievous and of absolutely no assistance in regard to any of the matters. I think that the people of Australia are becoming sick and tired of this constant hopping on any passing bandwaggon and screaming and shouting that all sorts of things will happen, with a concomitant failure to deliver anything of practical benefit to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in passing, too, that the kind of solution that Senator Haines so glibly throws forward in her uninformed and garbled presentation was that we could give tax concessions. Of course, the Democrats are great ones for tax concessions. They say we should give tax concessions to people who are prepared to save in banks which give low loans. Of course, it is typical of the Democrats to provide the tax concession solution on the one hand, while on the other hand asking for increased public expenditure. Every tax concession that this Government or any government makes available reduces the capacity of the Government to spend money. The most crying need in this country in the housing area is in the public housing area. The most crying need is not for those who can get mortgages or can nearly get mortgages, but for those who will never be able to afford a home. We have greatly increased assistance to the public housing sector. But there is no doubt that the real poor in our community who will never own a home are in great need of government support and government expenditure. The Democrats are very happy to hop up and say: `Pay more pensions. Give more public housing assistance. Give more rental assistance to the unemployed'. These are all things we wish to do and which we are doing, slowly and modestly. At the same time they suggest that we should throw tax concessions all over the place, thus reducing our capacity to spend money on the poorest people in the community. It is a total contradiction.

It has also been suggested that we should give tax concessions instead of facilitating more home loan funds coming from the banks. I simply point out that again this is either a total contradiction or a total misunderstanding of home loan financing because there is no point in having a tax concession available to people if they cannot get their loan funds. That brings me to a brief description of the situation in which we found ourselves. The banks of this country, which have traditionally provided about half the amount of home loan funds-and we want them to continue to do that-were not able to provide those funds. In that situation of rapidly drying up loans from the banks, talk about tax concessions is economic nonsense.

Senator Macklin has been screaming out throughout my speech that he wants some facts and now I will answer his request. I hope that he will pay attention to these facts because facts are aspects of the Australian Democrats' contributions to debate which are always singularly lacking. The first fact is that our Government has delivered dramatically well on its promise with respect to housing. There has been a growth in private and public housing under the Hawke Government, both of which have been unprecedented. Those facts cannot be challenged. There are many more Australians in homes today, be they public or private, than there were when we took office. Just before we took office in the 1982-83 year there had been a collapse of the housing industry. There had been only 105,000 commencements and only $406m had been devoted to public housing. Home ownership assistance had also collapsed. These were dramatic collapses which reverberated throughout the whole economy. There is no point in talking about the housing industry as if it were somehow insulated from everything else that was happening in the economy. It is an integral and crucial part of it and a collapse in that part of the economy signalled a collapse in the economy generally. As soon as we came into office we were able to deliver immediately on our undertakings to improve home ownership.

First of all, we increased the first home owners scheme, a scheme which has just been criticised by Senator Haines, but which has been an enormous success in boosting the housing industry and providing better access to home ownership. Since 1 October 1983 we have paid or committed $870m under the first home owners scheme and assisted 186,000 applicants-a fine record for any government. At the same time we boosted public housing by 50 per cent to $570m in direct grants for 1983-84 and to $624m for 1984-85. We had also allowed the States to use Loan Council funds for public housing and, of course, the States received these funds at a 4 1/2 per cent concessional rate, which makes a considerable impact on the total funds available for housing. For example, in the current year total Federal funding is $1,108m-that is, $654m in grants plus $450m in concessional Loan Council loan dollars. With the State contributions to housing, $1.8 billion is available this financial year and that is the highest ever available for housing, even in real terms. Let us just consider these facts when claims about reneging on promises for housing are being flung about in such a careless fashion.

Of course, the effect on the industry has been significant. In 1984-85 housing commencements reached 152,000, the highest for 11 years. There was job growth in the housing industry of 70,000 jobs, which has made a considerable contribution to our creation of half a million jobs-another Hawke Government promise which we have more than delivered and of which we are very proud. The upsurge in the housing and construction industry which had been going so well began to falter some months ago. In October last year the Indicative Planning Council forecast a downturn. In fact, it forecast that home commencements would be down to an unacceptable level. When that information was first made available, we did not jump to any instant solution; we examined and monitored the situation carefully. But by the approach of the end of the first quarter of this year it was clear that there was indeed a drying up of funds for housing and that we were on the verge of disaster in the housing industry. That would be a disaster for home owners, for those trying to get home loan funds and for those employed in the industry.

Banks were forecasting that their lending would be only $3 billion for 1986-87 rather than the $6.7 billion that they had lent in 1984-85. This is very important, and the importance of the banks' contributions in making home loan funds available appears to have been missed entirely by the Australian Democrats and others who have been critical of this Government's decisions. As I said earlier, the banks have traditionally provided about half the home loan funds in this country and if 50 per cent of the funds were to dry up we would have a crisis. It is not constructive to criticise endlessly the fact that the banks had lost savings deposits and were no longer able to offer loans at 13 1/2 per cent. That is a regrettable fact. There are criticisms of the banking structure in this country to which we would be responsive and, indeed, to which we have been responsive. Our deregulation of the banks has been one of our major responses. The fact was that the source of about half of home loan funds in this country was rapidly drying up.

In the face of this our Government could not just sit back and weep and wail and criticise the banks. In the face of this some constructive action had to be taken. We could not simply sit back and watch those funds dry up, see 50,000 jobs in the housing industry disappear and have as our only response a complaint or criticism of the banking structures in this country. Honourable senators opposite who have been critical of our decision should remember too that the banks, because of the ceiling, had been unable to attract savings deposits adequate to service the loans that they had in operation, let alone start new ones. They were in fact borrowing in the vicinity of 15 1/2 to 16 per cent in order to service the 13 1/2 per cent loans that they already had. Senator Haines might say that that is all right, but in fact it is not all right because it affects the profitability of the banks in a fairly disastrous way. The banks had lost about $2.2 billion from their savings bank deposits this year.

In comparison, the building societies had not been losing deposits because they were able to offer a higher interest rate to depositors. They had not only maintained their deposits; they had actually had an 11 per cent increase in the 12 months to January. Those facts need to be appreciated. The banks were rapidly losing the funds from which they could service their existing loans at 13 1/2 per cent and make new loans available, whereas the building societies, being able to offer higher interest rates to their depositors, had actually increased their deposits, and therefore their capacity to extend, by 11 per cent. The cries of `Discrimination!' which greeted our decision to assist the banks to maintain at 13 1/2 per cent the loans to which they were already committed and make new funds available up to $6 billion limit really need to be seen in the light of what was happening to the building societies. The building societies were continuing to lend and to attract deposits. They were in a totally different position.

I wish to comment also on the claims that have been made quite widely, even within the ranks of the Australian Labor Party, that the increased rates that the banks will now offer will preclude average families or home buyers from taking out loans. The fact of the matter is that in recent years it has been easier for low income families to get loans from building societies than from banks, because banks have much tougher lending criteria than do the building societies. So it is simply not the case that the better off people in the community go to building societies for their loans and the poorer people go to banks. In fact, the situation is the reverse. The more affluent people in the community, who have the sort of security that banks like, have been able to go to the banks, and the poorer families have gone to building societies and have taken loans at 15 1/2 per cent or 16 per cent. So there is no logic in the suggestions that now that banks will be able to compete with building societies in the rates they offer, they will be excluding a set of clients whom they had previously. That is quite illogical and those who claim that show an ignorance of the true composition of the customers of banks.

In the few minutes I have available I will devote myself to what will happen in terms of the decision which has been made. The first and most controversial element of the package is that the Government will make $120m available to the major banks, which is not a subsidy to the banks in their profit making capacities, but will enable them to do two things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subsidising the wealthy.

—I hope that Senator Macklin will pay attention to this, because he is obviously very confused. The subsidy will enable banks to continue to service the 13 1/2 per cent loans which they have already made and have been servicing at a loss of approximately $420m at this stage. The banks will still service the loans at a loss, but at a smaller loss because of the Government's $120m subvention. That $120m should not be seen, as it has been by the Democrats and others who have been carrying on about it in a sloppy way, as a gift to the banks but rather as a subsidy to those people who have a 13 1/2 per cent loan, on which the ceiling has not been and will not be lifted. The main purpose of the subsidy is to assist those existing mortgagees who have bank loans at 13 1/2 per cent. The other thing the banks will now do is lift their lending to up to $6 billion in the next financial year. That is very important. Anyone who comes into this place and professes a concern for those who are trying to get home loan funds and then sneers at an extra $6 billion which will come into the pool of home loan funds available, simply lacks any credibility.
—One thousand dollars a week.

—Senator Macklin is very excited and keeps saying `One thousand dollars a week'. The other element of the package, on which the Democrats and other critics have chosen not to focus, is that one of the conditions on which the subsidy has been made available to the banks is that they will introduce more low start loans-a very constructive and welcome measure. That will mean that the banks which get the subsidy will negotiate with their customers so that they will pay a lower rate of return on their loans during the early years when they are really battling and then, as their income goes up, their responsibilities decline and their children get older, they will pay at a higher rate. The consequence of this package may well be that people getting new loans will have either the same rate of repayment as the people who have loans at 13 1/2 per cent, or even a lower rate if they are able to negotiate a good low start package. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) will be seeking a commitment in writing from the banks that they will honour this undertaking to give more low start loans. That is very important, because anyone who has a home loan knows that it is the amount being paid out every week in the early years, rather than the total debt, which really affects the standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: The other element of the package to which very little attention has been paid is the effect on public housing. I would like the Democrats to pay attention to this, as they profess to have a concern for the poor, yet they have ignored the increase in public housing loans available as part of this package. The time is running out, so I simply remind the Senate that we will be making available a further $700m in grants for public housing and we will increase to 60 per cent the amount that the States can use from their total Loan Council funds for public housing. Those measures will boost public housing commencements to 21,000, compared with 17,500 last year and only 9,000 in 1982-83. It is the total package on which the Senate and anyone else interested in housing should concentrate. The total package is good for home owners, prospective home owners and tenants of public housing, and ought to be supported. Consequently, the urgency motion of the Democrats is rejected. For similar reasons, which I am sure will be addressed by my colleague Senator Ray, the amendment by the Liberals is also rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Housing is one of the subjects that affect absolutely everybody in Australia. There are many views on how the housing problem should be tackled, allowing for the fact that all the different groups are entitled to have their own views. There are many inconsistent attitudes and the needs of different groups have to be catered for separately. Over the past few years there have been numerous inquiries and much advice has been given, both by committees and individuals, who have produced information and recommendations which in so many cases are either unattractive or impossible for the government of the day to implement.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I came to the Senate I spent all my working life in industries connected with housing and I still follow it fairly closely now. Of all the things that have happened to housing in the past 40 years, undoubtedly the most successful and useful has been the mortgage guarantee scheme. If we are looking for one item that would be of the greatest use to the housing industry and to the people who are endeavouring to get housing, it is clearly a secondary finance system without any ifs and buts to go with it. The Government's actions have been very piecemeal up to this point. It is a true pressure reaction, and even the Government would not argue about that. It is the politics of unemployment on the one side versus monetary mismanagement on the other.

I totally agree that this is a matter of urgency and in that regard I support the Australian Democrats for having brought it forward. As they would recall, we on this side of the chamber brought up this matter only about two weeks ago. We made our point very clearly then as to what our views were, and they have not changed in a fortnight-we are not like that. I believe that the mover of the motion has missed and misinterpreted the position. I wish to deal with some of the points of the motion, which is in seven parts. The motion reads:
The reprehensible conduct of the Government in-
(a) selling out all future Australian home buyers by deregulating the interest rate ceiling for new home buyers . . .

That happened last week. Clearly that is an overstatement. There are cash buyers, Government scheme buyers and other people who will always find a way to purchase houses. It is not a matter of selling out all future Australian home buyers. That is wrong, because the only reason interest rates are high and false is the Government's policy of supporting the dollar. I believe that by reversing that position we could get interest rates back to a natural and normal state. The second part of the motion reads:
(b) selling out to banks and discriminating against building societies

`Selling out to banks' may be a flamboyant way of speaking, but it is still an extravagant statement. The banks have demonstrated the falsity of the Government's position with the interest situation and the props that they have. I suppose that at this stage the Government was caught out, and when it found it was on the hook, it had to allow the banks to make changes to the system, so that the banks would be able to restore their fund-gathering capacity.

The third point in the motion-making home ownership the exclusive preserve of the wealthy in Australia-again does not reflect the case at all. Certainly the savings banks have looked after the wealthy more than the lower price buyers but, by the same token, building societies have endeavoured to look after everyone in the housing market, as Senator Ryan was saying. It is a pity that we have to differentiate between the different classes, and it is a pity that the money available is distributed in the way in which it has been distributed. But the group that is particularly disadvantaged is the people who own housing for the rental market. Many of those who own property and rent it out do not do so because that is their business; they do so because that is the situation in which they wind up.

I doubt that the fourth point in the motion-creating the possibility that Australians will be paying over 20 per cent for home loans-is realistic. In Australia, the Government would be tossed out if we were experiencing 20 per cent home loans, and I do not really believe that the author of the motion would believe that that would be the case. On the other hand, if we deregulated and the dollar found a value of about 60c American, I think that the Government would get thrown out anyway. So, those are our two choices: Are we to have a 20 per cent housing rate, or are we to have a dollar worth 60c American? It is a loser both ways.

The motion goes on to speak of the urgent need for the Government to `reimpose the interest rate ceiling on new loans'. Clearly, if it was necessary to increase the rate to get money in for home loans, to reimpose a ceiling rate would drive the money out exactly in a reverse situation. That is obvious. The next point in the motion speaks of the urgent need for the Government to `guarantee that the interest rate ceiling on existing loans will not be removed'. Whilst I shall certainly return to that matter shortly, the question of getting guarantees from one or two people to do with interest rates or the housing business, or the management of the country at this stage, would be a little chancy.

The last point in the motion concerns the introduction of the alternative of what we now see as the Haines scheme. When I was going to school, I think it was called the granny bond scheme. It was a means of trying to attract money. But this has always been rejected because it provides differential benefits for investors, and those who need the concessions least are the people who get the greatest benefit from such a scheme. That has been the answer. But I support anything that will produce money for housing. As I say, the best way to do this is by having a proper, open mortgage guarantee system, a secondary finance system, so that we can encourage people to buy mortgages and to provide large lumps of money to the people whose business it is to provide housing finance.

I return to the question of the value of undertakings that we might get and the questions of getting a guarantee from people that the interest rate ceiling on existing loans will not be removed. We have had such a guarantees. I do not see why another lot would be of any greater reliability than the previous ones. I mention one or two of those. On 14 November 1985, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made this statement:

. . . as the Treasurer and I have said on a number of occasions . . . we will not scrap the 13.5 per cent interest rate ceiling . . . This is one area in which this Government is making it quite clear that it will not allow interest rates to rise.
On 3 December, in the South Australian election campaign, the Prime Minister said:
I have reaffirmed today. I have made it quite clear. I have told Mr Bannon again, not that he had any doubt, that my Government will not lift the ceiling on home mortgage rates.
Then the question was:
Will they rise after December 7th?
The answer was: `Of course they won't'. So it goes on with the Prime Minister, and then we get on to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who was asked:
You are still insisting, are you, that the 13 1/2 per cent ceiling on home loan interest rates should be maintained?

Mr Keating said: `Yes, I am'. It just goes on and on. We have so many classic cases of where we have had guarantees on this matter. We even get to the stage at which Mr Robert Tickner, for instance, calls it `a kamikaze political act'. Mr Peter Duncan says that it will `ruin the credibility of our senior Ministers'. Mr Gerry Hand says:
I find the assurances of my understanding of the comments made and assurances given are different to what in effect has occurred.

Mr Frank Walker says that to float the interest rate at all `could jeopardise all Labor governments'. I do not see why the mover of the motion would have any more feeling of guarantee that an undertaking on this matter would be any better now than it has been in the past. Of course, we also had the same guarantee about a new capital gains tax. Prior to the election before last, we had that absolutely gilt-edged, cast-iron guarantee: `There will be no capital gains tax'.

Matters such as that have had a big effect on housing in the last few years. We cannot look to what has happened concerning the effect of this freeing of the interest rate to this extent with the banks, as compared with what the longer term issues are and their effects. Last week a headline in the Hobart Mercury, on the front page, was:
Crisis in housing
Families forced on to street as Hobart rents soar beyond reach.

It is the other actions of the Government that have brought about increases in rent and have made people sell rental properties. It is the high interest rates that have made rents rise. It has caught people who can afford it least-people such as students, the elderly and the frail; and people who need to live somewhere near a relation. Again, I do not think that it is necessarily so that everyone wants to own their own property or needs to own it. There needs to be a pool of rental housing. I do not see that it is necessarily a good thing to try to make everyone into a home owner. I realise that Mr Dedman was of the other opinion, when he said that it was unfortunate if we had too many home owners. But that is not the point. The point is that we need to get people housed, and housed as well as we can. The interest rate question is nothing like as important as are the general economic circumstances, the feeling that tax is around the corner all the time, the knowledge that we are to have capital gains tax and to be caught up in any other ways when the Government wants to pull a few bob out of the market and to make the ownership of property less attractive.

TALK.START.PARA: —They just pulled $120m out to give to the banks. It is more than a few bob.

—That is right. It is a real bank deal, this $120m. I dislike the fact that this is being done under pressure. But all that it shows is that the banks were able to demonstrate to the Government that what it was doing was so wrong that it had to be put right in some way, and the Government chose the messiest and silliest way, which will live with it forever into the bargain. I do not always agree with Max Walsh, but I noticed in the Age of 8 April that he made a very telling comment. He finished an article by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Politicians and commentators who try to tell us that a $120 million subsidy to one of the better-off sectors of our community is a victory for economic rationalism should buy themselves a dictionary.

That sums it up well. It falls to me, Mr President, to move an amendment to the motion. We accept the basis of what the Australian Democrats have in mind-that the housing market is in a mess, that the Government's actions are inappropriate and that the worst of all worlds is with us-but we cannot accept that they were on the right track.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Archer for Senator Chaney) agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chaney moving an amendment to the motion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ARCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Chaney I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave out the statement of the matter of urgency, insert:
`The reprehensible conduct of the Government in
(a) maintaining artificially high interest rates;
(b) proceeding with the introduction of a capital gains tax;
(c) announcing plans to eliminate housing negative gearing; and
(d) providing direct assistance to banks and not to building societies,
leading to
(e) an increased burden on new home buyers;
(f) penalising existing home owners with mortgages other than from the savings banks;
(g) higher house construction costs;
(h) discrimination against home owners generally and lower income earners particularly;
(i) reduction in the availability of rental property; and
(j) significant increases in rental levels'.
Senator Chipp-Mr President, I take a point of order which I believe is important. It may take a little time--
Senator Robert Ray-Don't cut it out of my speaking time.

Senator Chipp-If I take up someone's speaking time it will be my own. As the last speaker in this debate, I will be the only one who will be affected. However, Mr President, I think your ruling is needed on a precedent relating to a matter of urgency which efforts are being made to establish today. The Democrats, through Senator Haines, have moved:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

I remind you, Sir, that the distinctive thing about a matter of urgency is that the Senate votes on it; the Senate expresses an opinion on it. The Democrats are on their own in this place in that they are critical of what the Government has done in allowing interest rates to rise on loans taken out by new home buyers. The next words of Senator Haines's motion are:
The reprehensible conduct of the Government in
(a) selling out all future Australian home buyers by deregulating the interest rate ceiling for new home buyers last week;

The motion then refers to selling out to banks, making home ownership difficult et cetera. It then refers to the reimposition of the interest rate ceiling on new homes and whatever. That was our matter of urgency.

By tradition the three parties in this place-the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats-have adopted a practice which has worked very amicably whereby each party takes it in turn to move a matter of urgency on which the Senate votes. The amendment just moved, I believe in good faith, by Senator Archer will virtually truncate our matter of urgency in every shape and form. It will make it meaningless because Senator Archer has moved that all words of ours-all words in Senator Haines's motion-be left out. The Opposition's amendment then seeks to substitute the words:
(a) maintaining artificially high interest rates;
(b) proceeding with the introduction of a capital gains tax;
(c) announcing plans to eliminate housing negative gearing; and
(d) providing direct assistance to banks . . .
and whatever. Standing order 139 states:
Every Amendment must be relevant to the Question to which it is proposed to be made.

Negative gearing and capital gains tax have absolutely nothing to do with the matter of urgency put down by Senator Haines. Senator Haines, on behalf of the Democrats, simply said that it is iniquitous that the Government has done this deal with the banks, paying them $120m subsidy and making new home buyers pay interest rates of 15 1/2 per cent. We think this is scandalous. If, Mr President, you put the question that the words proposed to be left out be left out, which undoubtedly, because of collusion between the Opposition and the Government, will be passed, this chamber will not be able to vote on Senator Haines's motion.

As I have said, the practice regarding matters of urgency has worked so well in this chamber. We paid the Liberals the courtesy of asking them whether we could raise this matter today. The Liberals have now constructed a ruse that will prevent the Democrats' matter of urgency being voted on. I just say to members of the Opposition that they can be too smart by half in this place. If they go ahead with this tactic today, for the remainder of the session there will be not one matter of urgency that they bring in that will not be truncated and made totally unrecognisable. What the Opposition is doing is bad sportsmanship, it is not playing the game and it is something that goes against the whole spirit of what co-operation is supposed to mean in this place.

Senator Chaney-Mr President, I take it that the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) has taken a point of order in respect of the amendment moved on behalf of the Opposition. He suggested that it was not a proper amendment under standing order 139. It was, of course, Senator Chipp who introduced this procedure to the Senate. He is waxing very indignant at the moment but it was he who, I think for the first time, introduced this procedure whereby Standing Orders could be suspended on a simple majority to enable these sorts of amendments to be made. The whole point, of course, is that originally under this procedure people could have been put in the position of being embarrassed by the fact that they had to vote either for or against a proposition that might contain various statements, some with which they agreed and some with which they disagreed. Of course, the Democrats have very carefully drawn the motion that they moved today to try to mix up propositions, some of which might have the support of the Opposition and some of which would not.

Obviously, the Opposition-and I am sure the Government also would not support the reimposition of an interest rate ceiling on new home loans. The Democrats have listed a series of what they describe as reprehensible elements of conduct on the part of the Government. They seek to make the Opposition cast a vote which could then be represented as being against all propositions contained in their motion whereas there may be some elements in it with which we would agree. For example, we might agree that because of the way this Government is going about running the economy there might well be interest rates going up to 20 per cent. We would certainly find that thoroughly objectionable.

What the Opposition is seeking to do with respect to this amendment is to pick up the central concern of the Democrat motion, which is the fact that the Government has indulged in what the Democrats describe as reprehensible conduct in a number of ways which affect home buyers in Australia. We agree with that broad general proposition of the Democrats. We think the Government has engaged in some reprehensible conduct. However, we disagree with some of the items of detail which are contained in the motion. We sought, therefore, to move an amendment which expresses very clearly what the Opposition's viewpoint is and why we believe that the conduct of the Government is reprehensible with respect to the housing industry. We refer to the very high interest rates which this Government has imposed. That is, of course, an element which is in common with the Australian Democrats' motion. Then we refer to things such as capital gains tax and negative gearing which will have a very substantially bad effect on the housing market in Australia. That situation is increasingly evident in the suburbs of Sydney, Melbourne and elsewhere where occupancy rates are so devastatingly bad and so on.

Mr President, what we are saying is that, thanks to the lead provided by Senator Chipp, we have in fact moved an amendment which will very clearly specify what the Opposition's position is and why we, in agreeing with the Senate that the Government has engaged in reprehensible conduct, disagree with some of the items of detail. I think to suggest that under standing order 139 this amendment is not relevant to the question is drawing a very long bow indeed. Mr President, I would respectfully suggest to you that all of the items which are contained in the amendment which was put down by Senator Archer on behalf of the Opposition are in fact relevant to the central point and the central concern of the motion which has been put forward by the Australian Democrats; that is, the position of Australian home owners. I draw your attention to paragraph (g) of the Democrats' motion which refers to the objective of all Australians being able to afford to own their own homes. We think that all of these matters are relevant. I would submit, Mr President, that it is a proper amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have given consideration to this matter. Standing order 64 provides that a motion to debate a matter of urgency may not be amended. Recently, leaders of parties in the Senate have given contingent notices of motion for the suspension of standing order 64 to permit them to move amendments to the motion. However, standing order 139 specifically provides that an amendment to any motion must be relevant to the question to which it is proposed to be made. In my opinion, it is clear that the suspension of Standing Orders, whilst it permits an amendment to be moved to the motion, does not absolve the mover from the provision that amendments must be strictly relevant. Accordingly, I rule that parts (b) and (c) of the proposed amendment-that is, the aspect relating to the proposal of the Government to introduce a capital gains tax and the aspect relating to plans to eliminate housing negative gearing-do not relate directly to the subject of the motion, which is the effect of the deregulation of interest rates on home ownership. Accordingly, I rule those portions of the proposed amendment out of order. I rule the other parts of the amendment in order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing today a matter of urgency raised by Senator Haines. I believe that, once again, the Australian Democrats are trying to play the three-card trick, which I suppose one could encapsulate as `all power and no responsibility'. No doubt, the Democrats always have very firm principles on the micro-problems of the world. I have always acknowledged how difficult it is for a group of parliamentarians in this chamber to cover a wide ambit of ides. The Democrats always manage to do it reasonably well. They are able to cover such things as takeovers, rainforests and repatriation-a very difficult task for seven people. But what tends to happen with the Democrats is that they get an expertise in the micro areas but never try to relate those micro areas together to a macro scheme of things. This motion is another classic example. They rarely relate these minor and detailed things to the macro conditions of the time. I understand, of course, that this is really a function of their survival strategy. Never having to appeal to 50 per cent of the vote rarely means that they have to look at the macro problem. It means that they just set out to protect the 8 to 12 per cent in anything they do. Therefore, they do not see the totality of what is developing in the economy. At the same time they never have to account to the electorate for tough measures. We used to call such people in the old black and white television days fringe area dwellers. They send a very fuzzy picture to their supporters; it is rarely clearly defined, rarely able to be debated, because they are never brought to book for the final responsibility of how the totality comes together. For instance, the Democrats always want to spend money, but they never want to raise it. Hence they can have the theoretical belief that some of them once had about death duties and capital gains taxes, but the nearer those propositions come to legislation and they have to put their hands up or whatever in this chamber, we have the difficulty that they suddenly go into a mode of indignant opposition and not support. As a colleague from South Australia said before, it is a form of popularism. If I were a Democrat I would also be into this popularism-of course I would. But I would not address it with the same sort of pious hypocrisy that they often bring into this chamber, and I would not have those holier than thou principles which have as much solidity as quicksand.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us put the motion moved by Senator Haines under the microscope and examine the various clauses. The first one says that we are selling out home buyers. Let us look at some of the facts. The previous Government in its last year in office presided over a fairly large collapse in the housing industry. In 1982-83 we had 105,000 home starts. By 1984-85 the figure had risen to 150,000 home starts. A lot of that increase to 150,000 obviously is to do with going back and taking up a bit of the slack from 1982-83. No one in this chamber would suggest that this country could sustain 150,000 housing starts a year. It would lead to a form of demand inflation that none of us would find acceptable. Given the current economic conditions in this country, it is the view of this Government and almost the view of the Opposition that 135,000 housing starts is the most acceptable and desirable level.

TALK.START.PARA: —One hundred and thirty thousand home starts.

—Senator Archer says 130,000. I am not here to argue. The level of housing starts we need this year to keep the economy viable and to meet existing demand is just a matter of judgment. We need 135,000 housing starts this year, next year and the year after. We do not need 100,000 one year and 150,000 the next-the cyclical boom and bust conditions that have afflicted the housing industry no matter what government we have in Canberra. We have to cut out the cyclical nature of that.

SPEECH.PARA: In March this year, we were facing the position of seeing a major erosion of savings bank deposits, indicating that the savings banks would be lending something like $3 billion less for housing than the Government and anyone else in the community would think desirable. This would have left us in a situation where there would have been 100,000 housing starts this year and that, we all agree, would have been disastrous. It would have meant that in the order of 50,000 jobs would have disappeared. Senator Haines in her speech mentioned the multiplier effect of the building industry. By lifting the rate on new loans it appears likely that just on $6 billion will be lent by the banks this year, thus ensuring those 135,000 housing starts. I am not about to come in here and say that that decision did not involve a fair amount of political pain and that we will not pay a price for it in the electorate with a degree of unpopularity-we will. In fact, what we are doing is showing some courage in government, a courage that I would commend to the Democrats on occasion to ape.

In the second point of the motion we are accused of selling out to the banks. The Democrats apparently do not realise that banks have to service existing loans. If the ceiling theoretically were lifted on existing loans the banks would be entitled to $480m more than they are currently getting. We are criticised for subsidising that $480m gap by providing $120m. We should ask ourselves where the other $360m forgone profit is. People talk about the record profits in banking last year-I acknowledge that. I would be terribly surprised if the figures were anything like that this year, because in the first quarter of this year the banks have had to sustain and service those existing loans at a loss. We are arguing in government that to retain the ceiling on existing borrowers it was necessary to subsidise the banks by up to $120m. We do not know how much that will be over a full year because the subsidy is applied over quarters and will depend on the rate of interest later this year and early next year. It could go up to $120m; it could be $70m. We are not in the business of predicting future interest rates particularly. That has always been difficult to predict, as both sides of this chamber have discovered. My guess is that, given the current downward trend, the whole $120m will not be expended.

I move to point (b), where we are accused of discriminating against building societies. The reality is that building societies have not been affected by the collapse of savings or deposits in the same way as savings banks. The savings bank deposits grew only 2.3 per cent last year compared with the rise for building societies of 11 per cent. We have to remember that building societies did not have the 13.5 per cent ceiling imposed on them and have been in a far better competitive position than the savings banks. All we are doing through our subsidy to the savings banks is restoring the competitive position of those savings banks. We are not giving them any undue advantage.

The third point in the motion moved by Senator Haines is that what we are doing is exclusively for the preserve of the wealthy. If there had been only 100,000 housing starts this year, of course it would have favoured the wealthy. The reality is that under past financing of home loans there has been nothing equitable about it at all. Most of the funds come from the poorer people and are stuck in deposits at 3 or 3 3/4 per cent and then lent to people who have a better credit rating. There has been nothing particularly fair about this past system that the Democrats find so wonderful. If we had only 100,000 housing starts this year, we would have found that only the well off would have got them. By keeping the level up at 135,000 we enable many more people from many more sections of society to undertake those borrowings. As well as that, banks have given commitments to a new way of financing home loans and are guaranteeing more low start loans. The old credit foncier loans system is on the way out and the sooner it goes, I would argue, the better.

Senator Ryan pointed out that the Democrats have overlooked our commitment to public housing. Public housing starts were 9,000 in 1982-83. They are currently running at 17,500 and we are proposing in the next financial year to go to 21,500. There are a variety of measures that in fact belie Senator Haines's claim. Indeed, I would argue fairly strongly that many of the people who are less able to pay loans are paying well above 15.5 per cent now. Bank loans are not available. They have to go into all sorts of weird and assorted cocktails that sometimes raise their repayment rates to 18 to 19 per cent. It is a truism that the least well off in the community get screwed by financial institutions far more than anyone else.

Let us move to point (d) in Senator Haines's motion, in which she condemned us for a potential 20 per cent home loan interest rate. I am not particularly good in the prediction stakes. However, the first point I make is that rates on bank notes have come down four points in the last four or five months. Every other indication is that interest rates are trending down. I do not think anyone in this chamber would deny that that has been the trend over the last four months. Whether that trend will continue is dependent on a number of factors. It will depend on the terms of trade over the next 12 months. It will depend on the rate of inflation in this country over the next 12 months. It will depend on the degree of Budget deficit adopted for 1986-87. It will depend on all those sorts of things but there is every indication at the moment that interest rates will come down. The real question is how far. If currently people are paying 15.5 per cent for a bank loan on new loans, will it go down to the 13.5 per cent barrier by, say, December? That is the $64,000 question.

One point I would like to make at this stage is that by deregulating the new interest rate, every government now has to come to account on the level of interest rates. Governments cannot hide behind the ceiling any more. If there is a prevailing rate of interest out there of 15, 16 or 17 per cent on home loan interest rates, any government that sustains that level over a long period of time will be defeated by this electorate. Abolishing the ceiling has, in fact, made governments more conscious of monetary policy. It means that instead of hiding behind monetary policies, they will have to take more responsible fiscal measures in future.

Point (e) calls on us to reimpose that ceiling. The question was asked, of course, by Senator Haines and others: Where did the banks suddenly get money from to lend? The Democrats should ask themselves where the banks got the money from over the last three months as deposits fell away. The banks have been moving money over from their trading bank accounts and lending it out at a loss.

TALK.START.PARA: —Offer them this handkerchief, will you?

—They were able to do it in the short term in anticipation of increased deposits for savings banks. The Democrats will bleat on and carry on here trying unsuccessfully to interrupt the train of my thought. They can do that as much as they like, but I did listen and I wonder what their solution is. They are always good on criticism. They come in here and bleat about this and that but when we ask them for a solution to anything, it is absolutely missing. Their policy, if I can assume a policy for them, is that they would like us to go and borrow billions of dollars, increase public indebtedness, keep interest rates up forever and subsidise interest rates forever. That would be their policy. That is the soft option. Am I wrong? Of course it is their policy. I would not have to hear their policy, I would just have to go out of this room, work out what is the weak soft option and I predict that the Democrats would come up with it every time. The Democrats will do it on housing and they will do it on everything else. As I said before, the Democrats are in the market-place for 8 to 12 per cent of the vote, not 50 per cent of the vote. That is their goal. They should protect their constituency and we will protect ours. We were asked under point (f) whether we would give a guarantee that existing rates would not be cut. We will give that guarantee because we are not in the business of slashing our wrists. If we lifted the existing rates on existing loans we would be sitting over there very quickly. They know it and I know it. We can give that guarantee under point (f).

SPEECH.PARA: The final point was that the Senate should support Senator Haines's proposal. I did not hear it today. I do not know what it is. How can I vote for that? Where is it? Why did not Senator Haines mention it in her 20-minute speech instead of going on with cartoons and the rest of the rubbish she started with and the other froth and bubble? Why did she not introduce into this chamber the Democrats' alternative?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in my private member's Bill.
—I have one final point to make. I was going to attack the policies of the Liberal Party but I cannot.
