SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing a critical question for the community; that is, the cost of housing loans. Investment in a home is the most important single investment that nearly every Australian will make during his lifetime. These new housing loan interest rates cannot be considered in isolation. We must also look, not only at the cost of housing loans for new acquisitions, but also at the cost of servicing existing loans for housing, at the availability of welfare housing and the availability of rental accommodation. All must be looked at as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing we must look at as a whole is the effect of interest rates as a total. Housing interest rates reflect other interest rates. They cannot be separated from the effects of economic policy and are a consequence of interest rates. The fact is that the general management of the Australian economy at the moment is a shambles. The Australian community-people in employment, particularly-is not aware of what the general economic situation is in this country. At the moment we are borrowing overseas $1,000m a month to support our current standard of living. The much heralded J curve which was going to solve all our problems by increasing the competitiveness of our exports and by solving the balance of payments just is not working. We have recently received the accounts for March. The current account deficit in February was $979m. In March it was $1,023m. That should be compared with the current account deficit for March 1985 of $593m. It has gone up over the last year from $593m to $1,023m.

If one looks at the promised effects of the J curve, so beloved by Treasurer Keating, even more telling is that in March 1985 our balance of trade was a credit of $187m. In March 1986, after devaluation when the J curve should have taken effect, our balance of trade was a loss of $221m. There was a swing of nearly $400m in our trade. What are we doing to face the situation? Under the pressure of this Government we are granting ourselves three pay rises this year. Looked at from outside those pay rises would have to be seen to be insanity. A pay rise is being negotiated now of about 2.2 to 2.4 per cent. There will be a so-called productivity rise costing about 3 per cent in the middle of the year and later in this year there will be a further pay rise, probably of about 4 per cent. One would like to think that a country that is trading at a loss and borrowing $1,000m a month to support itself would at least devote its productivity rise to making itself more competitive in international trade instead of, under the pressure of this Government, giving it back to the workers as a pay rise. The consequence, of course, is a depreciating Australian dollar. We have seen how it has fallen against the United States of America dollar. What we have not noted is that the United States dollar has fallen about 25 per cent against other currencies such as the West German mark and the Japanese yen. Our currency is falling very fast against nearly all the currencies of the world. We cannot carry on depreciating the Australian dollar because every time we depreciate it, the cost of servicing the $70 billion overseas debt rises more sharply and takes a larger proportion of our export earnings.

The only way the Government is propping up the Australian dollar is by keeping interest rates exceptionally high. At the moment the Australian prime interest rate is 18 per cent. Let us compare that with other countries in the world-Japan, 6.9 per cent; West Germany, 9.1 per cent; France, 10.6 per cent; the United Kingdom 12.5 per cent; and the United States, 9.5 per cent; but Australia is 18 per cent. The effect of this, of course, is that it deters investment. This might, of course, be temporary assistance for the balance of payments, because it stops our companies which are supposed to be the ones which are turning around our balance of trade by investing particularly in the secondary industry sector. It will deter investment in machinery and capital equipment. In the short term that may have some benefits for the balance of payments, but in the longer run it will reduce our growth and stop us curing our chronic unemployment. This high interest rate is very damaging to the whole community. The future of Australia depends on getting our economy in better shape. It is urgently necessary that the Government take the necessary action to tackle the fundamental problems of the economy. But that is a debate for another day. Today we are looking at one of the consequences of this total mismanagement of the economy by this Government; that is, the consequence for housing, reflected by high interest rates.

The Australian Democrats have moved a motion on this subject referring, in terms we will undoubtedly agree with, to the reprehensible conduct of the Government. They then listed four aspects of reprehensible conduct, all of which have a grain of truth, but all of which, I think, are somewhat overstated. Therefore, we would not support them in their present form. In the first aspect the Democrats state that the Government is:
selling out all future Australian home buyers by deregulating the interest rate ceiling for new home buyers . . .

There are many points about this. The first is that what the Government has done is a perfect example of Hawkespeak: The fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promises one thing and does the opposite. For instance, he stated categorically that he was committed to the retention of the ceiling on housing interest rates. Two weeks later Mr Hawke announced that the Government had lifted the ceiling on new housing loans.

TALK.START.PARA: —But only on new ones.

—That is right. He said he was committed to the retention of the ceiling on them. He immediately weaseled out by saying that he was just lifting it on new ones. He promised that inflation would come down; he promised that the dollar would not fall to where it is; he promised different action on petrol prices. This is all correctly known as Hawkespeak, which means that the Prime Minister says one thing and does another. But I think the value of his promises is doing somewhat worse than the Australian dollar because there is no high interest rate to keep up the Prime Minister's credibility. That is the first aspect. We would not agree with the actual wording, but we support the sense of what is there. The second aspect of reprehensible conduct claimed by the Democrats is:

SPEECH.PARA: selling out to banks and discriminating against building societies;

It is not entirely clear, bearing in mind the clients of banks tend to be the more wealthy section of the community, why a $120m subsidy to the banks is necessary, but I suppose the Government has its own reasons for giving this sort of subsidy. The third aspect is:
making home ownership the exclusive preserve of the wealthy in Australia;

Again, this is over-stated, but it is true that new home buyers under the present system are subsidising existing borrowers. That is a point we should emphasise over and over again. The existing borrowers are being subsidised by the people who are trying to get their first home. The fourth aspect is:
creating the possibility that Australians will be paying over 20% for home loans.
I suppose that is a possibility, but I think, as Senator Robert Ray has said, the Government would be out of office very soon afterwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are still in office in New Zealand.

—One would think the New Zealand Government would be out too. The Australian Government would be out very soon after housing loans crack the 20 per cent barrier. We agree with the general thrust of the motion by the Democrats but not the detail. We disagree what they propose should be done; that is:

SPEECH.PARA: and the urgent need for the Government to reimpose the interest rate ceiling on new home loans;

As the Government is managing the economy at the moment, if it did that it would mean that there would be no money at all available for housing loans at 13.5 per cent. So the critical question is that the Government must improve its management of the economy, but it will not achieve much by going to this particular solution. That would merely ensure that there was no money at all available from banks for new housing loans. The Democrats then call on the Government to:
guarantee that the interest rate ceiling on existing loans will not be removed;

I heard Senator Robert Ray give that guarantee. I think honourable senators will find that that is another piece that may be called Rayspeak instead of Hawkespeak. I do not think the Government will stick to that. The final proposal is for the Government to:
introduce as an alternative the plan proposed by Senator Haines. . .
I think that was dealt with adequately by my colleague, Senator Archer.

What we propose is more directly credible than the somewhat exaggerated criticisms, and not very accurate criticisms, of the Democrats. We propose that the Senate should recognise as a matter of urgency that the Government's conduct is reprehensible and irresponsible in maintaining artificially high interest rates. Its management of the economy is deplorable. The effects have not yet hit the Australian public, but the Australian public is suffering now and will suffer more in the future from the Government's refusal to tackle the fundamental problems of our economy.

The second point is that the Government should be criticised for providing direct assistance to banks and not to building societies. We have heard no credible explanation of why that should be so. These problems lead, firstly, to an increased burden on new home buyers who are subsidising existing borrowers, existing home owners, and, secondly, they penalise existing home owners with mortgages other than at savings banks. That is true. Why should a subsidy be given to borrowers from banks who tend to be the wealthier people, and no subsidy given to borrowers from building societies who, on the whole, tend to be the less affluent people? We also have higher house construction costs. I have recently seen figures of the soaring cost of home ownership. Last year the cost of an average home went up in my home town of Melbourne by 13.5 per cent. Housing costs are rising very sharply.

The fourth consequence of the Government's maladministration is discrimination against home owners generally and lower income earners particularly. I think that is self-evident. The last two consequences will be dealt with by my colleague, Senator Reid; that is, the reduction in the availability of rental property and the significant increases in rental levels. The provision of accommodation and homes must be considered as a whole and rental accommodation has a very strong impact on the other aspects of home ownership. As I said at the outset, the whole Government economic management is the source of this problem. It is a shambles and it is impacting through high interest rates on the community. As a matter of fact, this Government reminds me very much of Neville Chamberlain, the British Prime Minister, when faced with the rise of Hitler. Those who read history will remember that Neville Chamberlain was all for discussion, appeasement and trying to take trivial actions which bore no relation to the scale of the events he was confronted with. He even came back with a piece of paper, an accord I suppose he might have called it, which he flourished saying: `This represents peace in our time'. I think our accord should have been drafted in Munich. The Government is failing to represent to the community the real economic situation faced by this country. I repeat that we are borrowing $1,000m a month to support our current standard of living. What is the Government doing to tackle it? Nothing. We have got to face up to our economic future. We must tackle these problems as a nation united. The Government is here to govern and it must give leadership. This problem of housing interest rates is merely a symptom of a deeper problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hamer for his comments that at least gave recognition of the exaggeration that the Australian Democrats have put forward in this matter of urgency this afternoon. However, I cannot let pass his accusations about what he calls Hawkespeak or Rayspeak. All I can say is that if honourable senators look at current opinion polls it appears as if Hawkespeak is considerably more acceptable than Howardspeak in the Australian community today. To listen to the long and sorry tale of woe from Senator Haines and others here this afternoon, anyone would imagine that nothing had happened in regard to housing policy in the last three years. We have heard at length constant criticisms of the situation that has arisen in the last couple of months but, of course, the Opposition has conveniently ignored the very positive moves that the Hawke Government has taken with regard to the provision of housing for many thousands of young and not so young Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: If anything in this debate this afternoon is reprehensible it is the gross misrepresentation by members of the Opposition in failing to acknowledge the very sound commitment that has been given to housing policy by this government. Where has Senator Haines been during the last three years, for example? She spoke as though she had never heard of the first home owners assistance scheme under which, from 1 October 1983 to 29 August 1985, some 157,615 applications were approved to assist young home owners to buy their first homes. This assistance was provided at a cost in excess of $477m; yet, listening to the debate this afternoon, one would think that absolutely no financial commitment had been made and no planning had been put forward by this Government. What about the massive commitment to public housing? Members on the Opposition benches-I am referring to members of the Liberal Party-can certainly do nothing but hang their heads in shame when one considers the lack of commitment to public housing during the Fraser years.

Under the 1985-86 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement the States will receive the following amounts for housing: An amount of $517.5m will be given for untied grants; $36.5m for rental assistance to pensioners; $54m for rental assistance to Aborigines; $22.5m for mortgage and rent relief scheme; $13m for crisis accommodation; and $10m for the local government community housing scheme. Those last two schemes were initiatives of the Hawke Government. That scarcely sounds like reprehensible circumstances with regard to the Government's commitment to housing. The hypocrisy of members of the former Liberal Government to cry `shock, horror' with regard to that commitment! Let me remind them of their pathetic performance under Malcolm Fraser's rule. When we came into power the housing situation was absolutely hopeless. The industry had collapsed. There were only 105,000 commencements in 1982-83. Public housing funding had been completely slashed under the former Liberal Government. Only $406m in direct funds to public housing had been spent. Home ownership assistance had collapsed.

As soon as this Government came into power we took immediate steps to save the situation. We introduced the first home owners assistance scheme. We boosted public housing funding by 50 per cent, to $570m, in direct grants for 1983-84 and $624m for 1984-85. Do those figures sound like reprehensible circumstances with regard to the Government's commitment to housing? Of course not. The effect on industry was significant. In 1984-85 the number of housing commencements was 152,000-the highest for 11 years. The job growth in housing and construction resulted in some 70,000 persons being employed. This, of course, was a significant contribution to meeting the Hawke Government's target of half a million jobs.

This afternoon Senator Ryan and Senator Robert Ray documented the background to the Government's decision. I think it is important just to restate some of the points that were made. The announced package has given clear commitments to Australian home buyers and some of the key features need to be restated. The Government has maintained its commitment to protect existing savings bank home loans. The interest ceiling of 13.5 per cent will remain in force for the entire term of those mortgages. Senator Hamer and Senator Macklin can be sceptical, if they please, but the commitment has been given and I, for one, would vouch absolutely for the commitment.

The savings banks will be assisted to lift their home lending, firstly, by the Government providing them with cash assistance to ensure that they can maintain the deposits necessary to underpin existing home loans and, secondly, through the removal of the 13 1/2 per cent interest ceiling on all new home loans to allow banks to offer higher interest on deposits. Both measures combined will enable the savings banks to make $6 billion available for home lending in 1986-87 compared with the expectation of an annualised rate of lending of less than $3 billion. To help low income borrowers-these are the people whom Senator Haines is so concerned about-the banks have also promised to offer more low start loans and similar packages.

One of the problems with Australia's old banking system was that it lacked innovation, especially in home lending. Usually repayments, as a proportion of income, are greatest in the early years of a loan, just when the home buyer is struggling to make ends meet. The burden is far easier down the track when people are more established in their jobs and more likely to be on higher incomes. In the last couple of years financial deregulation has seen the advent of new housing finance packages tailored so that people pay less in the early years when their families are young and when they have more commitments to meet in establishing their homes, and they make up the difference later when they are more able to afford it. With funds drying up generally, those sorts of loans were drying up too. Now, the banks have committed themselves to making those loans much more readily available and, obviously, we will be monitoring the banks' commitment to ensure that that commitment does become a reality for many low income borrowers.

In conclusion, I suggest that Senator Haines listen more attentively to her more senior colleague Senator Chipp, whose understanding of the real issues with regard to housing seems to be more astute. I do not have with me the text of an interview that Senator Chipp gave, and I certainly would not wish to misrepresent him in any way. However, in Brisbane on Friday, 4 April, just after the announcement by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), Senator Chipp was interviewed on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio about the Government's housing decision. Despite the fact that on the news on the same day my good colleague Senator Macklin, who is sitting on my right, was pontificating and predicting doom and gloom, the comments of Senator Chipp seemed totally rational and totally recognised the dilemma that was facing the Government at that stage. Far from predicting doom and gloom Senator Chipp did acknowledge the Government's dilemma and the need to protect the building industry. I am sure that Senator Chipp will speak for himself with regard to this interview but, as I recall it, he certainly was not predicting the kind of doom and gloom and hysteria that we have heard this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) responded on behalf of the Government earlier in the debate on the matter of urgency, she indicated that housing was an integral and crucial part of the economy. There can be little doubt about that. That is why we are concerned about the chaos that exists in the housing industry at present about which we have heard quite a lot lately. I think the issue was debated quite recently in the Senate. We need real solutions to the problems of the housing industry. We need to reduce the rate of unemployment. That has not been mentioned today, but it is also part of the problem when one thinks about the number of people on the list seeking welfare housing at present. We need to reduce interest rates. The rates of interest in Australia compared with those in other countries with which we deal were mentioned earlier in the debate to show just how high our rates of interest are.

SPEECH.PARA: The rate of interest for housing is not specifically the problem; it is the rate of interest that all sections of the community are required to pay. The solution is not just to allocate more for public spending. We have heard, as Senator Reynolds has pointed out, the big spending solution to the housing problem. It is a question of spending more money when one sees a problem. As Senator Withers indicated earlier in the debate, if one spends a lot of money, the problem may go away, but we all know that it will not.

We have had the big spending solutions. Do honourable members remember Priority One: Young Australia? It was the big announcement in the August Budget last year. An amount of $5m was to be spent in 1985-86. Certainly, much of it has been spent, perhaps all of it by now. Mainly, it was spent on a big promotion for the Government. It was real bread and circuses act. It was supposed to have produced 10,000 jobs in each of three years. What has happened under Priority One so far this year? Has it provided as many as 600 jobs? It will be interesting to find out exactly what the figure is, but certainly it has not done for young people what it was supposed to have done.

Last week we had another big spending solution. We heard that $1,000m was to be spent on the drug offensive. Certainly, the aims are quite laudable. But the $1,000m is not being given now. It incorporates many initiatives that are already under way. It is really a bit of a gimmick to talk about $1,000m being spent on the drug offensive over three years. If one looks closely at it, one sees that what is being addressed is an education program. There is no attack on the source of drugs. There is no increase in penalties for those who are involved in this area. There is no serious threat that anyone will actually spend a long time in goal if he is convicted of an offence. There is no increase in the powers of the National Crime Authority.

Now we have the big spending solution to the crisis in the housing area. We need economic policies which will cause interest rates to come down, so that farmers, small business, home buyers and would-be home buyers will benefit. An amount of $120m is to be spent by the Government. We have heard today why this amount is being spent in the way that has been announced. Building societies are being left out and will not benefit. We have heard that $700m is to be spent to maintain the real value of public housing. But no solution has been offered in regard to cutting down the number of people on the welfare housing list who need welfare housing because the economic circumstances in which they find themselves are such that they have no alternative.

It is not really surprising that there is such a split in the Australian Labor Party in regard to this policy. Without taking up too much time, I mention the newspaper headline `Wran Attacks Government on Housing'. He criticised it for directly paying to the banks and not to the borrowers. He dealt with the serious implications-naturally being the New South Wales Premier-for the New South Wales building societies, which would be placed at a competitive disadvantage. Of course, the same disadvantage applies to all other building societies. But it was not just in New South Wales that we saw this split in the Labor Party. The State Council of the Queensland ALP strongly condemned the Federal Government at the weekend for allowing banks to lift interest rates on new home loans.
There are problems in the housing industry. The media also noticed it. Mr Laurie Oakes, speaking on the Midday Show with Ray Martin on 3 April, said:
It was a backflip of Olympic gold medal standard. The Opposition is referring to it as a U-turn, but it is more of a wheelie.

The Australian Financial Review said that it was one of the more remarkable political backflips of recent times, and there were many other similar quotations. The Government cannot hide behind what it has done in this area. It has not addressed the real problems and found real solutions.

The rental market is seriously affected by the Government's policies in this area and other areas. Of course, I accept the President's ruling that it is not appropriate to discuss the capital gains tax and negative gearing under the terms of the original motion, but one can refer to them as additional ways in which the rental market has been affected. I am sure that all of those in the industry are well aware of it. Rents are very high at present. It is very difficult to obtain rental accommodation because it is no longer attractive for landlords to be involved in renting. They are getting out of that area and new investors are not entering it. If the Government thinks that only big business is involved in the rental market, I can assure it that that is not so. In a place such as Canberra a number of people in the past have had a second house which they have paid off as a means of forced saving. Either the capital gains or negative gearing situation has made it attractive for them to do so. It meant that houses were available for those people who needed to rent. But one cannot escape the fact that over the six months from June to December 1985 the list of those needing rental accommodation in the public sector escalated from 143,000 to 159,000. Many of them, of course, were unemployed and not able to meet the sorts of rents that they would have to meet in the private rental sector.

Many of those people would have once hoped that they would have been able to buy a house. Perhaps they hope that the time will come when they will be able to do so. But because of the high interest rates many have had their hopes dashed. Whereas once upon a time one could buy a house and expect that a quarter of one's salary would be spent on servicing the mortgage, that is no longer the case. The present situation is that there must be virtually two wage earners in a family for the family to even contemplate paying off a mortgage. I think many of the people who have entered into low start loans and the fancy arrangements that have arisen will find in the future that they are not in the position that they thought they would be and that the additional costs on their mortgages are extraordinarily high. If they want to sell the house quite early in the mortgage period, they may even find that they owe a great deal more than the house is worth at that time. Those are some of the problems that flow as a consequence of the economic policies of this Government which have clearly led to the position we are in today. The motion before the Senate is about matters which need to be discussed as they are matters of urgency.

Let us not forget the impact on those in the rental market. They are particularly vulnerable, both socially and in other ways, as a consequence of their situation. Some people are required to move frequently and must move from one rental property to another. They may live in a caravan here and a room there. This has an impact not only on the mother and father, but also on the children of those families. They are required to change schools frequently. The two disadvantaged schools that exist in the Australian Capital Territory have within them a number of students who move frequently so that the turnover of students is particularly high. Those people are being disadvantaged more than ever because their education is disrupted in this way. The problem flows from the general economic situation of unemployment and high interest rates. Again, we are meeting the problem by imposing a big spending solution and not the solutions which will bring down interest rates, provide people with jobs and give them some stability in their lives.

I support the motion which has been put forward by the Opposition as an amendment to the original motion. I specifically refer to those areas which affect the rental market and the impact that will still be felt in that area. I believe the number of rental properties will continue to drop. I also refer to one other aspect which concerns a local matter. I noticed in the papers presented by the Department of Terri- tories in its supplementary estimates last week that $1.4m has not been spent this year under the Commissioner for Housing loans scheme. We have had a pretty bad run with housing in the Australian Capital Territory. We had the complete collapse of the scheme because of overcommitment a year or so ago and this year the Territory has underspent. I think the Minister needs to re-examine the criteria in order to see whether the means test, the total that can be borrowed and the value of houses on which it can be borrowed are right. It seems extraordinary at a time like this that there should be money left over-to the tune of $1.4m in this financial year. I support the amendment which we have put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reid for finishing early in order to give me a few minutes to speak on this motion. In four minutes time the bells will ring and senators will be called into the chamber to divide on this motion. SPEECH.PARA: A Labor Government will maintain interest rate controls on bank mortgage interest rates and extend those controls to building societies; require the savings banks and building societies to lend a set proportion of their funds for housing; establish an Australian Housing Fund in the Reserve Bank made up of deposits by non-bank financial institutions and channelled through the banks and building societies.

In other words, Mr Hawke said that under no circumstances would a Labor Government deregulate interest rates on homes. Now he has done that with the total, full and passionate support of the Liberal Party.

Let us look at the figures which show the effects of this action. The average income of an Australian worker is about $21,000 a year. I emphasise that: The average worker with a couple of kids takes home $360 a week. Because of this new move by the Labor Government, supported by the Liberal Party, $180 of that will go to paying off his home. Because we have deregulated interest rates we are now asking the Australian worker to buy food, clothing, education and every other expense for $180 a week. Into the bargain the Labor Government has donated $120m to the banks, the reason for which has not yet been made palpably clear. DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE TO THE NATIONAL INQUIRY INTO LOCAL GOVERNMENT FINANCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the Government's response to the Self report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance. The report is nearly 480 pages long and is a very important and well put together report. The reason I have mentioned the size of the report is that the Government's response is remarkable, both for its brevity and for its lack of substance. The response of the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) takes up three columns of the House of Representatives Hansard. There is no reference to what the States are doing and no attempt to deal with the question of rate pegging, and the question of rate exemptions has not been addressed. These are absolutely vital matters, which the Minister has made no attempt to address. There are many hundreds of other matters that the Minister has just allowed to go by; he has let the ball go through to the keeper.

The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations is about to be abolished. Although the Minister does not say so, it is obvious from his response that local government will not get the increase in the consumer price index plus two per cent which currently is the negotiated position with the States and the Federal Government. That position was negotiated by us when we were in government. The Minister does not refer to it. He talks about funding being guaranteed on a real consumer price index basis for 1986-87 and 1987-88, and that is where he ends. It is clear that if he was going to give local government the CPI increase plus two per cent, he would have said so. The fact that he is talking only about giving it the CPI increase indicates clearly that he will cut out the extra two per cent. It is clear that all the difficult decisions have been swept under the carpet or ignored and simply not dealt with by Minister Uren. He says:

The principal objective of the new program will be to provide financial assistance to those local councils who are most disadvantaged in respect of their ability to raise revenue and to provide services. That is, assistance will be provided principally for the purposes of horizontal equalisation.

The words `horizontal equalisation' are clearly gobbledegook. Local councillors really ought to have a good look at what this socialist Minister-Minister Uren is without doubt the most socialist Minister of this Government-did with the Australian Capital Territory when he was in control of it for a very short time. He tried to introduce socialisation as much as he possibly could. Local councillors should note that he is saying here that the most disadvantaged councils in respect of their ability to raise revenue and provide services will get the money. So it is clear that those councils which do their best to raise their rates from their customers will get the money. Those councils that do not bother to raise the rate revenue to the highest possible rate that they can get from the ratepayers will get the Federal funds.

That is what this Minister is all about. This is the Minister who approved funds for the Wyuna fiasco and for Tilley Devine's. There is a worrying absence of detailed financial commitment on the part of this Government. In regard to any financial arrangement with local councils, I say to local councillors: Get it set in concrete, otherwise you will surely not get anything out of this Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the statement made last Thursday by the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, Mr Uren, on personal income tax sharing arrangements for local government. It is a fact of history that in 1974-75 personal income tax sharing for local government was introduced by the Whitlam Government. I think it is fair to say that had there not been a Labor Government at that stage, there would have been no personal income tax sharing for local government in Australia today. The funds that were provided by the Labor Government in the 1970s were, in fact, the first untied funds made available to local government in this country from Canberra. Initially, some $50m a year was paid over by the Commonwealth to local government. By 1984-85, that sum had escalated to a very handsome $486m, and in the current financial year it is estimated that local government will receive from the Commonwealth Budget $534.7m. The funds that are paid are based on the previous year's personal income tax collections, and it is estimated that the growth in funds paid to local government in nominal terms this year will be 9.9 per cent. That represents a rise of 2 per cent on top of the estimated consumer price index increase for the current financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: On average across Australia, personal income tax sharing funds from the Commonwealth Budget represent the equivalent of about one-third of the rate revenue of local councils. I must say that in my State of South Australia some district councils receive more funds from Canberra than they do from rates. I instance the local government at Carrieton, in the mid-north of South Australia, which will I believe, in the current financial year, along with two other councils in South Australia, receive more funds from the Commonwealth Budget than it does from its own rate revenue. Personal income tax sharing funds have been a vital source of revenue for local government and they have enabled much needed services to be provided by local government.

I am very pleased that the Minister, in his statement last Thursday, undertook as a result of the Self Inquiry-that is, the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance-to continue on behalf of this Government a system of untied general revenue grants for local government. That is a very commendable policy from my point of view. The Minister has indicated that for the next two financial years-1986-87 and 1987-88-the base figure allocation for local government from the Commonwealth Budget will be this year's allocation of $534.7m, but also escalated to take into account cost rises reflected in the consumer price index over the next two years. Local government right around Australia can take heart from the Minister's statement that its general revenue funds, its untied payments from Canberra, in the next financial year and in the year after will be subject to a guarantee that maintains those funds in real terms. But over and above that, there is potential for a larger percentage increase in local government funds in the next two years. The increase will be not less than the percentage rise in the total general purpose funds available to the States, so that local government bodies can do better than a real terms maintenance of their funds; they can also expect some rise in real terms if there is a rise in real terms in general revenue funds available to the States.

That is a very commendable policy, and I am sure that it is welcome news to all local government bodies. It has certainly been warmly welcomed in my State of South Australia, where I undertook an extensive tour within the last few days of local government areas. Everybody in that State has been overjoyed at the news in the Minister's statement. His statement has certainly exposed the beat up by Senator Jessop on this matter in the Adelaide Advertiser of 24 March, in which he said that there would be big increases in rates for local government because this Government in Canberra was going to cut funds to local government. That is not true. It has been exposed as fear-mongering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is impossible in the space of five minutes to comment effectively upon the massive Self report-the report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance-and the diminutive ministerial response to that report. It is important to understand that the response of the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) comes against a background of the very great reforms brought in by the Fraser Government. It is important to remember that the present Minister was party, in the Whitlam Government, to a massive intrusion into local government, firstly by tied grants. The aim was to tie as far as possible the activities of local government; indeed, the stated policy of the Australian Labor Party then was to force local government, by means of tied grants, into a small series of regions. The whole aim was to centralise as far as possible into regions which were to be dominated from Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Fraser Government came into office it sought to disentangle this mess and to give to local government for the first time in history an equality of opportunity around the conference table. The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations, which I was privileged to set up in my time as Minister, brought for the first time local government, the State governments and the Commonwealth Government around the table for dialogue, discussion and research. Indeed, local government has more representatives on this body than does the Commonwealth. It will be a very grave matter if that advisory council is destroyed.

The Commonwealth Government and Labor State governments tend to regard local government as captive creatures of the States to act as their puppets. It would be ironic to take joy in the 1985-86 Budget decision regarding local government because the Fraser Government was responsible for local government receiving a 2 per cent revenue share. That percentage was reduced in the current Budget. So, in fact, if Labor takes joy, it is doing so in respect of a major reduction of funds from the previous level of 2 per cent. By using this year as a base for the future it is entrenching this practice.

It is important to recognise that local government in Australia represents a far smaller segment of government than is the case in almost any other democratic country. We tend to think that we are over-governed in Australia when we talk of a Commonwealth government, six State governments and 800-odd local governments. The fact is that if we look at even the unitary system in England, with its great county councils and local government areas, and if we look at the United States of America, with all its district boards, county boards and county taxes, we will see that there is far greater decentralisation of government in other countries than there is in Australia. This is a retrograde step. What has happened, tragically, particularly under Labor governments, and notably under the Wran Government in New South Wales, is that the funds made available by the Fraser Government in accordance with the 2 per cent formula resulted in a withdrawal of funds by State Labor governments and the imposition of more duties. As a result, the full benefit of untied grants and the full independence of decision-making has not been possible. Under Labor there has been a movement to destroy the independence of local government and now, of course, there is a move to shackle it.

It is a very great pity that we do not have time to debate in full the Self report and to analyse in detail the Minister's statement which runs true to the kind of pattern that we saw emerging under the Whitlam Government and which we now see emerging in terms of reduced freedom and real funding for local government. I regret that this should be so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sir John Carrick spoke of the work that the Fraser Government did in the area of local government. Of course, the Whitlam Government took the initiative in this field. It thought up the ideas that are now being put into practice and are a reality. The Whitlam Government has come in for considerable criticism for many of its actions. However, it is proper to praise the Whitlam Government for the initiative which it showed in this area which was then accepted by the Fraser Government. Senator Maguire said that over $530m had been set aside for local government this year and it is interesting to note the basis upon which that amount of money was made available. Senator Lewis said that the size of the response to the report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance is in contrast to the size of the report itself. Nonetheless, this report is of considerable quality. In the few minutes available to me I would like to quote from page 5 of the statement made by the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren), who has been accused of being the most socialist Minister in the Government. Whether that is so or not, it is interesting to see his very benign approach, the very great regard he has for local government and the efforts he makes to put that regard into practice. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to the recommendations of the National Inquiry the Government does not propose to make grants for local government conditional upon States maintaining their assistance to local government.

It is important that local government be independent of the States in regard to funding. As Senator Sir John Carrick has said, there is a tendency for the States to regard as captives the councils within their domains. So, by making funds available to local government and thereby not making local government dependent on the States, the Government is giving to local government an ability to exercise its powers above and beyond what the States might allow. Mr Uren went on to state:

Nor will the Government seek to interfere with States policies which limit rate increases. Should the Commonwealth act in these areas, it would only serve to penalise the local governments concerned for decisions in which they had no part. Maintenance of State assistance however, will be one of the matters subject to future review.

It is proper that the States should look to local government and try to make it more efficient. In fact, that is exactly what the State Government in Victoria is doing. The Victorian Government has set up a commission which includes Mr Stuart Morris, a member of the Melbourne Bar and a State planning tribunal and a man with an outstanding record in the field of local government. Mr Morris was President of the Shire of Sherbrooke and knows a great deal about local government. It is proper that reform should take place which will enable local government to perform tasks and give services which in many instances it is capable of doing. It is important that the services which are needed are amalgamated and provided to the citizens of the areas in which local government operates. The simple services that come to mind are the collecting of rubbish, the development of streets, the planting of trees and the other things which so affect the life of the ordinary citizen. It is important that local government be seen to be doing that. Indeed, it is important that the areas over which local government has responsibility be looked at more closely than has been the case.

For instance, we should look at the green triangle of Victoria which spills over into South Australia. We should also look at the La Trobe Valley, the Goulburn Valley and other similar areas. One sees the logic, as Senator Sir John Carrick said, of establishing areas on a more sensible basis. The report of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance is an important report. The Government's response is a most proper one. It shows the Minister's regard for local government; it shows this Government's regard for local government; and it shows that this Government is carrying on the traditions established originally under the initiative of the Whitlam Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the relief of the councils around the nation. The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) has, on this occasion, carried the day against the forces of reaction and darkness from the Treasury and the Department of Finance. How those two departments can continue with their pig-headed obstructive approach to most exciting new measures, on the basis of statistics from the 1960s, is beyond the comprehension of reason- able people. SPEECH.PARA: Both the Commonwealth Treasury and Department of Finance have relied heavily on Groenerwegen's 1976 study of rate effort in New South Wales. This survey was based on data from the 1960s, and so predates the introduction of General Revenue Sharing.

In other words, the departments were drawing conclusions about the operation of the personal income tax sharing arrangements solely on the basis of figures before those arrangements came into operation. That is a very disturbing tendency, all the more so because of the influence these departments command in view of their vice-like grip on all economic information and activity within this country. If they behave as badly in other areas and decisions are based on as shonky or irrelevant information as we have here, we will continue to have problems within Australia.

I know that most councils welcome the commitment of 30 per cent of untied funds on a per capita basis. This recognises the roles of all councils in delivering Commonwealth services in their areas and provides a guarantee against sudden cutbacks in project funding. The other 70 per cent of untied funds is to be allocated on the equalisation principle so that those councils most in need will get the largest amounts. The Government is offering real terms-guarantees for overall funding in the next two financial years. This is a good thing if the Government keeps its promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is offering real term guarantees of overall funding for the next two financial years. However, it is doing so in very vague terms. I hope that a 2 per cent growth rate will be included. This would tie local government to the same treatment as the States. Local government should be treated in the same way as the States. However, because of its expansion which has been half the rate of the Commonwealth and State bureaucracies and its funding avenues have been hemmed more tightly it will be important to ensure that Treasury and the Department of Finance do not lumber local government with the same sins as those of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also very important to note that rural councils are much more reliant on untied Commonwealth funding than are the metropolitan ones. In the 146 metropolitan councils, an average of 13 per cent of rate revenue is available from untied Commonwealth funding. However, in the 691 councils in rural areas, Commonwealth funding represents an average of 31 per cent of rate revenue. The situation is more marked in rural towns and purely rural councils where the untied Commonwealth money can be half of the rate revenue or even more. What that means is that any cut back in overall funding will hit hardest at the rural councils which are most reliant on that income. In the present rural crisis these councils have no way of increasing rates to make up for any Commonwealth short fall. They would have to cut services and lay off staff which would add further to the climate of depression in the worst affected rural areas. At least the Government has not worsened the predicament of rural Australia with this particular decision although a number of other decisions may be called into question. What the Government must do, however, is to face up squarely to the hornets' nest of the fringe benefits tax which itself is going to hit local councils and create an enormous number of problems.

When one looks at areas such as the Pilbara, one sees that there will be an extra $200,000 in tax on subsidised housing and $70,000 on free air travel for employees, which will make an enormous difference to the viability of those particular councils. It would be outrageous for the Commonwealth Government to claim back in fringe benefit taxes the `potentially extra' money it is giving in untied funds. I hope that the Government will examine this matter very carefully and refrain from putting rural and isolated Australian communities at a further unfair disadvantage.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH AUSTRALIAN LOCAL GOVERNMENT GRANTS COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The 1985 annual report of the South Australian Local Government Grants Commission outlines the procedures used in determining the amounts councils have received in untied Commonwealth funding in the current financial year. From July 1981, the base amount of funding available nationally for this purpose had been 2 per cent of personal income tax collected by the Commonwealth Government. In the light of the solemn promises by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about treating local government as a genuine partner in our three sphere system of government-these promises were made at the eighth National Institute of Municipal Management Seminar in May 1984-the Government's written commitment to 2 per cent of personal income tax was made just before the 1984 Federal election. Councils were not expecting unilateral action to undermine the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance. They received a rude shock last May when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that the 2 per cent of personal income tax would be watered down to a `2 per cent in real terms increase guarantee for any one year'. This statement came while the Self inquiry was still collecting evidence. Unfortunately, the Liberals and Nationals joined the Government to cut back the councils' entitlements. That means, in practice, that the Self inquiry could not realistically put forward a guaranteed percentage of taxation if the members wanted some action on the report.

The South Australian Local Government Grants Commission had, in October 1984, submitted that the 2 per cent of net personal income tax continue to be paid until another formula could be agreed on based on the range of services and functions performed by the various levels of government. That should have been the course of action, but a single stroke of Lib-Lab opportunism changed the rules of the game, despite both groups being committed in their policies to the 2 per cent of personal income tax.

I hope that the new arrangements about to emerge will prove more stable and not be susceptible to the same sort of tampering. The expanding roles of councils in providing human services and jobs that help sustain the rural communities should not be shrugged off again. I note that in the 1984-85 year the South Australian Local Government Grants Commission visited 47 councils and received 24 detailed submissions about special problems experienced by those councils. By such means it is able to get a feel for what is happening in each community. That is a very important factor in winning the confidence of recipient councils. The Commission reports a continuing problem with data provided by the Valuer-General as there are quite large jumps associated with new valuations. A three-year moving average has been used. This cuts out wild fluctuations in assessed entitlements. Large fluctuations in this area invite discontent amongst councils, particularly those which have lost out because their revenue earning capacity is much higher than the average revenue of the top 25 per cent of councils in their category. This uncertainty creates a climate of instability in which councils become very disturbed and reluctant to take on new services or to innovate. I commend the South Australian Local Government Grants Commission on its work and look forward to further excellent contributions in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the intention of Senator Macklin and the Australian Democrats in moving this motion. I certainly appreciate from my fairly short time here the problem faced by honourable senators and the intention of Senator Macklin to prevent, as he sees it, the crush of legislation which seems to occur before the end of every legislative session in this place. However, we should really think about what we are doing. I know that people in this place become very macho about the Senate, its powers and the fact that it is the most powerful upper House in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion dictates to the other chamber the procedures it should follow in debating the legislation before it. Senator Macklin says that a certain amount of blackmail is associated with the procedures he talked about at the end of a session. I do not believe that is necessarily blackmail. I think it has always been in the capacity of this chamber to say: `If we want to amend it, we will amend it and the House of Representatives will have to come back'. I can remember only one occasion when that sort of accusation could have been put to a government at the time. The effect of this motion will be, in fact, to tell the other chamber how to go about its business. Some people may not think that that is important, but I think it is important.

I think a possible outcome of the motion that Senator Macklin has put is that, as a result of the deadline that this motion may put on the other chamber, it may be the case that if an unscrupulous government were in power-I am not suggesting for one minute that this Government would do it-there would be an increased use of the gag or guillotine in the House of Representatives, therefore stifling the rights of members of that chamber. I do not think we should really indulge in that sort of behaviour.

I really would like to point out that the bunching of legislation, if it occurs in this place this year, will not be as a result of a large number of Bills being introduced by the Government. Senator Macklin was asked to demonstrate that that would be so, and he cannot. It will stem from the fact that we have a piece of legislation before this chamber which has already broken the record for the number of hours it has been debated. The Bill of Rights legislation has been debated for 35-plus hours, which is longer than any Bill since Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it should be.

—It has been the result of grandstanding and filibustering by the likes of the honourable senator who just interjected. That is a pity because, as I think I said at the end of the last session, we now have more senators and those senators seem determined to speak about everything that comes into this place, speak at great length and speak repeatedly. The inevitable result of that-I do not argue with it at all-is that we will have to sit longer, and I think we are going to have to sit--
—If you introduce them before then they can be adopted afterwards.

—Just a minute. I will come back to the honourable senator. He should not get excited about it. I think it is inevitable that we in this chamber will have to sit longer. We will have to sit many more weeks and in fact we will have to consider sitting many more hours in those weeks because what has happened is that there are more of us here for a start, more people want to speak and more people want to speak at inordinate length. I think the Standing Orders about tedious repetition have been forgotten years ago in this place, given what has happened with the Bill of Rights legislation. It is absolutely ludicrous that this chamber cannot make up its mind about such a piece of legislation after 35 hours of debate. Not even the filibustering in the United States of America approached that degree before it introduced the changes in its Standing Orders to stop it. I would have liked members of the Opposition to reconsider their position on this matter, but it is quite clear they are going to vote for the motion. Therefore, I feel bound to move an amendment which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph 1, after ``That'' (first occurring), insert ``, unless otherwise ordered''.

In other words, another unless otherwise ordered clause should be inserted into this motion. I do not think any government or any opposition could rule out at this stage of the sittings the possibility that genuine, urgent or emergency legislation may be required. Important legislation may arise. I do not actually anticipate this occurring but it may occur. Should this happen, we would have to move for the suspension of standing order 134, which requires either seven days notice or an absolute majority. We may not have an absolute majority even with goodwill in this place. Therefore, I think it is reasonable that the words `unless otherwise ordered' be inserted to provide a sensible version of the motion, which I admit has been put forward by Senator Macklin in all good faith and in order to overcome the problems that all of us have faced in the past. Accepting the fact that I have shortcomings in lots of areas, but counting is not one of them, and that this motion is going to go through, I urge honourable senators to support my amendment. I move:
Paragraph 1, after `That' (first occurring), insert `, unless otherwise ordered'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise on behalf of the Opposition to support the motion which has been put forward by Senator Macklin on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The motion in fact reflects a point of view which has often been put forward by the Opposition in this place and probably it has been put forward by oppositions of both a Liberal-National Party persuasion and a Labor Party persuasion. I think the motion does reflect a genuine difficulty that, for some reason, the process is one which leads to a bunching of legislation at the end of a session. It has long been my personal view that the only way to cure that is to introduce machinery which means that legislation which is introduced late will be held over. Just as a matter of curiosity, I went back over the discussions we have had in this place with respect to programs that the Government has announced. I looked at the Senate Hansard of 22 February.
—You are not going to quote me too.
—No, I am not going to quote Senator Grimes; I am going to quote myself. I stated my view on 22 February. I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate must look to its legislative function in a very careful way. I again put the view that if the Government introduces legislation of a substantial nature, which does have substance which requires attention, we should not deal with it in a way which prevents our giving it proper attention. If that means that legislation needs to be left until the Budget session because it has been introduced too late, I believe so be it.

I quote that merely to say that our support of the motion that has been put before us by Senator Macklin reflects our consistent view that time is necessary to consider legislation and the bunching of legislation does prevent us from doing the job that we are elected to do. I do not think it is a matter, as Senator Grimes suggested, of Senate powers; I think it is more a matter of Senate responsibility. I think we do have a responsibility to perform our legislative function in a more careful way. We cannot do that under the pressures under which this Government puts us and, indeed, previous governments have on occasions put the Senate. So I am delighted to support the motion which has been put forward by Senator Macklin. Incidentally, I accept the point made by the Manager of Government Business, Senator Grimes, that the Senate should be able to vary this if it wishes. I do not think it is necessary for the amendment that Senator Grimes has moved to be carried. I would have thought that it was open to the Senate to vary its own resolutions. Even if that is so, at worst, it is a belts and braces amendment, and the Opposition proposes to support it.

Last week we had a very good example of the sort of emergency Bill which had to be dealt with quickly. I refer to the legislation relating to the Builders Labourers Federation. There can always be some issue which arises which requires the Parliament's attention. I give notice to the Government that it certainly would not be our intention to use this proposal as a fetter to that sort of emergency action if it is required in the national interest. I do think it would be in the national interest to have a slowing down of the process if, indeed, a lot of legislation were introduced late.

I take issue with Senator Grimes on one other point. He criticised the debate which has taken place on the human rights legislation. I have not been directly involved in that debate, but a number of senators who are in the chamber now have been involved. I notice Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Macklin, and there are others who have taken part in the debate. Having heard a deal of it and having looked at the Hansard, I must say that I dispute Senator Grimes's suggestion that there has been anything in the nature of a filibuster. In fact, this is new legislation which introduced novel concepts to Australia. I think the quality of debate has been extremely high. I, on behalf of the Opposition, certainly reject any suggestion that there has been anything in the nature of a filibuster. That is certainly not true. Even if that suggestion were true, the motion moved by Senator Macklin is not one which would be affected by that suggestion because it relates only to when legislation is to be introduced. So there is nothing to stop the Government introducing its legislation day by day. That motion does not put any fetter on dealing with legislation which is introduced right up to 30 May this year.

With regard to whether the Senate will continue to sit after the dates which have been laid down, I take this opportunity to alert the Government and, indeed, the Australian Democrats to the fact that, given that the program envisages our sitting for a continuous three-week period at the end of May and the beginning of June, it is the view of the Opposition that we should not then just continue to sit week by week. It is the view of the Opposition that that puts an inordinate strain on all senators including, and perhaps most of all, Government Ministers. We will be asserting the view that if additional sittings are required there should be at least a one-week break after that proposed period of three weeks at the end of May and beginning of June before we resume sitting, if resumed sittings are in fact required.

I have only one other point to make. I cannot move an amendment because there is an amendment before the Chair. I foreshadow that when we have dealt with the Government's amendment to Senator Macklin's motion, I will move a further amendment, which has been circulated in my name, and which seeks to insert an additional paragraph in the motion. I shall speak to that amendment now, if I may, to save time. The amendment seeks to insert the following paragraph:

`(1a) That immediately after debate on a motion for the second reading of a Bill is adjourned in accordance with paragraph (1), or following the giving of notices on a subsequent day, a motion may be moved without notice to refer that Bill to a standing committee for inquiry and report by a day not later than the first day of sitting in August 1986.'.

The point of that amendment is that under the Democrats' proposal, which we are supporting, it may well be that a series of Bills will be left on the Notice Paper between May and August of this year. What we would like to do is to preserve the opportunity to send those Bills to relevant standing committees of the Senate. Honourable senators will recall that there have been a number of attempts to formalise the arrangements for Bills to be given more detailed committee consideration by sending them to our standing committees. There is usually a reluctance on the part of the Government to see that done. To this day, we have been unable to obtain the support of the Democrats for a number of specific proposals but, after discussion with them, I think we are in agreement that where Bills will be held over in any event it may well be useful for them to be given some detailed scrutiny during the recess period so that we can examine them more carefully and deal with them perhaps more expeditiously when we return to Canberra in the Budget session in August.

The purpose of my amendment is simply to give the Senate the opportunity, where Bills are to be adjourned until the August Budget sittings, to move that those Bills be sent off to the standing committees. I stress that that is in no way pre-empting the Senate's decision on any particular Bill. That will be a matter for consideration when we move for the reference of any Bill to a committee for such consideration. I suggest that that could be a valuable way for us to test whether we will get a better legislative performance out of this Parliament by having a number of Bills subjected to that sort of committee scrutiny rather than merely dealt with in the second reading debate and in the Committee of the Whole.

The motion which has been moved tonight may be a very useful step in introducing more regular and ordered procedures in this place which would give us a better opportunity to perform our legislative function. I have been somewhat disappointed at the low level of senatorial interest in the purely legislative function of this place. For most of us the politics of immediate issues tends to take precedence. Any opportunity we can take to provide a better atmosphere and a better set of procedures for the exercise of our purely legislative functions is worth trying. I hope that, from this experiment, we might see, just as we saw with the establishment of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, another useful step in improving our performance as legislators. I say to the Manager of Government Business (Senator Grimes) that I can assure him in a totally non-partisan way that I think the problems his Government faces are totally similar to the problems which we faced in government. I believe that some of the changes that the Government has made, in particular the gradual extending of the sittings to a longer period in the year, are potentially positive changes. This new initiative may add to those changes and may lead to less defective legislation being foisted upon the Australian people.
Amendment agreed to.
