SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to Senator Chaney's amendment. The Government will not oppose and certainly will not divide on this amendment. I appreciate and I accept Senator Chaney's proposal as a positive proposal to try to improve the legislative function of this chamber. Unlike him, I think some of the changes we have made, including the setting up of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, have not brought about the great positive changes that some people would like to believe. Since I have been a member of the Senate the number of committees has increased and the work of those committees has increased.
—Not the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

—Certainly not. To start referring Bills willy-nilly to those committees might create considerable difficulty for those committees. Even in the time that I have been here people on committees have made some complaints about their capacity to keep up with the work. Therefore, I would be reluctant to see this process introduced without the introduction of some mechanism whereby the whole committee in question could be consulted on its capacity to deal sensibly with this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not add to the efficiency of this place if we add to what Senator Chaney perceives as an inefficient mechanism for dealing with legislation in this chamber a further inefficient mechanism whereby the committees of the Senate will deal with legislation. I can remember being on the Standing Committee on Social Welfare, or whatever it was called in those days, and one of the things that we dealt with, for some strange reason, was reports from statutory authorities which came in late. Until the former Senator Peter Rae and his Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, dealt with that issue, almost all statutory authorities seemed to bring in late reports, and the Standing Committee on Social Welfare, which really had no knowledge and not much interest in that process, used to deal with all of those endless late annual reports of statutory authorities in an afternoon and come up with some form of words which would please the Senate and make us all think that we had done the right thing.

My personal view is that the procedures in this place are defective. That does not mean I want to turn them upside down. But I think the Standing Orders Committee and all senators should look at them. Senators should start to look at the procedures we use to deal with legislation to see how sensible they are. They should see how sensible are some of the words that Ministers and members of the Opposition use when introducing legislation. It seems to me in this day and age they have little purpose, although I accept that the system of first, second and third readings was introduced to ensure that legislation was dealt with in a steady way and so that people could not rush legislation through the Parliament unnecessarily. But surely we can change the procedures and methods that we have used. One of those changes may involve the standing committees having a greater role in the consideration of legislation. But I think that that can only be done with the co-operation of the standing committees and the co-operation of the chairmen of those committees. I do not think it will assist us to have this chamber refer legislation to standing committees in a sort of offhand way, which is a great danger in the sorts of procedures that Senator Chaney talks about. I do not think it will do anything more than add another layer of inefficient procedures to the ones we have now.

As I say, we do not oppose the proposal. Quite frankly, one of the reasons that we do not oppose it is that we do not intend to introduce any legislation after 30 May. But if we do, I accept that Senator Chaney's proposal is a sensible one. If we as a government start to introduce legislation after 30 May and if that legislation will clearly not be dealt with until the Budget session, why should not the Senate standing committees, if they are willing to do so-or even if they are unwilling to do so-consider that legislation? If they are willing to do so we as a Senate can judge the efficiency and efficacy of their considerations at a later date. As Senator Chaney says, it will add a layer to the experience of the Senate when we consider changes to procedures at a later date. So I certainly do not oppose this amendment. But I give notice that if such a circumstance should arise, we would expect that the committees and the chairmen of those committees would be consulted before the Senate hands on legislation in that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should make it quite clear that this is not in any sense a proposal for indiscriminate reference of Bills. Each Bill will be examined on its merits and there will be consultation among the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and, one would hope, the Government to decide which Bills should be referred to committees and which committees should consider them. The views of the committees would also be taken into account. The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) has on the Notice Paper a motion to set up a mechanism to do this. That motion has not yet been proceeded with. We must establish a proper procedure for examining which Bills will benefit from referral and then see how it works. The committees, after all, are known as legislative and general purpose committees. In the past their efforts have been almost entirely general purpose, with a very minor legislative impact.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us try this proposal and see how it works. I think I can undertake on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition that there will be full consultation with all parties-certainly with the Democrats, in order to produce the numbers, but one would hope with the Government, and in particular the chairmen of government committees. We do not want to foist a Bill on a committee which is reluctant to take it. On the other hand, we are not prepared to give the Government the power to veto Bills which should properly be referred to committees. I think what might emerge from this is a proper consultative procedure to establish which Bills will benefit from being referred to committees. Also there will be a judgment by the Senate as to whether the Senate as a whole benefits from a proper study of legislation and public examination by a committee before the Senate considers it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the two amendments, I am very happy to accept the amendment to my motion moved by the Government.
—We have already carried it.
—Yes.
—Ex post facto happiness.

—Yes, ex post facto happiness. With regard to Senator Chaney's amendment, I think the comments made by the Manager of Government Business (Senator Grimes) are certainly appropriate. Senator Chaney in his comments referred to the recess period. The proposal has been made that committees will sit probably for the entire time of what is normally called the recess. The general proposition that Senator Chaney has proposed previously-Senator Hamer has been one of the major movers in the discussion of this by senators-is an excellent one. However, I would like briefly to go through the problems that we have had in regard to the proposal. One is that the resources that are available to the Senate in terms of Hansard, staffing and so on have not yet been resolved. Fairly obviously, there is a very important resource problem with regard to committees. I am a member of a committee which has been waiting for some weeks for the Hansard before we can get on with the work, because the Committee really needs the Hansard to be able to carry out the review. We have found out that the reason why the Hansard has been delayed-it is entirely appropriate that it should be delayed-is the urgency of another committee's transcript. If we add to this, I think the system will actually crumble. I do not think that Hansard has the resources or the capacity to deal with that extension.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the sitting times for such committees is becoming a massive problem. I sit on three or four committees. One spends a considerable amount of time shuffling through one's diary, trying to find a date on which a reasonable quorum can be found. By and large most people say: `No, I can't do that because I am on this committee or that committee'. It is not that the members are doing work in their electorates, but that the committee work is growing enormously. In other words, there must be a rationalisation of sitting times to allow these things to occur.

There must be a rationalisation of the Estimates committees, standing committees and select committees. There was a proposal, which I thought was a very good one, for the collapsing of the Estimates and standing committees and possibly an extension to cover all portfolio areas. I think we could probably encompass in that most of the select committees. If we picked up all the portfolio areas there would probably be an appropriate standing committee to which one could refer ad hoc matters as they arise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you worked on select committees?

—Yes, I am a very strong supporter of select committees. We are talking about the rationalisation of all Senate committees. Senator Grimes raised the point in his first contribution to this debate that there was an obvious need for the extension of the sitting times of this chamber. Until we come to grips with that, I think we are probably just playing around. In many ways I think we must recognise that this chamber is unable to do the type of work it is doing. This is not necessarily because of the increase in the amount of legislation. The most fascinating increase in the amount of work is in terms of reports-which are hardly considered in this place, having regard to the vast amount of work that goes into them-papers, ministerial statements and other such matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is a need for an overall consideration of the work. With all due respect to the comments made by Senator Chaney and Senator Hamer, I really cannot see how we can pick out one of those items without dealing with the others. I think they are interrelated. It is difficult, I know, to treat them in that way. But without treating them as interrelated problems, I do not think we have any means of moving at all. That might be a dispiriting message. Possibly we will have to go back to Senator Grimes to see whether the parties can come up with some reasonable sitting times. Perhaps in those sitting times we can set down sitting times for the committees as well. I think we need to move next in that direction. If that were so, we may very well be able to accommodate some more legislative matters than we have been able to accommodate at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been suggested here that Bills be referred to committees. But before that takes place I think there should be a thorough investigation into what resources the committees have. In my experience in this place there have been too many references that have proved too much for a lot of committees. The resources are simply not there. If a Bill is put before a committee and it does not have the resources, I do not believe that committee can do the work. I have run into problems where there is a lack of human resources. I am not criticising the staff in any way, but I think that many of the committees do not have the right type of staff at times. We may need lawyers or we may need all sorts of experts and the cost of having such people available would be enormous. There is an enormous amount of work going on in committees, as Senator Macklin said, and senators are trying to find the time to make themselves available. We have to do our electoral work and it is very difficult to find the time to serve on committees. I would recommend a thorough investigation into all the resources needed if Bills are to go before those committees. I simply rise to give the Senate that warning.
