SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate began the second reading debate on the Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986 when we sat last Friday afternoon. I remind the Senate that this is the second occasion on which we have had a general debate on trade practices amendments. The Government introduced a general Bill for that purpose last year and then only a short time ago it split that Bill-debate on which was proceeding in this place until recently-into two Bills, one of which, the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill was disposed of and passed by the Senate last week. This second Bill contains all the other provisions in the original trade practices amendment legislation, other than the question of the transfer of a monopoly power or a bare monopoly, which was the subject of a great deal of interest in the media and in this place as well because of the proposed takeover of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd by Bell Resources Ltd. However, that particular issue, which started off as relatively minor in this debate and which assumed such large proportions in recent weeks, has not been disposed of and we are back to the original Bill without that particular amendment which caused all that debate.

SPEECH.PARA: When we were debating this matter on Friday afternoon I indicated that the Opposition was opposed to the present Bill-that is, the series and miscellany of amendments which the Government has put forward to the original Trade Practices Act. We are opposed to it because of the very grave addition to regulation which it imposes upon the business community in particular, the added costs that will impose on the business community thereby reducing the ability of that community to play its part in improving the economy and increasing employment and job opportunities for people.

I had been referring to the fact that this was not just the view of the Opposition, that in fact in the last 20 or 30 years Parliament-by the magnitude and complexity of legislation of which this Trade Practices Act is a very good example and these proposed amendments are a further example and by the regulation making power which arises under so much legislation that the Government exercises with carefree abandon-has made so many regulations, all of which add to the problems of the business community. It has reached such a stage that even the present Hawke Government, with all its fondness for legislating answers and solutions to all problems, has begun to realise this fact itself. In fact, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, just prior to the last election in December 1984, started to give some recognition to this in public. It may be significant that this recognition was only being made in the course of that fairly unsuccessful election campaign which he embarked upon at the end of 1984. In November 1984 he certainly said that unnecessary, institutional and legal impediments needed to be removed from this country's productive resources.

Following that statement during the election campaign, he said in July last year that the Government would set up a body which was to be known as the Business Regulation Review Unit and that this was being done in some recognition of this problem that he had spoken of on behalf of the Government in the 1984 election campaign. At the end of last year in a speech to the Business Council of Australia, the Prime Minister said he understood the complaints of the business world about the ever increasing volume of legislation and the burdens that that had placed on business. He said that his Government would do something about it. This Government is very good at rhetoric and saying that it will do something about problems, but it is not so good at delivering the goods on these matters. At the very same time as the Prime Minister was making these statements at the end of last year to the Business Council of Australia, the Government introduced this piece of legislation which, in itself, is another classic example of the type of regulatory burden of which the business community has been complaining for so long.

The Business Regulation Review Unit reported to the Government a couple of months ago and has in fact pointed out that there are 16,400 Commonwealth public servants engaged in or supporting those engaged in business regulation of one sort or another under a vast range of pieces of legislation. I point out that that number of 16,400 public servants refers only to the Commonwealth public servants who are engaged directly in business regulation. It certainly does not deal with the enormous number of State public servants or those who work on statutory authorities, either Federal or State, who are engaged in regulation of one sort or another. Furthermore, it does not include the tremendous burdens that are imposed upon the business community by having to employ servants and agents to comply in various ways with government regulations. The new Business Regulation Review Unit of the Commonwealth Government will have no fewer than 16,500 Commonwealth Government employees engaged in its activities and it estimates that the cost of employing those officers will be no less than $700m per year.

One of the more interesting and rather startling and disturbing conclusions of the Unit is that this figure deals only with those Commonwealth public servants who will be engaged directly in this activity. It has estimated that there could be up to twice that number of public servants indirectly engaged in business regulation. There are 16,500 employees identified as being directly engaged in business regulation and possibly up to double that number of employees will spend part of their time on it indirectly, in one form or another, as a result of the activities of those 16,500 employees who will be heavily engaged. Even if one is generous to the Government and takes a rough figure of half that number, one ends up with something like 20,000 Commonwealth Government public servants who will be engaged in business regulation in one form or another at a total cost to the Government of over $1 billion a year.

Despite this advice from the Government's Business Regulation Review Unit, which the Government set up with a great deal of fanfare from the Government about how the Government will do something about it, the Government has introduced legislation of this kind which will only add to the burdens, will no doubt increase the number of public servants involved in these activities and will further increase the Government's expenditure on this type of activity. I instance that as another example of the way in which this Government makes sympathetic noises about this, that or the other problem and says it can understand it and will so do something about it, yet it comes into this place with legislation which does absolutely the reverse. It is another classic example of the continuing hypocrisy of the Hawke Government, which more and more people are coming to understand and resent, as is becoming clearer every day.

This legislation to amend the Trade Practices Act has approximately 70 clauses, most of which will increase the burden on the community by regulation of one sort or another. It will greatly expand ministerial discretions, without any review whatever, despite much rhetoric from this Government about how there ought to be proper, independent reviews of decisions of Ministers. The Bill will also add to the duplication of Commonwealth and State regulation under the consumer protection laws. The legislation has given rise to a great deal of criticism. A great many submissions have been made to members of Parliament, submissions which I am sure all of us have seen at some stage or another.

I list the organisations which have made very substantial and weighty submissions in criticism of one aspect or another of this legislation: The Confederation of Australian Industry, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, the Business Council of Australia, the Law Council of Australia, the Metal Trades Industry Association Inc., the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association, the Association of Consulting Engineers of Australia, the Royal Australian Institute of Architects, the Queensland Chapter of the Association of Consulting Engineers of Australia, the Australian Institute of Quantity Surveyors and the Food Industry Council of Australia. All of those bodies-there may be others as well-have made fairly major criticisms of some or all of the amendments contained in this Bill. Although one could say that some of these organisations may have dealt with matters of self-interest, the fact of the matter is that many have come forward with very substantial criticisms. The Law Council, which has a direct personal interest in only some of these provisions, has given a very impressive survey of the various deficiencies of this legislation.

The way the Government has dealt with these submissions is a very worrying aspect of this legislation. The submission from the Confederation of Australian Industry deals with the way in which the Government dealt with the question of product safety and product information, on which a whole new Division will be included in the Trade Practices Act. The CAI has pointed out that the Bill contains 11 1/2 pages of provisions relating to the recall powers. That was done after the Government had issued a discussion paper in relation to certain options about product recall and had given a closing date for comment on that paper of 31 August last year. Having received all those submissions, the Government brought legislation into the Parliament within five weeks of that date. That is all the attention the Government seems to have given to some of the very detailed and thoughtful comments which were made to it in relation to this matter. It is perfectly clear that the Government, having sought comment on certain matters, must have had its legislation in place and did not see fit to devote much attention to some of the comments that were made. Indeed, the way in which the Government has introduced its amendments to this legislation at a very late stage of the consideration of this Bill would bear out the fact that its so-called consultation with industry was really little less than a hoax.

There are a large number of most objectionable features in this legislation. It deals with a wide range of aspects of the Trade Practices Act. Virtually every provision contained in the legislation will add to the complexity, burden and cost of business regulation. One of the most worrying things is that it will introduce very great ministerial discretions which cannot be reviewed under the various processes that have been set up over the past 10 years or so, with bipartisan support in this Parliament, to provide adequate ways of reviewing ministerial discretions. All of that progress that has been made on a bipartisan basis in this Parliament is ignored, and great new ministerial powers are given. We shall be dealing with those in greater detail in Committee. But the Government is setting back the clock 10 years, if not more, by the wholesale adoption and introduction into the Trades Practices Act of these great new ministerial discretions, which are entirely unreview- able. They cannot be reviewed under the ordinary administrative review process or in the courts of law.

It is for that combination of reasons that the Opposition will vote against the second reading of this legislation. If, unfortunately, it is passed, throughout the Committee stage we shall be endeavouring to ameliorate as far as possible the very large number of objectionable features of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly at this stage on a point with regard to the way in which the Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986 has been handled. The Bill is the same as the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985, with the omission of that section that we have already dealt with in another Bill-section 50 (2C). This particular Bill was passed by the House of Representatives on 20 March, and a message from the Governor-General was announced recommending an appropriation of revenue for the purposes of the this Bill. That is the part to which I wish to refer-message 125 from the Governor-General. In passing, I comment that I find it rather odd. Presumably we are not paying the Governor-General enough, because he is not provided with any letterhead paper any longer; it is simply a sheet of ordinary paper. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In accordance with the requirements of section 56 of the Constitution, the Governor-General recommends to the House of Representatives that an appropriation of revenue be made for the purposes of a Bill for an Act to make various amendments of the law relating to trade practices. 20th March 1986.
It should be observed in passing that the prohibition contained in the first paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution is:
Proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys, or imposing taxation, shall not originate in the Senate-
and that those requirements which are contained in section 56 are:

. . . appropriation of revenue or moneys shall not be passed unless the purpose of the appropriation has in the same session been recommended by message of the Governor-General to the House in which the proposal originated-

These are not justifiable but are matters, basically, for the Houses of Parliament and for the Governor-General. The claim that the Bill which we are debating, the Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986, is a money Bill-that is, that it appropriates revenues or moneys-is clearly false and, I believe, must have been known to be false when the people who engaged in that exercise made such a claim and so recommended to the Governor-General. It appears to be based on the assertion that any Bill which in order to appropriate might require an appropriation or an increase in appropriation is itself an appropriation Bill. This is so clearly contrary to the language of the Constitution and to the plain meaning of the legislation that I do not believe that it could be believed by those who were asserting it.

If one looks at section 53 of the Consti- tution-there are some remarks of High Court judges with regard to this particular section when it came before them in other ways-one sees that the relevant paragraph says that the Senate `may at any stage' return a Bill to the House of Representatives with requests, and this, indeed, is what has been involved in the exercise that we have been going through. If we look at that particular exercise, we see that `at any stage' can be interpreted as meaning at any stage in the Senate's initial consideration of the Bill the Senate could press a request-as it has, indeed, successfully done in the past-and, if it wanted to, could so rearrange its own Standing Orders in such a way as to have many stages of a Bill, and hence have innumerable opportunities to press requests by simply constructing it in such a way.

I refer also to the fact that at the Consti- tutional Convention an amendment to insert the word `once' in the relevant paragraph of section 53 was defeated. Hence, I believe that there was an understanding of what was going on and what could possibly go on at a later stage. Delegates to the Constitutional Convention, including Sir Edmund Barton, indicated in their remarks that the difference between an amendment and a request would be one of procedure only, and that obviously has turned out to be the case, the rationale for the difference being to preserve the right of the House of Representatives to make in a Bill any amendments involving additional appropriation or taxation. The money required for the operation of the provisions of this particular Act is appropriated by the annual Appropriation Bill, as is indicated by the explanatory notes on the Estimates provided by the Attorney-General's Department. Therefore, the claim that the Trade Practices Revision Bill is a money Bill is transparently incorrect.

I believe that here we are looking at advice which was given. In our early views with regard to this Bill we were looking at a division of these Bills for tactical purposes, as the Government has also done. At that stage, I understand that the Government was given some advice that it was not able to do so in the Senate because it was a money Bill. Of course, neither of those reasons stands up. The Senate is quite able to divide Bills if it wishes to do so, whether they be money Bills or not. Section 56 of the Constitution provides:

A . . . proposed law for the appropriation of revenue or moneys shall not be passed unless the purpose of the appropriation has in the same session been recommended by message of the Governor-General in the House in which the proposal originated.

Presumably, it was in following that section that that particular message from the Governor-General was delivered. I think it can be seen that section 53 and section 56 are expressed in similar terms, and that a Bill which could not be introduced into the Senate because it would appropriate revenue or moneys would require a Governor-General's message to the House of Representatives recommending the purpose of the appropriation.

It is fairly obvious to me that this misleading advice has been given purely for the purpose of obstructing senators and the Senate in the performance of their legislative activities. This is an incredibly serious situation. It is one which has bedevilled relationships between this House and the House of Representatives for some considerable time and one which was eventually resolved with regard to the annual services of government provisions and the way in which they should operate. That has operated fairly successfully over the years since that pact was made. I suspect in particular that this operation was aimed at the Australian Democrats because of our commitment not to block Supply.

If the claim were carried to its logical conclusion, it would mean that virtually every Bill introduced into the Parliament would be held to be a money Bill. It would also mean that every amendment moved in the Senate would be regarded as affecting some appropriation and thereby falling under the prohibition contained in the third paragraph of section 53, which provides that the Senate may not amend any Bill `so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people'. Government advisers are clearly trying to steer members of parliament into an acceptance of what can only be called bizarre interpretations in order to prevent and hinder what they regard as troublesome interference on the part of the operation of the Senate with regard to its correct legislative role. I believe that the Government, in terms of its operation in this chamber, should not go down this path but should follow the procedures which have been used successfully since the compact was decided and agreed upon.

I am also particularly disturbed at the strategy which is involved here and which, of course, involves the Governor-General's message. It seems to me that the message in this case is being used for a partisan purpose in this chamber. I think considerable difficulties would arise in future if this strategy were pursued as a tactic. I would be very interested to hear the Minister explain, at an appropriate stage of the Bill, why it has occurred and why it has occurred in this way. If the Minister maintains that this is a money Bill, I would like him to point to the specific clauses of the Bill that he believes support his case. Presumably he is not going to refer to legal aid which is not dealt with in this Bill and which at one stage was one of the reasons trotted out by various people why this is in fact a money Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating part of what was the former Trade Practices Amendment Bill. This Bill, which I understand technically still resides in the Senate, has been overtaken by and split into two separate Bills. The Trade Practices Amendment Bill has become the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill and the Trade Practices Revision Bill. The Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill has been passed by both Houses with no major disagreements. The Bill now before the Senate, the Trade Practices Revision Bill, contains several elements, as did the earlier Trade Practices Amendment Bill, to which the Opposition is very strongly opposed. The reasons for our opposition have, I believe, been made clear by Senator Durack this evening and by other speakers, including Senator Durack and me, in the earlier debate on the fuller Trade Practices Amendment Bill. Our opposition to the various areas and elements of the Bill before us at the moment-the Trade Practices Revision Bill-will be spelt out in greater detail during the Committee stage of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like briefly tonight and in relatively broad terms to reiterate our main problems with this Bill. The first problem is that the original Bill, along with many other pieces of legislation, was steamrolled and forced through the House of Representatives in a totally undemocratic fashion late last year, at the end of the last session. In fact, so eager was the Government to get that Bill through the House last year that it was circulating amendments to its own proposals on the very day that the Bill was debated and passed through the House of Representatives. What a mockery that makes of the democratic parliamentary processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Consultation at work.

—Consultation at work. Par excellence, Senator Evans. The Minister has put it in a nutshell. This very full piece of legislation was very important to the whole of the business community of Australia. It was important not only to large business but also, more importantly, to small business. The Government forced that Bill through the House of Representatives in an unseemly hasty manner a very few weeks after the closing date for submissions the Government had asked for in relation to an exposure draft. Quite obviously, the legislation was introduced at a speed which made it impossible for the Government to take into account the very real and very serious objections that the business community put to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Government as a general proposition that, if we are to have responsible and serious government in this country, a much greater regard must be paid to the due processes of the consideration of the important issues of the day that affect us as a community or as important sections of the community. I believe that we do ourselves and the democratic process a very serious disservice by treating important legislation in the way that we so frequently do. As parliamentarians we have a responsibility to say to governments of whatever political persuasion: `Let us have a proper look at what we are doing because if we do not we will get bad government, bad laws and we will rightly deserve, as parliamentarians, the opprobrium of the community'. I believe that we, and particularly the Government, are running that risk in respect of the Bill now before the Senate, and deservedly so.

The Opposition's second reason for opposing this Bill is that it is anti-business. It is anti-business because it seeks to impose yet another layer of unwarranted, unnecessary and undesirable regulation on the business sector. The Bill seeks to enforce the entrenched ideology of the Hawke Government by being anti-business. Despite the protestations to the contrary in the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and in some contributions made in the Senate and the House of Representatives in respect of the earlier Bills, this Bill is not only anti-business but it is anti-consumer because it has very significant cost implications of a negative nature for the consumer. The cost of additional regulation has to be passed on and in the end it is the consumer who pays. This is an anti-business and anti-consumer piece of legislation because it is extremely costly to the consumer and extremely regulatory to business as a whole. We do not have an exact costing of the legislation but it has been estimated that the direct cost to the business community will be of the order of $50m annually and could be considerably higher. If that cost is multiplied throughout the community, the costs to the community will be very considerable indeed.

We have in this Bill a repeat of the old Australian Labor Party socialist philosophy that industry and the community can be improved by more and more regulation and involvement by government in telling sections of the community what to do and what is in their best interests. This Bill flies in the face of the Government's professed concern over the last couple of years to reduce business regulation. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his 1984 election speech only 18 months ago said:

Over the next term of Parliament we will remove legislation and regulation which is damaging to business and employment expansion and which is not justified as an efficient means of promoting economic and social objectives.

That is a direct quote from the Prime Minister's 1984 election policy speech. Yet in mid-1985, the Government, to its credit, set up a business regulation review unit to apply a cost-benefit approach to new regulatory proposals and to seek out existing regulations which might be eliminated. Not one of those objectives leading to the establishment of the business regulation review unit appears to have been met in the Bill now before the Senate. The first report of the business regulation review unit was released only a couple of months ago. Amongst other things the report said that the unit had found that more than 30,000 Commonwealth public servants had been employed in administering business regulations at an annual cost to the taxpayer of $1.4 billion. Coincidentally, $1.4 billion per year happens to be the amount of money that the Government is trying to chop off its expenditure commitments for this forthcoming year. So we are not talking about chicken feed; we are talking about very significant amounts of money. We have the Government's own regulatory review unit saying that we have 30,000 Commonwealth public servants employed in administering business regulations-let alone all the other regulations that government gets involved with-at an annual cost to the taxpayer of $1.4 billion. That is an estimate for the Commonwealth Public Service alone.

The Secretary of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Overland, is reported as saying that for every officer employed by the Commonwealth there is at least another employed in the private sector. That would add another $1.4 billion to the cost to the community. Mr Overland is also reported as saying that if we add State and local government regulation, the cost can be quadrupled. On that basis, the total annual cost to the community of the regulation of business in Australia could well exceed $10,000m per year. That is about $600 for every man, woman and child in this country per year. Even if that is an over-estimate a substantial discounting of that figure would still lead to the inevitable conclusion that the community faces an enormous cost through business regulation. It is an enormous drag on business activity. No wonder that we are rapidly falling behind as a nation in terms of our international cost competitiveness. We need to get off the back of business, not to strangle it with an ever-increasing burden of regulation. That is not to say that regulation from time to time is not appropriate or desirable. But what it does mean is that before we impose more and more regulation on business it must be given the fullest scrutiny and it must be given the fullest justification. We have neither of those criteria filled in this particular case.

I will reserve detailed comments on the provisions of the Bill until the Committee stage, but I foreshadow that there are several issues that concern me very much and, as has been outlined earlier by Senator Durack, that concern the Opposition. The proposed changes to section 46 are an obvious example of that. Without making a final judgment on section 46 I am extremely concerned that organisations like the Business Council of Australia and the Law Council of Australia which have considered these matters and provisions very carefully have come to the conclusions that they have. I quote, for example, from a letter to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) from the Business Council. It states:

The cumulative effect of the changes to Section 46, as they now stand, means that the primary thrust of the Act will be directed towards damage to individual competitors rather than damage to competition itself.
It goes on to state:

If we are to ensure the maintenance of a vigorous, efficient and internationally competitive Australian industry, we believe there is an urgent need for the Government to remove unnecessary uncertainties and confusion which currently exist in the proposed amendments to section 46.

The thing that I find interesting and very surprising, and most of all very disappointing, is that despite those comments that have been given to the Government quite some time ago, and despite the debates that we have had in this chamber and in the other chamber on the Trade Practices Amendment Bill, the Government appears to have taken not one whit of notice about the expressions of concern that have been voiced from such wide-ranging and very important sections of the community. If the business groups in this country are saying the type of thing that I have just given as an example, surely it is incumbent on the Government at least to give those claims the closest scrutiny and consider- ation. There is no evidence whatsoever, as I have said, that the Government has done that. Section 46 is a matter of major concern, so are other provisions in the Bill, for example, the mandatory recall provisions in the legislation.

Several well researched submissions have been made to Government on the matter of recall procedures. Even though it is a reserve power that is being proposed there are various matters for concern in that. For example, as I understand it, the reserve power does not contain a requirement that before a mandatory control power is used a product must first of all have been banned from sale. The issue of the reserve power to recall products is not, as I understand it, subject to independent administrative law review. In terms of the mandatory provisions there is the whole question of the role of administrative decisions and administrative law, vis-a-vis the common law processes of this nation. That is another area that certainly concerns the Opposition.

Beyond these two and other specific provisions in the Bill I believe that there is-I am not suggesting that it can necessarily be done in the context of this Bill-a very urgent need to look more closely at the whole philosophy behind the Trade Practices Act. The history of this Act goes back a long way. Consideration of it goes back to the days of the Menzies Government. We then had the impact on it of the Whitlam Government's ideology and policies. Then we went through the Fraser period and now we are in the Hawke Government period. I have very considerable doubts as to whether any of us have looked sufficiently at the Trade Practices Act as it now stands to see whether it is an internally consistent document in terms of its philosophy and its spirit. I believe that we have not looked at it to that extent and that it is not such a document at the moment. I do not believe that it is internally consistent and I do not believe that it has the overall interests of what we need in this country in terms of growth and vitality and the encouragement of individual incentive, entrepreneurship and enterprise. We need to look at the relevance of the Trade Practices Act to the needs of Australia in the 1980s. We talk about the need for rationalisation. We talk about the need for restructuring. All that is very desirable, but we have Acts of Parliament with provisions that are contrary to the encouragement of some of those processes and to the encouragement of greater competition and the international competitiveness on which this nation will depend for the future living standards of all Australians.

There are some very considerable issues at stake here. I hope that the Trade Practices Act-and I said this in the earlier debate on the Trade Practices Amendment Bill-is something that this Government will look at. Certainly, we on this side of the Senate will be doing so. I believe that the Trade Practices Act is in the wrong portfolio. Essentially, it is a piece of business legislation. Sure, it is a piece of law, but in my view the Trade Practices Act should be within the portfolio of a Minister with specific economic and business responsibilities. The way that this Act is framed and administered is, as I said before, of vital importance to the whole operation of the private sector. It is for that reason that I believe its carriage ought to be with a Minister with specific economic or business responsibilities. I appreciate that this is not a matter for debate in the context of this present Bill, but it is a matter that I believe we as a Parliament will need to consider and should be considering, in the not too distant future.

I have very grave reservations about this Bill. The Bill that we have is designed to split the earlier piece of legislation that we debated a month or so ago. The reason for the split was occasioned by the attempted takeover by Bell Resources Ltd of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. It was a piece of expediency on the Government's part to split the legislation. The split in no way removes-indeed, it heightens to some extent-the concerns we had about the earlier piece of legislation. We on this side of the chamber certainly will be seeking from the Government in the remainder of this debate, particularly in the Committee stage, a much greater explanation of the reasons for some of its proposals. We will be continuing, as we did with the earlier legislation, to oppose those proposals very strongly indeed because we on this side of the chamber want a healthy, dynamic and growing private and business sector in this country, which is in obvious contrast to a government which produces the sort of legislation we have before us in this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986 which is before us tonight is the remaining nine-tenths of the old Trade Practices Amendment Bill that was split into two following problems that the Government faced with regard to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and its attempted takeover by Bell Resources Ltd which caused the Government to separate the amendment to section 50 of the Trade Practices Act with regard to mergers. We dealt with that last week. It was an interesting manoeuvre by the Government, which was aware of the fact that, while the Opposition was supportive of the changes to section 50 that were proposed in the original Trade Practices Amendment Bill, that was about the only section of the legislation that the Opposition was in fact supporting, whereas the Australian Democrats were far more supportive of the remainder of the original legislation which dealt with consumer protection.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short talked about the fact that the Bill before us tonight is anti-business legislation. I suggest that it is anti-bad business legislation and I remind him that the majority of the pieces of legislation which come before this place deal not with the 90 per cent of people or organisations that behave in an ethical or moral way but with the 10 per cent of those that do not. It is an attempt, in one form or another, to protect the potential victims of those people. That is as true of State legislation as it is of Federal legislation. After all, we would not need most Acts of Parliament if people behaved in the manner in which a lot of us would like to see.

This piece of legislation, in effect, is aimed at protecting consumers against organisations in the community far more powerful than those individual consumers-that is, businesses that engage in one form or another of restrictive trade practices and anti-competitive actions or businesses which misuse their market power generally. The legislation is aimed at protecting consumers-I am including in that term not just individuals in the community but also small businesses which are equally vulnerable to the predatory behaviour of some large and powerful organisations in the community-from businesses which are cavalier in their behaviour as far as measures such as recalling unsafe products are concerned, businesses which make misleading statements and businesses which in one way or another indulge themselves in unconscionable conduct of sorts, including charging small businesses for unsolicited advertising. As I said a moment ago, this legislation is aimed at protecting individual consumers and small business consumers from the anti-social behaviour of a minority of larger, more powerful organisations.

If, as Senator Short said, this is costly to the community, I suppose that is rather unfortunate but it is an inevitable consequence of a government attempting to do the socially appropriate thing, and that is to keep costs to individual consumers and small businesses to a minimum when those people are at the mercy of some unconscionable business conduct. I remind Senator Short and others that, after all, the Trade Practices Act was originally the brainchild of the Fraser Government. That Government can hardly be called the most socialist of governments that we have had in this country.

The important thing to remember about this legislation is that it is, in effect, putting into practice recommendations that have come from the Green Paper. Senator Short also said that the legislation had been rushed through the lower House. I am surprised that he did not add `in the small hours of the morning', which people usually dredge up to imply that something sinister has happened, instead of simply saying that the House of Representatives sits rather stupid hours. The legislation may have been pushed through the House of Representatives. That does not alter the fact that it has had some two years of community debate because it is two years since the Green Paper was brought out by the Government on the need to revise the Trade Practices Act for various reasons, including not only the fact that judges have an unfortunate habit of seeing things in black and white instead of paying more stringent attention to general reasonable interpretations of the law, but also the fact that things have been shown through business practices to have been omitted from the legislation.

The legislation does not, to our mind, go far enough. It does not, for example, pick up the recommendations made by the Green Paper about section 49. As I indicated in my speech in the second reading debate when the legislation was first introduced in February in this place, I will move amendments in some of those areas. One area that I did not raise in the speech in February was the question of amending section 74 to add an additional section with regard to the recall of dud or lemon cars. This amendment is more or less identical to the terms of the private member's Bill which I introduced on behalf of the Australian Democrats some years ago and which Senator Gareth Evans assured me the Government would not support at that time because the Trade Practices Act as a whole was being thoroughly investigated at that stage and no doubt this issue would be picked up then. Not surprisingly, however, I do not notice in the Bill any attention being paid to that extremely irritating and expensive problem that occurs to a number of consumers annually-that is, being sold a new car which, in effect, is a dud or a lemon because it presents its owners with persistent and recurring problems of one sort or another and they are unable to get any satisfaction from the dealer, the manufacturer or anyone else.

The legislation is based on similar legislation in the United States of America and I hope that the Government, or maybe even the Department which tells the Government what to do, will give it more sympathetic attention than it received that last time. I am not going to hold my breath waiting, however. I somehow suspect that this is too radical a reform to the Trade Practices Act even for the current Labor Government, given the current Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). It is remotely possible that it would have received more sympathetic attention under the previous Attorney-General, but we will never know. It is interesting, therefore, to reflect on the fact that it is the changes that are being made in this legislation to section 74 that are causing the most heartache to some sections of the community.

Since the Bill was held over from February while we debated whether Bell Resources Limited, John Elliott via the Elders organisation or anybody else should take over BHP, we have been inundated with letters of complaint from various organisations about section 74, some of which make the most extraordinary suggestions about the likely effect, including the fact that if a doctor does not cure a patient he or she is likely to find himself or herself in the middle of litigation. If a lawyer does not get his or her client off whatever charge he or she is on, that lawyer will be subject to litigation. Presumably if the average infant school teacher does not get the entire class totally conversant with its two times table he is, somehow or other, held to ransom pour faveur section 74, that lists the proposed changes to section 74. Many of them, of course, quote litigation in the United States of America and the massive pay outs and the problems with personal liability, insurance and so on. But to the best of my knowledge not even in that most litigious country has failure to cure somebody or win a case of itself been the cause of litigation and/or huge pay outs. As far as the massive premiums for personal liability insurance are concerned, I suggest that the professional groups concerned take that matter up with the insurance companies, that most conservative of organisations which are, I suspect, putting up their premiums in fright rather than on any actuarial basis.

One of the most intriguing letters that I had on this whole question of section 74 was a multi-page letter which set out what it said were the errors in basic assumptions, the fundamental inconsistencies and the discriminatory effect of section 74. In part, it had this to say:

The first basic assumption is that the amendment to section 74 will simply re-state the common law. The duties imposed on a professional by the common law are clearly stated in Section 1 of this submission.
I do not intend to go into that at the moment. The important sentences follow:
If section 74 were to apply to professionals there would be an implied term that the services rendered by them would be done with due care and skill . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a pretty shocking prospect.
—Yes, I thought that. For a moment when I first read the letter I thought perhaps I had misread it and that I had omitted something but, no, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: If section 74 were to apply to professionals there would be an implied term that the services rendered by them would be done with due care and skill . . .

That is something which I would have thought was devoutly to be wished anyway, but apparently, according to the writer of this submission, has never operated in the past and ought not happen in the future. He points-it is a he; I am not making that assumption-specifically to sub-section 74 (1) and goes on to say:

. . . and that where a client expresses an implication makes known to the professional any particular purposes for which the services are required or a result that he desires the services to achieve there is an implied warranty that those services will be reasonably fit for that purpose or are of a nature and quality that might be reasonably expected to achieve that result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous.
—Senator Gareth Evans suggests that that is outrageous. That is certainly the suggestion that is being made by the writer of this letter when he states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is an implied warranty that those services will be reasonably fit for that purpose or are of a nature and quality that might be reasonably expected to achieve that result.

So presumably if a client or a patient goes to a professional and requests a service which is unreasonable there is no obligation, one assumes, under the proposed changes to section 74, that the professional providing the service will be able to fulfil the request from the client. The letter goes on at some length in addition to that. It states:
This approach conflicts with the common law in two respects:-
(i) the test of care and skill-
I presume that the writer means due care and skill since that is what was used in an earlier paragraph-

is a higher duty than reasonable care and skill because under the common law the professional is not required to bring to the performance of his or her duty an extraordinary degree of care but only a reasonable and ordinary proportion of it; and

(ii) to imply a term that the services will achieve a desired result is beyond the common law position under which for example an attorney does not undertake that in all events you shall win your case and a surgeon does not undertake that he will perform a cure or an accountant that a business proposal will be acceptable.
I was not aware, apart from the strange reading that this person has made of the proposal, that the changes of the Act were going to somehow magically produce that end result. The letter continues:
The second basic assumption which is in error is that all professional advice guarantees the success of a venture or undertaking.

I have not been aware in the past that that, in fact, pertains. Doctors do not guarantee success of a venture or undertaking. Lawyers do not guarantee to get a person off whatever particular charge he is on; they simply undertake to do the best that due care and skill, reasonable care and skill, will produce. After all, the question is not whether a patient is successfully treated or whether a person successfully got off his case, but whether the person providing the service has provided a service which is fit for the purpose for which it was undertaken. So doctors are not encouraged to take off the wrong leg. They have always found themselves faced with litigation if they make a mistake of that sort in surgery. If a lawyer is blatantly negligent in a case he, too, can expect to find himself subject to even the common law.

I was intrigued to read an article in the Advertiser recently with regard to a custody matter. The father, who was seeking overnight access, and unsupervised access at that, was suspected of sexual abuse. According to the report the Queen Elizabeth Hospital written report was presented to the court. It clearly suggested that sexual abuse had taken place. However, because the mother's solicitor failed to appear at the hearing, the court was not told of an additional report that was available, which was still being prepared by the hospital and which could well have influenced the court in its decision. Assuming that the mother's solicitor failed to appear for some unsatisfactory reason, I would have thought that under common law that solicitor would have found himself or herself in some trouble. It appears to me that the changes to this legislation are not going to affect significantly the behaviour of reputable professionals, those who provide services that are fit for the purpose or those who apply due care and skill to the advice they give, to the submissions they prepare for clients or to the treatment they give their patients.

So all in all, as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, this legislation is a piece of pro-consumer legislation. If it is anti-business at all, it is anti-bad business. It sets out to give additional protection to vulnerable members of the community. It is not draconian in any way at all although, as I said earlier, it does not go far enough. We will be moving amendments that attempt to strengthen it. The Government has already picked up a number of our amendments and, indeed, picked up a number of amendments suggested by the Law Council of Australia. So the Government has not been totally derelict in its legislative duty. It has paid attention to those groups, including members of parliament, which have gone to it with reasonable suggestions for improving the legislation. I hope this legislation will be passed speedily in order to extend, as it should be extended, the sort of protection to consumers that they need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seem consistently to be following Senator Haines as trade practices Bills, or sections of them, come up for repeated debate in the Senate-a level of debate which, unfortunately, was not allowed by the Government to take place in the House of Representatives. Senator Haines has some fixation about the early hours of the morning which escapes me but in fact the Government, with unseemly haste, required this Trade Practices Revision Bill to be rushed through the House of Representatives in such a way that proper detailed examination could not take place-before, in fact, the Government's amendments to the Bill, which it had in place at that time, were put into the Bill. That was clearly a gross discourtesy to the House of Representatives. In fact, I think it was a gross distortion of the proper way in which any responsible government should conduct itself when introducing a Bill of such significance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Trade Practices Revision Bill is a Bill of enormous significance. It is not every day that we deal with Bills which are described by a Senate committee as `trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties'. This description of this Bill was made by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. This Bill involves reverse onuses of proof; one is guilty until one is proved innocent. Apart from things like that, I suppose it could be held by some people, including the Australian Democrats, that it is a charming Bill which does not go far enough. Maybe they want more reverse onuses. Maybe they want more trespassing on individual rights and liberties.

I must say that I find this Bill to be monumentally offensive to some basic principles. What is even more offensive is that the Government has determined deliberately not to respond to some major objections from organisations such as the Law Council of Australia, let alone from the Opposition, which it treats with contempt in matters like this. One would have thought that the Law Council of Australia would be a body worthy of more consideration than it has been given. It is true that when a Trade Practices Bill was last before us some amendments recommended by the Law Council were presented by the Opposition. In not every instance did the Government find them totally offensive; it objected just to the major ones and to most of them.

I stress that some of the matters that Senator Haines raised appear to suggest there is no such thing as common law in Australia. For her to talk about the gross negligence of a lawyer and how this sort of legislation is clearly needed in these sorts of matters is arrant nonsense. The fact is that the common law provides for penalties and awards damages against people who behave in this way. Although I did not want to be distracted into going into the individual elements of the Bill again, now that Senator Haines has mentioned the question of proposed new section 84, which relates to the relationships between professional persons and their clients, I want to say that it is incredibly boring to hear, over and over again in this chamber, people saying: `Well, it is true that there is a common law which does in fact provide opportunities for damages and so on, but we think that something should be done in this Bill for the sake of consumers. This is a piece of consumer legislation'.

I am one of those people who take the view that consumers should be within the embrace of the rule of law and that they have every right to take actions for damages, particularly as we have such a substantial system of legal aid for those who cannot afford to take such actions. If we follow the course that Senator Haines and the Labor Government want-namely, to impose this kind of consumer law on the community; that means on the business community and thereby on the whole community because the cost of this kind of thing gets passed on in higher prices-I hope that the Opposition's strong objection will receive sympathetic support within the community. Let us look at the question of professional persons and their clients. The Law Council quite clearly says:

The amendment would impose on engineers, accountants, architects, lawyers, doctors, dentists and many other professions (the vast majority of whom are in the small business sector) a statutory warranty that their services will achieve whatever result the client desires.
The Law Council continues:
This is tantamount to a warranty by the doctor that the patient will be cured or by an architect that an innovative design will work.

Although the Act would not affect all professional services provided on a personal basis within a State, the Act would apply to incorporated professional practices in the States and to those and individual practices in the Territories.
As I have already mentioned, the Law Council states:
The common law requires that a professional will use due care and skill and that, if negligent, a professional can be sued for damages.

Quite frankly, in my view, if the Government wants to impose itself in this area there are far better ways of doing that than having this kind of law. I suggest that if it wants to run consumer claim bureaus, let it do so. Doing it this way seems to me to impose quite intolerable burdens on professionals, who, generally, as I say, are small businesses in effect.

Apart from anything else there is the real threat that the imposition of this kind of warranty-this is a point that the Law Council makes-would tend to stifle innovation. People would not be prepared to take the risks involved in falling foul of the warranty required in this legislation. Innovation, in particular in medicine, architecture, engineering and other professions, would clearly be stifled. I cannot see the demand for the proposed change. I cannot understand why it should proceed. I am overjoyed that in the Committee stage the Opposition will be moving amendments that deal with that section.

I wish to deal with another couple of points Senator Haines made. She said: `Look, there has been plenty of debate on this measure because there were two years of community debate'. That is all very well. There may have been two years of community debate, but what about some answers to the specific points that have been raised repeatedly in this chamber in this debate? Of course, there was no opportunity for much debate in the House of Representatives, but here in the Senate one would hope to get some response to these matters of principle.

Just to add to the point-I mentioned this in the professional context-as to whether this is really a Bill that small business embraces totally to its heart, obviously professionals in small business do not do so because in recent times we have been inundated with correspondence from people from the professions outlining to us their real concerns about section 84 about which I have just spoken. On top of that, Mr D. M. Gibbons, the Executive Director of COSBOA, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, has noted in respect of one clause-I think it is clause 35-that:

. . . the proposal to give the Minister power to order a mandatory product recall in certain circumstances goes a little too far I feel, and could result in unnecessary and very costly and distortive decisions arising from interest group pressure rather than technical facts, for example.

Let us not get carried away with the idea that small business is united behind the Australian Democrats' united stand-it is unusual that they are united on this matter; this is one of the few matters on which they appear to be united-because the reality is that while some elements of the Bill certainly appeal to some sections of small business, other sections of the Bill do not appeal to other sections of small business. So let us get this in perspective. This is not, frankly, a Bill that suits all small businesses. It is a Bill that is oppressive to the great bulk of businesses in Australia, including many small businesses. As Mr Gibbons says, it is a Bill that could result in unnecessary, very costly and distortive decisions arising from interest group pressures.

The reality is that this Bill, like so many consumerist Bills, provides an excessive level of power to a developing group in this community which enjoys nothing more than being, if one likes, the Australian representatives of the Naderist movement in America. Many of these consumer groups consist of people whose bona fides I suggest, are not outstanding, people who do not have a genuine interest in the consumer but who have a consuming interest in getting stuck into business of any kind. It disappoints me that in many ways government grants through various bodies appear to have been given to a whole group of these consumer bodies, some of which appear to be no more than fronts for some individual unions, particularly in Victoria. It is extraordinary to recognise that the office addresses of quite a group of Victorian consumerist organisations appear to be the same as those of the metal workers union. Perhaps that is not a matter to be developed at great length at the moment. But it does seem to me that this consumer movement has been misused quite disgracefully in some areas-I am not saying everywhere-by people whose motives have absolutely nothing to do with the best interests of consumers and who have an industrial or political motive which appears to me to be far more disruptive and hostile to the business environment, and certainly very additive to the costs of items produced in Australia, than it is of looking after the interests of consumers.

Let me deal further with another problem about this Bill which relates to a basic principle which concerns me immensely. I refer to reversing the onus of proof. The late Senator Alan Missen was a member of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills when the question of the onus of proof in this matter was raised. I mention his name because, of course, he was a champion, as are many on both sides of the House, of that principle, particularly when it involved matters of as serious a nature as this, in which the penalties can be severe. It interests me that in justifying this reverse onus of proof the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) stated:

. . . where a matter is peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant, or, alternatively, the Crown would have great expense or difficulty in establishing the issue which could readily and cheaply be proved by the defendant, a reversal of the persuasive onus is permissible.

This is justifying the reverse onus involved in this matter, to which the Law Council, of course, has quite properly and sensibly objected. The reversal of the onus of proof is in relation to representations made by a company and the consequences flowing from a representation that is deemed to be misleading when it relates to a forecast for the future. The Attorney-General, in responding to concerns by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, said that in Thompson v. Master touch TV Services (1977), Franki J. held that:

. . . a prediction or statement as to the future is not false within the words of section 59 (1) if it proves to be incorrect, unless it is a false statement as to an existing or past fact which may include the state of mind of the person making the statement or of a person whose state of mind may be imputed to the person making the statement.
The Attorney-General continued:

His Honour also held that a promoter's promise or prediction about the future performance or profitability of a business opportunity is not caught by section 59 (1) unless it can be shown that the defendant `did not believe that the forecast or prediction would be satisfied or was recklessly indifferent concerning the forecast or prediction.
The problem, as I see it, is that the Attorney-General continues:
It is virtually impossible in most cases to obtain conclusive proof of lack of belief or recklessness from surrounding circumstances and without an admission of guilt from the defendant.
This would suggest that one cannot get any successes in this area. I am not convinced, I must say, at this stage that that is so. The Attorney-General states:

This is because the circumstances surrounding the prediction or forecast (ie. the grounds on which the defendant makes the statement) are matters peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant. In the Mastertouch case, the information was dismissed because the informant had not satisfied the Court that the defendant did not believe the forecast or prediction was true. The defendant did not go into evidence, so there was no evidence as to the state of mind of its manager.

If it is impossible or virtually impossible to get such successful prosecutions, I must admit I am intrigued by the number of cases that I have here that indicated findings that involve successful prosecutions. It may well be that in some of those cases the finding emerged from an admission of guilt by the defendant. But let us return to the Mastertouch situation. The Attorney-General says:
In the Mastertouch case, the information was dismissed because the informant had not satisfied the Court that the defendant did not believe the forecast or prediction was true.
The extract from the case that I have here deals with it as follows:

An operator of a business which involved the arranging for portraits to be painted in Taiwan from photographs advertised for an agent in Canberra to serve as retail outlets for the paintings. The advertisement suggested that the agent should earn a minimum of $400 per week. In fact the purchasers of agencies only earned $45 in seven months. The Commission was unsuccessful in proceedings under s. 59 because the section relates to businesses carried on at a person's home whereas the agency in question in this case related to a business to be carried on from a person's home . . .

Perhaps the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) who represents the Attorney-General can explain to me which of these two versions of the Mastertouch case is correct-whether it is because the informant had not satisfied the court that the defendant did not believe the forecast, or whether it is because of that technical difference between `at' a person's home and `from' a person's home. I would be interested to find out whether this summary from a highly reputable organisation which provides information in these matters is correct.

Let us look at some other cases in which this matter has been successfully prosecuted. Another one is Wilde v. Menville Pty. Ltd. in 1981-which is well after 1977, of course-in which a secondhand truck dealer who sold trucks by falsely representing to purchasers that they could obtain employment from nominated sources if they bought a truck from the defendant was found to have breached section 59 (2). Fines totalling $105,500 were imposed. In another case, Ducret v. Colourshot Pty Ltd. in 1981, a company which advertised for sale franchises for collection agents for film to be processed by the company, and which included in its advertisements reference to potential weekly earnings which were grossly in excess of the actual earning rate, was found to have breached section 59 (2). Fines totalling $130,000 were imposed. In Walter v. Viney, 1982, in an action for damages for breach of section 59 (2), the applicant alleged that he was induced to lease a concrete truck and purchase of franchise from the company with which the defendants were associated by statements made by the defendant about the company's business and the income a franchise could expect to earn. The court held that on the evidence no statements had been made which were false or misleading in the material case. That is another strike against the existing legislation. On the other hand, in Reardon v. Aquajet Holdings (SA) Pty Ltd, 1982, a manufacturer of carpet cleaning machines which sold the machines to persons answering employment advertisements for cleaners which stated that the position offered a return of approximately $400 to $800 a week was found to have breached section 59 when the earnings of those persons who purchased the machines proved to be substantially less than the advertised figures. Fines totalling $51,000 were imposed.

I have instanced those cases to suggest that on the face of it-and there may be a better explanation-there appear to have been some successful prosecutions, perhaps in a couple of instances as I have suggested, involving admissions by the defendants. The Attorney-General says that it is virtually impossible to obtain successful prosecutions in this matter where one must depend on conclusive proof of lack of belief or recklessness, but there seem to be occasions where there has been success. I raised this matter with the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the legal adviser to that Committee said that in each case, however, it was clear that there was a necessity for predictions which were alleged to contravene section 59 of the Act to be made either recklessly or without belief that they would ultimately be satisfied. Quite frankly I do not find it offensive that we should require the prosecution to establish that the acts were committed recklessly or without belief that they would ultimately be satisfied. In fact one can achieve some success in this matter because it seems to me that the cost of doing it the other way round, of putting the onus on the company, involves reversal of the onus of proof in a matter of grave seriousness, which to me is totally improper. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee took a particular view and I quote from its report of 4 December 1985 in which it said:

. . . while the Committee is prepared to concede that in some instances the reversal of the persuasive onus of proof may be justified by the particular circumstances of the case . . . the Committee does not believe that this is such a case.
It is, of course, referring to this legislation. The Committee goes on:

In most criminal proceedings the prosecution is required to prove the state of mind of the accused and it is difficult to see why belief as to the correctness of promises or predictions should be in any different position.

In this particular case the Committee makes a suggestion about the position which exists if, in fact, the Attorney-General is correct in saying that it was impossible for the prosecution to prove its case-for example, in the Mastertouch case-and that it is virtually impossible to establish this situation which, however, seems to be capable of being established in normal criminal matters. I do not know why it cannot be established in these matters. Perhaps that is a quirk of the law which I, as a non-lawyer, do not understand. If that principle exists so comfortably in criminal law, why can it not exist in such matters as these? In any event, if there is a real problem the Committee has suggested that in this case a reasonable balance would be struck by placing on the defendant an evidential burden, since the basis on which it makes its predictions is peculiarly within its knowledge, but then requiring the prosecution to rebut the evidence that has been so advanced. I do not know whether the Minister for Resources and Energy feels like responding to that, but it seems to me that we face the problem that if we resolve the matter which the Attorney-General has alleged-that it is virtually impossible to get prosecutions-by reversing the onus of proof, we are doing more damage than we are correcting. There must always be a clear version of cost and benefit in this matter.

This requirement of imposing a persuasive onus of proof on the defendant trespasses unduly on personal rights and liberties. In this matter I agree with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, of which I am a member. If we are to have legislation which we are happy to see in this Senate, which imposes on personal rights and liberties, which reverses the onus of proof and which interferes significantly with the existing relationship between professional people and their clients involving a curious warranty which does some extraordinary things about the recall of a product without having to seek a court order, about which the Small Business Association made mention, if this Bill is to do all these things, it seems to merit some reasonable responses from the Government. The fact that the Law Council of Australia is still very concerned about this Bill in its present state, despite the flood of proposed and possible amendments, seems to be a very sound case for its being looked at much more thoroughly by the Senate. I would certainly welcome the opportunity in the Committee stage to support the many amendments that Senator Durack will move. I urge the Senate, and the Australian Democrats in particular, to recognise the dangers existing in this Bill at present and to support the Opposition in its attitude to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The nature of the Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986 was best summarised by Senator Haines, who said at one point in her speech that it was not anti-business, it was anti-bad business. That is perfectly correct. The Bill is designed to and does promote good, efficient business and discourages anti-competitive, stultifying, stodgy, bad business. The Government does not believe that the Bill embodies any obsessive preoccupation with business regulation for its own sake or business regulation that operates in some counterproductive way to the interests of our national economy any more than we believe those allegations are true of the parent Act which this amending Bill is designed to streamline and attend to in various ways in the light of accumulated experience of recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: Those matters about claims of an excessively regulatory character are dealt with, as are most of the other points made by Senator Short, Senator Durack and Senator Michael Baume, in my second reading reply on the first round of this debate on 11 February. I do not want to bore the Senate by repeating what I then said, but I note that other senators have not felt so constrained. I simply refer to pages 71 to 73 passim of my speech in Hansard on 11 February 1986. A number of other matters of detail, including the onus of proof issues raised by Senator Michael Baume, are more appropriately dealt with at the Committee stage and I will reserve more detailed remarks for that occasion.

There were a couple of matters raised in the course of the debate which I do think need some attention, however. One was Senator Short's assertion that the Bill was steamrollered through the House of Representatives-a familiar theme with other speakers; and the other point which needs attention is slightly more detailed and that is Senator Macklin's argument that this Bill, in terms of its presentation to the Parliament on this occasion, represents a culmination of some elaborate conspiracy theory on the part of the Government, designed to deny the Senate its proper rights. In the minute or so available to me, I am happy to assure Senator Macklin that there is no foundation whatsoever for his concerns. The treatment of the Bill as a money Bill, in relation to which a message from the Governor-General has been received, characterises it as an appropriation Bill which accordingly can only be introduced in the House of Representatives. The reason for that is simply an abundance of caution on the part of the Parliamentary Counsel about the way in which a Bill of this kind should be treated when it contains a clause, as this one does, by the amendment to section 170 of the existing Act, which in effect appropriates money for legal aid or financial assistance to litigants.
