DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Dilantin-Domestic Violence: Report of Australian Law Reform Commission

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., pursuant to Sessional Order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise this evening concerns the decision of the Government to take dilantin, the drug used by epileptics, off the list of drugs which are available at a nominal cost. I have been approached by Jennifer Lucas, who suffers from epilepsy and is very concerned about the Government's decision regarding dilantin. She informed me that dilantin is the No. 1 anti-spasmodic drug which most epileptics use.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Queensland Daily Sun newspaper recently, Mr Mike Cavanagh, the Secretary of the Epilepsy Association, was reported as saying that during World Health Week epilepsy sufferers would seek public support for their protest about the increased cost of dilantin, the drug on which all epilepsy sufferers rely. Mr Cavanagh pointed out that dilantin is a drug which epilepsy sufferers usually take for life and it is very important that they continue to take it. On 1 April the cost of dilantin went up by $1.57 a prescription. It was one of the three drugs affected by legislation passed last year which allowed a part charge on prescriptions when the Government and the manufacturer could not agree on the price of the drug.

About 350,000 people suffer from epilepsy in Australia, with 314,000 prescriptions for dilantin being issued annually. Epilepsy sufferers say that they need these tablets to keep them alive, but most certainly to stop them from having seizures. The Hawke Labor Government repeatedly claims that it is concerned for the disadvantaged and chronically ill, but this action of increasing the cost of dilantin, which is used by people with epilepsy, is most unreasonable and does not show care and concern for epileptics.

Epilepsy is a chronic condition and many people for whom dilantin is prescribed are unable to work. I believe that it is unreasonable to ask those people to pay more. I have raised this matter to draw the Government's attention to this problem. I hope that it will see its way clear to put dilantin back on the list of drugs which are available at a nominal cost. I am sure that the many people who suffer from epilepsy would be grateful if that action were taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I raise tonight concerns the Law Reform Commission report No. 30 on domestic violence. I understand from having read the report-albeit not every word, but close thereto-that it relates particularly to the law in the Australian Capital Territory. Nonetheless, the report makes some comments that are useful and of interest to people in the States who are concerned with this growing problem, or the growing awareness of the problem, in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I make is that this report is one of the few I have read which acknowledge that in this field there are competing interests and principles; firstly, that we should be free from violent attacks and, secondly, that the privacy of our homes should be protected from the intrusion of police officers, social welfare workers and the like. It is a pleasure, in an odd sort of way, to read a report on such an unfortunate issue which acknowledges that all is not black and white, that there are some grey areas and that we need to work in a bipartisan way to address the problems created which are in these grey areas.

One example of a grey area is dealt with on pages 18, 19, 20 and following with respect to arrest. The report of the Law Reform Commission states that it is concerned to see that arrest is not seen as a penalty. I have a concern that law enforcement procedures are not unwittingly misused-I stress `unwittingly'-as welfare procedures. I acknowledge that the boundaries of the two areas-namely, the powers that the police need to keep the peace and the welfare needs of the community-overlap. This is one of the grey areas in which we should tread with some caution when the civil liberties of the alleged offender are at risk. I do not mean to take up the cause of wife bashers around Australia, but simply to flag that it is a grey area where we should not let our zeal to attack the truly violent in the community interfere with our long held beliefs on protecting the innocent.

I noticed that mention was made in the report that the expense of handling the variety of orders one can get in the Australian States to protect victims, in particular women, from domestic violence, is necessarily lower in the magistrates courts than in other courts. That is true, but I remind my colleagues that the victims of domestic violence are not always people whose income or assets is so limited that they cannot get legal aid. As often as not, they are women whose income or assets excludes them from getting legal aid and who for a whole variety of reasons, some of which are not necessarily acceptable, would not go to welfare agencies for assistance. Those women have to fund a prosecution for protection themselves. In South Australia a guilty plea on a drink driving offence, which is basically five minutes work for a solicitor, costs $160, so a run of hearings on a protection order would cost substantially more than that. I simply wave a flag of caution in saying that it is simply not good enough to say that the expense of going to a lower court is less, without acknowledging that the expense for a private citizen to pursue such an action is quite prohibitive.

I did not notice in the report any reference to the administrative procedures under which these actions are pursued. The report mentions the situation in South Australia, where there are three circumstances under which one might appear before a court. Firstly, there is the hearing for a preliminary temporary order, at which the alleged offender does not have to be present-in other words, the court can proceed ex parte. A couple of weeks after that there is a hearing for a confirmation of the preliminary order. At that time or at a later stage there is another hearing for a variation of the original or confirmed order. A problem is created by the administrative procedures because the second and third hearings must be heard before the same person who heard the first one, so the rostering of magistrates can result in extensive delays. For the private person or the taxpayer who is funding these actions, this can prove an exorbitant cost because the solicitor does not say: `Never mind, that, I have wasted another morning; we cannot get on before the same magistrate and I cannot get paid'. The solicitor is paid. The victim of domestic violence or the Legal Services Commission has to find the money-approximately 80c in the dollar-to fund this lousy administration.

While administration of these matters is not an exciting area of law reform for people to pursue, in a practical way it affects the people who are trying to protect their own safety by taking out these sorts of orders. Accordingly, I ask any honourable senators who have even a passing interest in this matter to make some time to cast their eyes over this report and to come to some conclusions about the matters raised therein.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.40 p.m.
